Abstract

Background
-----------------
Background
As a treatment for the common cold, cough, sore throat, and influenza, honey has been used since ancient times. It is expected that various effects (such as anti-inflammatory, immunomodulatory, anti-infection, protective effects, etc.) are obtained by eating honey. Although a large amount of studies have been conducted, there is still little evidence in Japan to support those expectations. Since honey is a fermented food, there may be a difference in efficacy between each type of honey due to the difference in the species of the honey bee from which it is made, the pollen in the honey, the degree of ripening (fermentation), and other factors. Therefore, a systematic review and meta-analysis of the effects of types of honey on the prevention or treatment of the common cold have been conducted.
Objective
This systematic review and meta-analysis aims to clarify the effects of honey species on the prevention or treatment of the common cold by conducting a systematic review using Web of Science, Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, Joanna Briggs Institute, Efficacy Review Database, LIVIVELink, ClinicalTrials, DART-Europe, Korea Research Index, and China National Knowledge Infrastructure databases. For the treatment of the common cold, the effect of honey on the duration of cold symptoms and honey on the degree of improvement of symptom severity will be investigated. As for the prevention of the common cold, the effects on the prevention of colds, the number of days away from work, missed workdays, and days absent from school will be investigated.
Methods
We will conduct a literature search using the following search terms: Honey OR honey species OR honey quality OR honey composition* OR nectar. We will include studies that are randomized controlled trials and observe the treatment or prevention effect of honey, as well as studies that meet the following three criteria: 1) honey, 2) cold, 3) preventive or curative effect of honey, and 4) study conducted in Japan, North America, Europe, South America, Australia, Oceania, and Asia. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Evaluate the feasibility of conducting a multicenter, phase II trial of stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) for lung cancer in children.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related death in children and young adults. Due to the relatively low incidence of pediatric lung cancer, and because most children diagnosed with the disease are not eligible for prospective trial enrollment, it is unclear how best to treat this malignancy. This is especially applicable to patients with Stage III disease. It has been shown that advanced stage metastatic lung cancer patients have substantially improved survival when treated with hypofractionated stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT), rather than conventional radiotherapy (RT), for lung lesions. The efficacy of this treatment in improving overall survival when applied to pediatric lung disease is not known. It is our hypothesis that pediatric lesions will be comparable to adults in terms of responsiveness to both SBRT and conventional RT. The purpose of this study is to conduct a phase I/II dose-escalation trial of SBRT in children and young adults with lung and/or central nervous system (CNS) metastases and/or primary pulmonary tumors that are not amenable to surgery or conventional RT due to poor lung function.

Official Title
-----------------
Phase 1/2 Feasibility Trial for Radiosurgical Treatment of Children With Advanced Lung Disease

Background: People in Southern US states have the highest prevalence of chronic diseases and highest prevalence of HIV among the nation. HIV incidence among Black women, the fastest growing at‐ risk group, is four times the national average with little decreases seen over the last fifteen years. This highlights an urgent need for development, evaluation, and implementation of interventions for Black women who have or are at risk for HIV. One approach to achieving this is the Five Point Initiative, a community‐based participatory research (CBPR) intervention developed with and for Black women at high risk for HIV. This novel community‐based participatory intervention will empower the voice of the community and engage community members to be a part of identifying solutions for the greatest challenges that face Black women living in Black communities. Methods: Community‐based events, held bimonthly in the community from July 2020 to June 2021, will be utilized to deliver Five Point Initiative‐based interventions. Events will take place at pre‐existing venues throughout five points in African‐American communities in Miami‐Dade County and will target key community stakeholders, such as religious leaders, business owners, community organizations, and other Black women. These key community stakeholders will also play a part in co‐designing and providing feedback on the content at the events. Findings. This approach will serve to strengthen the partnership between community stakeholders, researchers, and community members to decrease stigma of getting tested for HIV, increase testing for HIV and STIs and linkage to services through the Community Navigation Center. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to investigate a potentially more conservative strategy of treatment for patients presenting with intermediate-risk prostate cancer who are candidates for prostatectomy. The strategy involves preoperative salvage radiation therapy (RT) rather than standard postoperative salvage therapy.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The trial will evaluate safety and prostate-specific antigen (PSA) failure-free survival (PFS), defined as PSA nadir + 2 ng/mL for 1 year or more. PFS will be estimated with 95% confidence according to the Kaplan-Meier method. The incidence of adverse events will be described for Grade ≥ 3 genitourinary (GU) and lower gastrointestinal (GI) toxicity and any Grade ≥ 4 toxicity.

Introduction:
Neonatal alloimmune thrombocytopenia (NAIT) is a disorder in which maternal alloimmune antibodies in pregnancy causes severe thrombocytopenia in a fetus. The first line treatment is steroids. If platelet count is not corrected within 48h, IVIG is usually used. 

Aims & Methods:
An Open label study was conducted at department of neonatology at Siriraj Hospital. A total of 43 neonates with NAIT and severe thrombocytopenia between 1.5 to 5k/μl were included in the study during January 2017 to December 2018. Pregnancies with high risk of fetal thrombocytopenia that was indicated by Fetal anemia, small for gestational age, or hydros fetalis  were excluded from the study. 

Out of the 43 neonates who required IVIG, 27 were given with steroids as well. 

Out of 43 neonates, 21 neonates received steroids only, 21 neonates received steroids with IVIG and one neonate received IVIG only. 

The neonate was followed up till platelet count of ≥50 k/μl (corrected for hematocrit) without any bleeding sign and symptoms. 

Results:
Out of 21 neonates who were treated with steroids only, total of 12 (57.14%) neonates responded very rapidly (<12 hours) to the steroids. Eight neonates (38.09%) did not show significant response within 12 hours. Out of 21 neonates who were treated with steroids and IVIG, total of 15 (71.42%) neonates responded very rapidly to the treatment and six (28.57%) did not show significant response to the treatment (p value 0.545). Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
PURPOSE: Prostate cancer is often associated with other concurrent malignancies. The objective of this exploratory study is to assess the frequency and nature of these malignancies in patients being treated with prostatectomy or radiotherapy in order to inform the design of a clinical trial.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Prostate cancer represents a significant public health problem in the United States, where it is the most common malignancy in males. Approximately 233,000 new cases are diagnosed each year and, despite improvements in surgical techniques and therapeutic regimens, it is the second leading cause of cancer-related death in males. Prostate cancer is frequently associated with tumors from other epithelial sites. This comorbidity may be a function of a field effect attributable to shared common carcinogens, or may reflect an increased inflammatory state in the prostate with an increased risk for cancer in other tissues. Understanding the relationship between prostate cancer and malignancies in other sites may improve the long-term understanding of their underlying pathogenesis, and may inform new approaches for screening and diagnosis, as well as for more appropriate use of existing treatments. Recent studies have established that a large percentage of men with prostate cancer under a common genetic alteration in chromosome 8q24 that predisposes to urothelial tumors; the presence of this chromosome alteration may have a role in the increased risk for malignancies associated with prostate cancer. In addition, patients with prostate cancer are at an increased risk for other malignancies including renal cancer, hepatocellular cancer, and urothelial cancer. This cohort will focus on evaluating the presence of concurrent gastrointestinal malignancies in men undergoing curative treatment for localized prostate cancer. The primary hypothesis is that the frequency and extent of concurrent gastrointestinal malignancies in this population are higher when compared to the general population. An exploration of the nature and timing of these can

This study arm is designed to help us evaluate the impact of the educational intervention on the rates of germline genetic testing completion in prostate cancer patients across different risk groups. The use of a trained clinical research coordinator to deliver the educational intervention ensures standardized delivery of information to all participants, regardless of their risk group or family history. This approach will allow us to evaluate the effectiveness of the educational intervention in a real-world setting, regardless of patient characteristics. Furthermore, the comparison between the study group and the control group will help us to understand the impact of the educational intervention on genetic testing uptake even when patients have a different genetic predisposition, either through a positive family history or through their own genetic mutations. This will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of the educational intervention and its applicability to different populations. Overall, this study arm will help to improve the uptake of genetic testing in prostate cancer patients, leading to better outcomes in high-risk, very-high risk, and metastatic prostate cancer patients, regardless of their family history of prostate cancer or other genetic predispositions.

Abstract:
Background: Lung cancer is one of the top most morbidity causes and the leading cause of cancer deaths worldwide.. Early lung tumors (LTE) with a diameter of 1‐3 cm have a very high risk of becoming malignant and are challenging to treat as well as difficult to diagnose. This paper outlines the study design of a Phase 1 trial evaluating the safety and tolerability of Padeliporfin Vascular Targeted Photodynamic Therapy (VTP) in patients with peripheral lung tumors (PLTs) who are at high risk of malignant neoplasms. Methods: The study will have two parts: Part A, a dose escalation/de‐escalation study which will employ a modified 3+3 design for Part A. Part B will evaluate the MTD and RP2D for Padeliporfin VTP therapy. We will enroll 14‐36 patients in each of the Part A dosage stratum cohorts. Conclusion: VTP will be delivered through robotic-assisted bronchoscopy (RAB), a technique that is increasingly being utilized in the evaluation and treatment of patients with lung nodules. The use of RAB is minimally invasive in diagnosis and treatment and can reduce morbidity and mortality. The study design will provide a novel approach to early lung tumors using VTP and may revolutionize the treatment of these tumors.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of the study is to investigate whether the use of new, digital methods with artificial intelligence can speed up the process of detecting a perforation in the colon wall, and be used in a clinical setting in the future. The study will include all patients admitted to the surgery department at Stavanger University Hospital for urgent surgery due to colon perforation. The study is a quality assurance evaluation of the results of traditional and artificial intelligent radiographic imaging. The diagnosis of colon perforation is based on CT scan, ultrasound, contrast enemas, and surgical findings at surgery. In short, a small sample of water will be removed and examined for the presence of bacteria, using a new, digital and automated tool.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study is a quality assurance evaluation of the diagnosis of perforated colon. Patients undergoing surgery for acute colon perforation are eligible for inclusion. 2-5 cm of colon will be sampled, to be examined for the presence of bacteria and other organisms. This study includes an additional and new quality assessment method, which is a digital, fast and precise detection method (Molecular Diagnostics). The traditional way of quality assurance in detecting a perforation is to open the abdominal cavity and examine visually whether there is a fluid pocket, which is considered a sign of a perforation in the wall of the colon. This method cannot be completed with absolute certainty due to the limited visibility of surgical areas, which may lead to undetected colon perforations. With the introduction of new and more advanced digital methods for radiography and artificial intelligence, it becomes easier to find a perforation in the patient's abdominal scan. In addition, it is becoming increasingly clear that there are living bacteria and other organisms in the lumen of the colon all the time, although it is unclear how far they move from the colon. In addition, it is unclear whether it is possible for bacteria to cross the digestive system wall and colonize it, or cause peritonitis. In this study, the aim is to investigate whether the digestive tract wall has been perforated, how far back into the gastrointestinal tract it went, and whether there are bacteria in the liquid from the gastrointestinal tract. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the feasibility of a novel method to measure bone formation at two separate points in time (a baseline and 6-month post-operatively) by a non-invasive imaging technique (Dual energy X-ray absorptiometry - DEXA). We hypothesize that this method will be able to detect differences in rates of bone formation in surgically treated spine fractures post-posterior decompression and posterolateral fusion. As part of this feasibility assessment, we will use the DEXA measurements to investigate if changes in bone metabolism are associated with improvements in subjective strength and functionality as measured by the SF-36 questionnaire. In addition, we will compare postoperative radiographic results on serial x-rays to determine if the novel method is accurate. Lastly, we will explore the relationship between subjective and objective measurements of bone healing (such as the SF-36). Data collected in this study will be useful in designing a future randomized controlled trial to determine if treatments can be altered to enhance the rate of osteogenesis in these challenging cases.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This study will enroll 20 to 40 patients undergoing treatment for thoracolumbar fractures. The following procedures will be performed: at baseline, on day 1 after surgery, at the 4-week visit, at the 6-week visit, and at the 12-week visit: subjective assessment by SF-36 questionnaire objective assessment by DEXA scan radiographic evaluation by x-ray (anterior posterior, lateral)

Official Title
-----------------
Application of Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DEXA) to Investigate Subjective, Imaging, and Physiologic Correlations in Patients Undergoing Treatment for Spinal Fractures

Conditions

Spinal Fracture, Lumbar Fracture, Spinal Trauma, Spinal Injuries

* Diagnostic Test: Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DEXA)

Abstract:
It is becoming recognised by the public that there is a strong link between cancer and poor dietary intakes of fruit and vegetables. This view is not supported by strong evidence but by the fact that some fruits, including pomegranates, are known to affect genes involved in cancer development. Therefore, the aim of this study was to examine the effect of pomegranate supplementation on the expression of genes involved in DNA repair mechanisms. In a randomised, double‐blind placebo controlled parallel group study, 190 newly diagnosed colorectal cancer (CRC) patients consumed 2.5 mL concentrated pomegranate juice or a placebo daily for six months following surgery to obtain CRC specimens for microarray analysis. Microarray analysis was undertaken following the selection of differentially expressed genes using statistical software. In addition, candidate gene expression was confirmed using real time PCR. Overall, there was a significant reduction in gene expression of 22 genes in participants treated with pomegranate compared to those who consumed a placebo. Further analysis of these candidate genes showed that pomegranate treatment increased the expression of 12 genes involved in DNA repair pathways and decreased the expression of 10 genes involved in carcinogenesis and cancer progression. As pomegranate juice consumption could reduce tumour progression via modulation of various genes involved in cancer progression, it has considerable potential as a chemopreventive dietary agent for CRC.

Background
-----------------
Age-related stroke is the main cause of death in middle age. It has been shown that the initial inflammatory mediators of the bloodstream after ischemic stroke are mainly released by immune cells and endothelial cell activation in the periphery. These molecules enter the brain after crossing the blood-brain barrier. The soluble cluster of differentiation (CD)14 protein was found to be an immune mediator associated with cerebral injury after cerebral infarctions in animal models of ischemic stroke.
In addition to its potential role as a clinical biomarker, it is unclear whether CD14, as a novel therapeutic target, may alter the effect of intravenous rtPA in patients with acute ischemic stroke. The

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the most common type of liver cancer and is often associated with a poor prognosis. Advanced liver cancer is difficult to treat, and the overall survival rate is low. Interventional therapy, targeted therapy, immunotherapy, and other treatments have been used in recent years to improve the effectiveness of HCC treatment. However, no single treatment can effectively eradicate HCC, and drug resistance is a major problem. Some patients who initially have favorable treatment responses will eventually relapse. In recent years, research has shown that the use of drugs to reduce drug resistance in HCC can improve the treatment outcome. This study aims to explore the efficacy of adding apatinib and camrelizumab (Apa‐Cam) to the treatment of advanced liver cancer, further providing reference for the treatment of advanced liver cancer. METHODS: This is a single‐center, single‐arm, open‐label, phase II clinical trial. A total of 18 participants with advanced liver cancer who meet the inclusion criteria and are taking apatinib plus camrelizumab will be recruited, and the primary endpoint is tumor response rate. The secondary endpoints include disease control rate, progression‐free survival rate, overall survival rate, adverse events, and pharmacokinetics. RESULTS: By February 2021, a total of 36 participants had been included in the study, all of whom were over 18 years old, diagnosed with HCC, and received the treatment for two months. Among the 36 participants, 17 participants showed complete response and the average tumor response rate was 53.9%. After two months of treatment

Abstract:
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a malignant tumor with high recurrence rate and poor prognosis after radical resection or local therapies. Therefore, the combination of immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) and chemotherapy is an effective treatment for advanced HCC. The aim of this study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of nivolumab combined with regorafenib in the treatment of advanced HCC. We will also investigate the mechanism of action of this combination therapy. The primary endpoint is progression‐free survival (PFS). Secondary endpoints include overall survival (OS), objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), and toxicity. Patients with AFP≥400ng/ml, ECOG score 0‐1, and BCLC stage B‐C will be enrolled and randomized to regorafenib alone (armA) or regorafenib plus nivolumab (armB).

Acute decompensation event, hepatic encephalopathy grade ≥ 2, acute kidney injury (stage 3 acute kidney injury (AKI) according to Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcome (KDIGO), serum bilirubin ≥ 10 mg/dl, and hemodynamic instability with vasopressor support are all signs of acute-on-chronic liver failure (ACLF). ACLF is accompanied by a  high risk of rapid mortality if aggressive medical therapy and treatment modalities are not immediately available. This is why we set up the COOLEY study. The cytoSorb device is a medical device that reduces the blood circulating cytokines and other inflammatory mediators. The device will be used to improve survival and clinical outcomes in severely ill patients after acute complications with concomitant liver failure. In the COOLEY study, severe ACLF is defined as grade ≥ 2 according to European Association for the Study of the Liver (EASL) clinical classification. We will enroll 40 patients from the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) of the UZA between December 2021 and December 2022.

Abstract:
The purpose of this study was to determine the feasibility and patient burden of a comprehensive and multimodal physiotherapy program in the home environment of people with mild to moderate traumatic brain injury (TBI). 20 patients were recruited from a traumatic brain injury service in NSW, Australia. Patients were assessed by either a physiotherapist or allied health assistant at baseline. Participants then received a multimodal therapy program including a comprehensive home safety assessment, provision of aids and adaptive equipment, home exercise, and self‐monitoring. Patients were then reassessed 3, 6, and 12 months following the initial assessment. There was a significant decrease in the incidence of falls over the trial period and this was greater in those patients with the highest baseline fall risk. There was a significant reduction in the number of ADLs missed due to physical reasons following the intervention. These findings suggest that a comprehensive home‐based intervention can be feasible following mild to moderate traumatic brain injury. The findings of this study provide evidence that a multimodal rehabilitation approach may help to promote health and reduce the risk of falls in the home environment for traumatic brain injury patients.

This article presents 2 cases of myelopathy after intravenous (IV) injection of 18F-labelet in a 12-month period, based on an increased awareness for the occurrence of adverse drug reactions associated with the injection of 18F-labelet into the lumbar vessel.
In 2016, 25 patients (9 men) referred for routine 18F-labelet PET‐CTs at our hospital were studied following an IV bolus injection administered into the femoral or median cubital veins. Study on the Evaluation of the Sensibility and the Specificity of the Lymphatic Vessel and the Lymph Node Detection in CNS Infection Patients

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Background: In this research, the efficacy of a technique using ultrafast CT (UFCT), which can generate quantifiable and measurable images to measure the lymphatics of the human body in seconds, was assessed in patients with brain infection. Methods: In this randomized clinical trial study, seventy patients with brain infection admitted to Isfahan Shaheed Beheshti University of Medical Sciences and Health Services were randomly selected as the research communities. Ultrafast CT was performed for all of the research subjects. The lymph node density was calculated for each patient and compared with the findings of the gold standard diagnostic method (clinical and laboratory findings). Findings: The findings of the study showed that for patients from 0 to 75 years old, ultrafast CT is an appropriate method for evaluating the density of cervical lymph nodes and assessing lymphatic drainage status in brain infection patients.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This research was conducted at the Isfahan Shaheed Beheshti University of Medical Sciences and Health Services in 2022. The study population was patients with brain infection admitted to the hospital for diagnosis and treatment. Eligible participants are those who have given written informed consent to participate in the study. Ultrafast CT was performed for all of the research subjects. The lymph node density was calculated for each patient and compared with the findings of the gold standard diagnostic method (clinical and laboratory findings).

Abstract:
Background & Aims: Endoscopic resection of large colonic lesions is a relatively recent topic in the field of polyp endoscopic resection. Among several different endoscopic procedures, conventional hot EMR or en bloc endoscopic mucosal resection, remains the standard technique for the en‐bloc removal, regardless of the lesion endoscopic appearance or size. Hot EMR involves piece‐meal dissection and resection of the polyps, followed by ablation of the lateral and deep margins with an electrocoagulation probe. The aim of the study was to compare the feasibility of conventional Hot EMR and novel Cold EMR with respect to the specimen resection rate, complete resection rate, polyp sizes, lesion locations, number of endoscopic procedures, and hospital stay. Materials and Methods: This randomized trial was conducted in 100 patients who were randomly allocated to hot or cold EMR from May 2017 to September 2020 at a single institute. The primary endpoint was the complete resection of the target lesion at the first attempt with the exception of fragmenting, while maintaining feasibility within ± 20% of previous studies. Results: A total of 180 lesions (102 lesions in the cold EMR group and 78 lesions in the hot EMR group) were included. The complete resection rate was significantly higher in the hot EMR group than in the cold EMR (96.2 vs. 89.1%, respectively). When the polyp sizes and lesion locations were analyzed, the complete resection rate in the hot EMR group was significantly higher in lesions larger than 20 mm (93.8% vs. 80.0%

Brief Summary

Treatment of osteosarcoma relies primarily on cytotoxic chemotherapy. While these drugs generally do a good job of controlling the disease, the toxic side effects can often be debilitating. Furthermore, the development of drug resistance and the subsequent decrease of effective treatments are other important problems that can reduce the effectiveness of chemotherapy. The purpose of this study is to examine whether treatment of osteosarcoma with the combination of the cytotoxic drug Ifosfamide and the non-cytotoxic drug Everolimus will result in higher response rates, longer progression free survival (PFS), and increased overall survival (OS) rates without increasing toxicity. 70 patients with relapsed or refractory osteosarcoma will be accrued and treated. All study participants will receive 2300 mg/m^2 of Ifosfamide subcutaneously on days 1-3 followed by 5 mg/m^2 of Everolimus daily orally on days 3-8 every 2 weeks. PFS will be determined by CT/MRI scans according to RECIST standards and OS is defined as the time from enrollment to death from any cause.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of the study is supportive care with facilitated ACP sessions to promote advance care planning, reduce decisional conflict, increase the completion of advance directives, promote quality of life, and improve clinical outcomes in older adults who have been living on the street for a long time. The intervention is a structured ACP session for older adults who have been chronically homeless that will utilize principles of facilitation and narrative gerontology. Participants in the intervention group will receive facilitated group sessions and participants in the control group will receive facilitated one to one sessions.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This will be the first feasibility study to examine the efficacy of a facilitated ACP intervention for older formerly homeless adults who currently reside in Permanent Supportive Housing (PSH). This intervention is needed as this population is at a greater risk of chronic, life-limiting illnesses than their housing-stable counterparts. The goals of this study are 1) to evaluate the feasibility of conducting intervention sessions to improve ACP completion, 2) to reduce decisional conflict, 3) to support quality of life and increase clinical and behavioral health outcomes 4) to identify factors that may influence successful implementation, and 5) to identify gaps or shortfalls in the delivery of the intervention. The hypotheses for this study are that the control group will have higher rates of decisional conflict and lower rates of ACP completion than the intervention group. We also expect the intervention group to increase end of life planning, health literacy, and perceived social support, and reduce social isolation. Further, those participants randomized to the intervention will demonstrate improved clinical and behavioral measures and greater quality of life indicators than those in the control group.

Brief summary in scientific language
=================
The clinical problem is that most individuals with depression do not respond to an antidepressant after treatment for 8 weeks. Depression is a common disease that is the leading cause of disability worldwide. The consequences of depression include an increase in mortality, comorbidities, suicide, and reduced quality of life and work capacity. Although there are many available antidepressant drugs, 30-40% of individuals with depression experience inadequate treatment outcomes. Although the clinical practice guidelines recommend a switch to a different antidepressant if the first antidepressant fails after 8 weeks, there is uncertainty regarding an alternative when this option is not effective. The proposed solution to this problem is to target the pathophysiology of the disease. The hypothesis that we want to test is that cognitive biases associated with depression can help to predict medication response or lack thereof. If this hypothesis is confirmed, it will lead to an approach based on the underlying pathophysiology of depression, rather than trial and error, which will improve treatment outcomes and reduce the risk of treatment failure. This can also help to reduce costs. We propose a randomized controlled trial to investigate whether a psychological treatment that targets cognitive biases is more effective than a placebo in preventing relapse in MDD or BP. This trial also aims to explore whether the effect of this intervention is mediated by cognitive biases. 

Brief summary in easily understood language
=================
Treatment with antidepressant medications is a common treatment option for depression, but approximately one-third of individuals do not respond. This can lead to further research to find ways to improve treatment. Some of these approaches focus on finding the right medication for an individual, while others focus on understanding the causes of this lack of improvement. The proposed solution to this problem is to target the underlying mechanisms that are related to the disease and the medication. The investigators want to test if a psychological intervention that trains individuals to change their thoughts (cognitive biases) can improve the effectiveness of medication.

Brief Summary

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety of percutaneous translational angioplasty (TA) in the treatment of intracranial artery atherosclerotic stenosis or stenosis, compared with medical treatment alone.

-----------------
Percutaneous transluminal catheter angioplasty (PTA) is the first effective and minimally invasive intervention for cerebral artery stenosis or stenosis. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Levetiracetam is a new anti-epileptic drug. It has been used in the treatment of epilepsy in children and adults. In this study, the investigators evaluate the anti-epileptic efficacy and side effects associated with levetiracetam in combination with valproic acid or clonazepam. The investigators also evaluate the pharmacokinetic characteristics of levetiracetam in combination with valproic acid or clonazepam.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Cases of epilepsy with or without generalization seizure of children and patients with epilepsy with or without generalization seizure (aged 5-12 years old) were selected in the present study. The investigators enrolled 120 cases of children and 60 cases of adults based on random number table method, and administered 1000mg of levetiracetam orally. Cases were followed up 16 weeks, and adverse reactions were monitored. At the same time, the efficacy of epilepsy and the pharmacokinetics of levetiracetam in different age populations were observed.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Several studies have shown that the use of topical anesthesia with lidocaine in the delivery of epidural anesthesia provides significant improvement and patient satisfaction as compared to the use of pre‐block. Pre‐block consists of injecting the local anesthetic solution between the skin and the subcutaneous tissue at the site of epidural needle puncture. In this study, we compared the effects of pre‐block with the traditional anesthetic techniques performed in the labor room before epidural analgesia.MATERIAL AND METHODS: A prospective randomized study was conducted at the labor room of Benha University maternity hospital between October 2016 and February 2017. The study included 120 parturients. 60 parturients in each group were randomly assigned to pre‐block or a conventional anesthetic technique.RESULTS: Pain was evaluated using a visual analog scale (VAS) before puncture, after the epidural needle was inserted through the skin, after the epidural catheter had been inserted, and five minutes after the injection of the local anesthetic solution. At these four assessment times, pain was assessed in the conventional group and pre‐block group. The VAS scores for pain, post‐blocking nausea, and overall satisfaction levels were compared between the two groups.CONCLUSIONS: For epidural analgesia, the pre‐block technique reduces pain compared to a conventional technique. It is useful for labor induction epidural anesthesia and significantly improves patient satisfaction.

Title
=================
Comparing a 4-day Low Carbohydrate, High Fat Diet Versus a 4-day Low-Fat, High Carbohydrate Diet in Athletes during Training

Scientific title
=================
A randomized cross-over study comparing a 4-day low carbohydrate, high fat diet versus a 4-day low-fat, high carbohydrate diet in athletic performance during concurrent training

Plain English Summary
=================
Background and study aimsCarbohydrates are an essential part of an athlete’s diet as they are the main fuel source for exercise. However, certain athletes will use up a lot of carbohydrates during the day due to their high training and competition workload. It may be that after a few days of high training volume, athletes would not be able to replace their energy stores (e.g. glycogen) through the amount of carbohydrates provided from their diet. Therefore, certain athletes may experience fatigue if the amount of carbohydrates provided from the diet is not enough for a number of days following training. Dietary strategies such as reducing the amount of carbohydrates in the diet while increasing the amount of fat may be beneficial for restocking energy stores (glycogen). We hypothesise that a diet low in carbohydrate with higher fat would be more effective in restoring glycogen (stored energy) in athletes following a heavy training period compared to a diet high in carbohydrate.Who can participate?You may be eligible to participate in this study if you:are a male athlete between 16 and 40 years of ageare able to maintain low-carbohydrate daily intakes, are in good health and do not have any chronic illness

OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the efficacy of a structured education programme in increasing self‐care in people with severe mental illness (SMI).DESIGN: We conducted a randomised control trial.SETTING: A community mental health care setting in the Netherlands.PARTICIPANTS: Participants were 50 persons meeting the ICD‐10 criteria for schizophrenia, schizotypal and delusional disorders, bipolar affective disorders, major or recurrent depression, and anxiety disorders and recruited from the outpatient clinic at Maastricht‐University Medical Centre.INTERVENTIONS: The 16‐session self‐care intervention.MAIN OUTCOME MEASUREMENTS: The primary outcome was the Global Assessment of Functioning, including a self‐care subscale. Secondary outcomes were the Social Cognition and Interaction Scale, the Work and Social Adjustment Scale, health‐related quality of life, and medication compliance.RESULTS: Results of this trial demonstrated that an 18‐month structured education programme is feasible to improve the ability of people with SMI to understand and self‐manage their illness. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Older adults with atrial fibrillation (AF) are at risk of poorer quality of life (QoL), impaired cognitive function, and adverse cardiovascular events. We developed a novel museum intervention in older adults with controlled AF, using mindful awareness and sensory stimulation. In older adults with AF, we hypothesize that the novel intervention will improve QoL, cognitive function, cardiovascular (CV) functions, as well as promote psychological well-being. The main objectives of this study are to: 1) assess the feasibility and acceptability of a novel museum intervention in older adults with controlled AF.

Detailed Description
-----------------
We developed the novel Museum Visit and Interactive Talk (MiVIT) intervention. It is a 2.8-hour museum intervention that utilizes mindful awareness and sensory stimulation to provide participants with experiential learning and social interactions. This museum intervention consists of two different experiences. It aims to promote positive feelings and sense of belonging, reduce loneliness in older adults, resulting in improved physical and mental health status. In the current study, we will recruit 40 participants and enroll them in either a control or an experimental group, with 20 participants in each group. The experimental group will receive the museum intervention in a pre-determined order to avoid bias, while the control group will receive the intervention in a reverse order. A third group (n=5) will not receive any type of intervention. All participants will be assessed on the primary and secondary outcomes at T0, T3 and T6. Assessments for T3 follow-up will be performed within 2 weeks after the first intervention for the experimental group and within one month after the intervention for the control group. Assessments for T6 will be performed 4 weeks after the intervention for both groups. A total of 216 assessments will be conducted between T0, T3 and T6 (see Figure 1).

Official Title
-----------------
Mindfulness and Sensory-Stimulation in Museum Settings for Improving Mental, Physical, and Cognitive Health in Older Adults

Conditions
-----------------
Atrial Fibrillation

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study is being done to find out if REGN2810 (cemiplimab) in combination with platinum-doublet chemotherapy (carboplatin and gemcitabine) can help patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) live longer. REGN2810 (cemiplimab) is a drug that has been shown as single agent (given alone) to work in patients with advanced NSCLC who have been previously treated with chemotherapy. An improvement in their disease was seen which could prolong their survival without their disease getting worse. However, if used in combination with chemotherapy, it may help advanced NSCLC patients even more. This study will evaluate the efficacy and safety of REGN2810 (cemiplimab) in combination with platinum-doublet chemotherapy (carboplatin and gemcitabine) in patients with previously-untreated advanced NSCLC.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This phase II, multicenter, open-label study will evaluate the efficacy and safety of REGN2810 (cemiplimab) in combination with platinum-doublet chemotherapy in subjects with previously-untreated advanced NSCLC. In study Arm A (non-squamous NSCLC), subjects will receive cemiplimab 350 mg intravenously (IV) every 3 weeks plus carboplatin AUC 6 IV every 3 weeks plus gemcitabine 1000 mg/m² IV on Days 1 and 15 every 4 weeks (35/28 day cycle). In study Arm B (squamous NSCLC), subjects will receive cemiplimab 350 mg IV every 3 weeks plus carboplatin area-under-the-curve (AUC) 5 IV every 3 weeks plus paclitaxel 200 mg/m² IV on Days 1 and 8 every 4 weeks (35/28 day cycle). Cycles will continue until disease progression or cemiplimab discontinuation

Abstract:
Background. Lumbar disc herniation (LDH) is a common cause of back pain and leg pain in adults. In many cases, surgery is required to remove the disc herniation and relieve the compression on the nerves. Objective. To evaluate the safety and effectiveness of PerQdisc Nucleus Replacement System in the treatment of lumbar disc herniation with compressive radiculopathy. Methods. This was a prospective, randomized, controlled, non‐inferiority clinical trial. Adult patients with lumbar disc herniation with compressive radiculopathy were randomized into two groups. One group underwent routine discectomy (control group), and the other underwent disc‐height‐preserving nucleus replacement (experimental group). Outcome measures included visual analog pain score (VAS) for leg pain and back pain, Oswestry Disability Index (ODI) score, and patient satisfaction score. The primary outcome measure was the between‐arm difference in improvements in leg pain. Results. A total of 52 patients were included in the study (31 in the control group and 21 in the experimental group). The mean age of the patients was 46.5 ± 6.8 years, and the median duration of symptoms was 10 months. At 6 months post‐surgery, the mean improvement in leg pain was 62.2% in the control group and 78

Study design
=================
The study will use the Simon two-stage design.
In Stage 1, 15 participants will be randomized in the 1:1 ratio to receive one of 2 intervention combinations. The safety of each intervention combination will be assessed in this stage.
In Stage 2, 15 participants will be randomized to one of the intervention combinations that demonstrated no major safety concerns in Stage 1. The efficacy of the selected intervention combination will be assessed in Stage 2.
If a predefined efficacy threshold is reached during Stage 1 and/or Stage 2, the randomization will be ended and an efficacy phase will be initiated wherein 72 participants will be randomized to the efficacy phase intervention combination.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The study will be performed in the Outpatient Heart Failure Clinic at Mie University Hospital. Patients with heart failure will be recruited among those who visit the outpatient clinic. Patients will be randomly assigned to take or not to take the standard drugs (SGLT2 inhibitors, sGC stimulator, and ARNI).

Detailed Description
-----------------
Heart failure is a condition where the heart is unable to pump enough blood to meet the needs of the body. The standard drugs for the treatment of heart failure include beta-blockers, angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), and more recently sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors. ARBs and SGLT2 inhibitors are used in the treatment of patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). SGLT2 inhibitors are believed to reduce the risk of death from cardiovascular causes and hospitalization for heart failure. The standard care for patients with heart failure includes the use of SGLT2 inhibitors. sGC stimulator (PDE5 inhibitor) is a new drug for the treatment of heart failure with preserved EF. ARNIs, which combine the effects of ACE inhibitors and ARBs, have superior efficacy and safety. The use of ARNIs in the standard treatment of heart failure will have a significant impact on the morbidity and mortality of patients with heart failure. However, the mechanisms by which these drugs improve heart failure and other cardiovascular conditions are not well understood. The mechanisms of action of these drugs are also not well understood. It is therefore important to study the mechanisms of action of these drugs in order to improve the treatment of heart failure. This study will be the first of its kind in Japan and will provide important insights into the mechanisms of action of these drugs.

Official Title
-----------------
Impact of SGLT2 Inhibitor, SGC Stimulator, and ARNI on Lithogenic Parameters in Heart Failure Patients

Conditions
-----------------
Heart Failure:Reduced Ejection Fraction, Heart Failure:Preserved Ejection Fra

Can you briefly explain how your research study will change the treatment of patients? 

Study type
=================
Observational study

Abstract
=================

Background
-----------------
The aim of this study is to establish a study cohort to assess whether changes in patient characteristics and/or the use of HF drug therapies, including SGLT-2 inhibitors and/or SGC stimulants influence the outcome of patients with heart failure with reduced (HFrEF) or preserved (HFpEF) ejection fraction.

Methods
-----------------
We will establish an investigator-initiated open cohort of approximately 1100 patients per country (Italy, Germany, France and UK combined). Both HFrEF and HFpEF patients with a known etiology of heart failure, who are stable on HF drug therapy and without any change in their HF drugs in the previous month, will be included in the study. Information at inclusion will be collected retrospectively from the medical history. A set of 54 biochemical and clinical parameters will also be available.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The investigator-initiated observational HARMONY trial is a prospective, cohort study designed to investigate changes in the characteristics, prognosis and outcome of patients with HF and reduced (HFrEF) or preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). Patients are enrolled at 6-monthly intervals. Changes in patient demographic and clinical characteristics and/or the use of HF drug therapies, including SGLT-2 inhibitors and/or SGC stimulators, at 6-monthly intervals will be assessed. The data from this cohort are to be analyzed prospectively at annual intervals.

Official Title

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Research on the effect of intranasal ketamine in patients with epilepsy is scarce. Objective: Assessment of the seizure reduction effect and safety of low-dose intranasal ketamine in adult patients with drug-resistant temporal lobe epilepsy. Methods: The study will be an open-label dose-escalation in patients with uncontrolled TLE on maximum tolerated dose anticonvulsants.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Objective: Assessment of the seizure reduction effect and safety of low-dose intranasal ketamine in adult patients with drug-resistant TLE. Methods: The study will be an open-label dose-escalation in patients with uncontrolled TLE on maximum tolerated dose anticonvulsants. Seizure reduction will be measured as the percentage change in seizure frequency (number of seizures in the last three months of the study) from baseline to the last six months of the study. The proportion of responders (> 50% reduction in seizure frequency) will be assessed at baseline, 6 months after the start of ketamine, 12 months after start of ketamine, 18 months after start of ketamine, and 24 months after start of ketamine.

Official Title
-----------------
A Prospective Dose-Escalation Study of Intranasal Ketamine in Adult Patients With Drug-Resistant Temporal Lobe Epilepsy.

Epilepsy

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Dexmedetomidine has multiple beneficial effects, including reduction in stress, heart rate, and systemic blood pressure, an increase in arterial oxygen saturation, and improvement in cardiac function. To the investigators' knowledge, there are a limited number of investigations of dexmedetomidine efficacy and safety in critically ill patients with acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF). This single-center, prospective, randomized study will evaluate the potential clinical benefits of dexmedetomidine in sedation in critically ill patients with acute decompensated heart failure.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
To understand the effects of SGLT2 inhibitors on kidney disease in patients with heart failure, we will obtain kidney biopsies at the time of HF hospitalization and 3 and 6 months following the initiation of SGLT2 inhibitors. The study will enroll up to 32 consecutive patients who agree to kidney biopsy and initiate SGLT2 inhibitor therapy.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Background Sodium-glucose co-transporters (SGLT), including 2 (SGLT2) and 9 (SGLT9) are expressed in the kidney. Both SGLT2 and SGLT9 inhibition have been shown to reduce filtration fraction by 10-15% which is not associated with any significant change in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) over 16 weeks in the setting of type 2 diabetes. In animal models, SGLT2 inhibitors have been found to reduce tubulointerstitial fibrosis, which may be a common target in the treatment of CKD. Thus, the primary specific aim of the proposed study will test if SGLT2 inhibition has any early effect on tubulointerstitial fibrosis and inflammation, as early markers of kidney disease progression in patients with chronic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). The second specific aim explores the possibility that SGLT2 inhibition may not increase the rate of decline in GFR. The tertiary aims investigate the effects of SGLT2inhibitors on podocyte function and endothelial function, which may be associated with decrements in kidney function. This is the first study to explore how SGLT2 inhibitors may affect kidney structure and kidney function in patients with HF. Subjects ≥18 years old admitted to a tertiary care hospital in a major metropolitan area with HFrEF and an eGFR ≥30 ml/min/1.73 m2(by CKD-EPI equation) will be considered for enrollment. In addition, patients must have a urine collection >300 mL within

The study will be conducted in two phases: an observational phase and an interventional phase. In the observational phase, the changes in biochemical and metabolomic parameters before and after the initiation of the respective heart failure therapy will be evaluated in each study arm. In the interventional phase, patients will receive the respective heart failure therapy based on the established practice guidelines. The primary objective of the study is to investigate the metabolic response to the initiation of heart failure therapy and its impact on biochemical and metabolomic parameters.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The use of oral phosphodiesterase inhibitors ( PDE5) is a valid therapeutic option for the treatment of erectile dysfunction (ED) in patients with Peyronie's disease (PD). However, the duration of treatment remains controversial. Based on our preliminary clinical experience, we proposed an innovative treatment strategy in patients with PD - two different dosages of vardenafil: a high dose (20 mg-40 mg), in order to maximise the effect on the quality of erections and in the first six months of treatment and a lower dose (5 mg twice a week), in order to maintain the effect even after 12-18 months. The aim of the study is to evaluate the efficacy of two different dosages of vardenafil (60 mg and 20 mg) compared to sildenafil citrate (100 mg) in improving erectile function and penile angulation in patients with surgically and non-surgically treated PD.

Detailed Description
-----------------
To investigate the efficacy and tolerability of two different dosages of vardenafil (20 mg in the first six months and 5 mg in the following 6 months) compared to sildenafil citrate in improving erectile function and penile angulation in patients with surgically and non-surgically treated Peyronie's disease.

Official Title
-----------------
Efficacy of 24 mg Once Daily Daily Tadalafil and 60 mg Sildenafil Citrate in Patients With Erectile Dysfunction and Peyronie's Disease: a prospective Comparative Study

Conditions
-----------------
Erectile Dysfunction, Penile Deformities, Peyronie's Disease

Background: In patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), disutis mali/CRLB‐101, a CXCR4 antagonist has an important role in a post‐transplant (TP, allogeneic bone marrow or stem cells) setting. A double‐blinded phase 3 randomized placebo‐controlled trial was conducted to evaluate the safety and efficacy of disutis mali in CML patients during the first year of TP. Patients and Methods: Between 2007 and 2009, 142 CML patients (141 in the disutis mali arm and 1 in the control arm; 98 in CP, 39 in AP and 5 in BP) were analysed. In patients with a matched sibling donor, high‐dose methotrexate and cyclophosphamide were administered 24 hours before TP, and in patients without an HLA‐identical sibling, cytarabine and fludarabine were co‐given with TP. Cyclosporine and methotrexate were administered within 100 days after TP in both groups. The patients were randomized to receive disutis mali 300 mg every day from the day before TP for a total of 104 inpatient days or placebo until day 90. Study type

Observational

Condition
=================
Increase in serum creatinine after the intake of a high-fat meal in healthy volunteers

Intervention
=================
The aim of this study is to demonstrate the increase in serum creatinine by comparing the values before and 1 hour after the intake of a low- and high-fat meal in healthy volunteers. The intervention is the consumption of a low- and high-fat meal. The low-fat meal consists of bread, cheese, and sausage (348 kcal, 13.5g fat, 11.6 g protein, 36.3 g carbohydrates), while the high-fat meal consists of fat-rich sausage (393 kcal, 33.6 g fat, 14.2 g protein, 21.2 g carbohydrates). The meal will be prepared by the study center.

Brief summary
=================
In normal physiological conditions, a high-fat meal causes a temporary increase in serum creatinine levels. This change is not associated with changes in renal function. However, an acute increase in serum creatinine can cause diagnostic uncertainty when evaluating acute renal failure. The aim of this study is to investigate the change in serum creatinine levels in healthy volunteers after a high-fat meal and to determine how this change affects the diagnosis of acute kidney injury. The results of this study will contribute to the accurate diagnosis of acute kidney injury in patients and the appropriate interpretation of serum creatinine levels in clinical practice.

Acute kidney injury

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
We are recruiting healthy adults, 25 years of age and older. Participants will consume a beverage that contains 2H5-Phenylalanine, a stable isotope that is not harmful and is naturally occurring in our environment. A small number of participants will receive a dose of the stable isotope labeled amino acid, in addition to regular food. Blood samples will be collected over 12 weeks.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This study will investigate the albumin catabolic rate (ACR) in healthy adults, 25 years of age and older. ACR is a measure of how quickly albumin is broken down by the body. Albumin is the most abundant blood protein in humans, and its levels can drop due to various conditions such as severe burns, injuries or illnesses. It's important for the body to maintain adequate albumin levels as it plays a vital role in maintaining blood pressure and fluid balance. Lower ACR can be an indication of systemic inflammation. In this study, we will assess ACR by administering a beverage containing 2H5-Phenylalanine, a stable isotope that is not harmful and is naturally occurring in our environment. A small number of participants will also receive a regular foodstuff containing the stable isotope labeled amino acid in addition to regular food. Blood samples will be collected over 12 weeks to determine albumin concentrations, ACR and blood urea nitrogen (BUN), an indicator of kidney function. Ultimately, the results of this study may help us understand more about diseases or metabolic disorders that might be associated with low ACR.

Official Title
-----------------
Stable Isotope-Labeled Phenylalanine Provides a Novel Method to Quantify Albumin Catabolic Rate and Assess Liver Function in Healthy Adults

Human, Kidney, Dysfunction, Liver Cirrhosis, Liver Disease, Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome, Hepatitis, Kidney Disease

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Drug: Stable isotope labeled phenylalanine

The use of local anesthetics such as ropivacaine and bupivacaine has been a standard technique for blockade of sympathetic efferent fibers and pain sensation 
[1,2,3,4,5,6]. However, the optimal ratio of local anesthetics is not yet determined. Although it is assumed that the optimal mixture of ropivacaine and bupivacaine has some anesthetic synergic effects, no studies have evaluated the effects of the different ratios of ropivacaine and bupivacaine on postoperative pain 
[7,8]. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effect of bupivacaine and ropivacaine mixture at different concentration on postoperative pain.
2. Methods
A total of 90 patients, American Society of Anesthesiologists I to III, aged over 20 years undergoing surgery under spinal anesthesia were recruited into this study. All surgeries were scheduled as elective surgery and were performed in the operating room over 14 months. Patients with a history of peripheral nerve disease or drug allergies were ineligible for this study. Abstract:
To compare the effects of n‐3 and n‐6 lipids on the progression of left ventricular (LV) noncompaction (LVNC) in adult human subjects with noncompact phenotype and mild systolic dysfunction. A total of 12 young patients with mild LVNC (LVEF ≥35) were enrolled in a prospective, double‐blind, randomized, cross‐over study, comparing the effect of n‐3 fatty acids vs. n‐6 fatty acids. Serial cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) scans were performed before, during and after treatment period. Fourteen subjects completed the study. After 1 month of treatment, the group LVNC was significantly improved (% LV endocardial wall thickness: 7.38 +/‐ 2.21 vs. 7.33 +/‐ 1.97, 7.23 +/‐ 2.28 vs. 7.29 +/‐ 1.78; p = 0.006, p = 0.009). There was no significant difference between the n‐3 fatty acid and n‐6 fatty acid treatment groups in terms of CMR parameters. Treatment with n‐3 fatty acid vs. n‐6 fatty acid for 1 month revealed improved LV noncompaction (LVNC score; p = 0.007). No adverse effects were observed in either group. Treatment with n‐3 fatty acids is efficacious for improving cardiac function in mild LVNC without affecting heart rate and ejection fraction. However, its efficacy is reduced if it is continued for a long time.

Abstract:
In 1993, the American Association of Health Plans reported results of a survey of 1,839 respondents with congestive heart failure. The question was asked in what setting patients first presented with congestive heart failure. Forty‐nine percent reported that their initial medical contact was in an emergency department (ED), and 52% reported that it was in an internist's or family physician's office. The study also showed that patients who saw a cardiologist first had a shorter delay between symptom onset and first medical contact than those with no delay. The patients receiving specialty care received a diagnosis of congestive heart failure more rapidly than those who were not treated by a cardiologist. These findings suggest that the sooner a cardiologist is consulted, the earlier the diagnosis and the more likely the use of appropriate treatment measures. The benefits of early diagnosis cannot be exaggerated because 2‐year survival rates for those diagnosed with mild‐to‐moderate heart failure average greater than 80%, whereas patients diagnosed with heart failure while presenting in advanced congestive heart failure have survival rates that are less than 50%.

Abstract:
Background: Lateral epicondylitis is characterized by pain in or around the lateral epicondyle. The cause of this condition is not well‐understood, and the treatment depends on the severity of the condition. Conservative treatment modalities include rest, antiinflammatory drugs, corticosteroid injection, physiotherapy, and surgical intervention. This prospective, randomized, controlled study aimed to evaluate functional outcomes in patients with chronic lateral epicondylitis treated with ultrasound therapy guided by electromyography‐triggered electrical stimulation and compare these results with those treated with ultrasound therapy and electrotherapy alone, or with extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT). Methods: A total of 48 patients suffering from chronic lateral epicondylitis were randomized into three groups in a prospective controlled trial. Group 1 was treated with ultrasound therapy guided by EMG‐triggered electrical stimulation; group 2 received ultrasound therapy and electrotherapy only and group 3 received ESWT. Clinical Evaluation: The patients were evaluated pretreatment and at 2 and 4 weeks after the first treatment. The assessment consisted of both subjective and objective evaluations, including Patient Specific Functional Scale (PSFS) and Patient Rated Tennis Elbow Evaluation (PRTEE) were used as objective measures. Results: No significant difference was observed between groups 1 and 2 (p‐value = 0.50, 0.17, respectively). This lack of difference was maintained at 4 weeks of follow‐up. The present phase III study evaluated aflibercept at a lower 2‐mg dosage as well as two different dosage schedules of 2 mg over 52 weeks. Methods: In this multicenter, phase III, doublemasked, active‐controlled study, 501 patients were randomized 1:1:1 to treatment with monthly aflibercept 8 mg (n = 167), bi‐monthly aflibercept 8 mg (n = 165) or monthly aflibercept 2 mg intraocular injections. The end‐point measurewas the mean change from baseline visual acuity at study week 48. Results: The treatment groups were well balanced for demographic characteristics and baseline characteristics. At week 48 (primary study timepoint), all treatment groups showed marked improvements in best corrected visual acuity compared with baseline. The least squares mean change from baseline in best corrected visual acuity at 48 weeks was 13.9 letters for the monthly 2‐mg dose group, 15.8 letters for the monthly 8‐mg dose group, and 16.6 letters for the bi‐monthly 8‐mg dose group (all P < 0.001). The 8‐mg dose groups (both monthly and bi‐monthly) maintained significant improvements in visual acuity compared with baseline through week 52. Adverse events included conjunctival hemorrhage, eye pain, retinal vein occlusion, and eye infection. Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of 3 months of aerobic exercise training during hospitalization on the immune function, clinical outcomes, and post‐hospitalization physical fitness of hospitalized children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) using the Wii Fit balance board. Materials and Methods: The study included 20 hospitalized boys aged 5‐17 years diagnosed with ALL who were randomly assigned to a control (n = 10) or exercise intervention (n = 10) group. Results: The groups, in terms of patients' demographic and clinical characteristics, were similar. No clinically significant differences were observed between the groups regarding their serum concentrations of C‐reactive protein (CRP), IgG, IgA, and IgM. Although there was no difference between the groups in terms of hemoglobin and hematocrit values, the leukocyte and platelet counts as well as neutrophil values were significantly higher in the control group compared to the intervention group. In addition, although there were no significant differences between the groups in terms of Karnofsky Performance Status scores, body composition measurements and physical fitness tests before the intervention, at the end of the intervention, the patients in the exercise intervention group had higher physical fitness results (p=0.035), and they were found to have lost body weight, fat mass, total body water and had decreased body mass index. Conclusions: During hospitalization, physical fitness training with the Wii Fit was well tolerated by hospitalized children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia and was associated with improved physical fitness and reduced body weight and fat mass. In the future, prospective studies should investigate the efficacy of long‐term inpatient physical fitness training on immune system function and clinical outcomes in hospitalized children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
To assess the safety of prophylactic antibiotics in patients at high risk of surgical site infection after elective colorectal cancer surgery in a randomised controlled non-inferiority trial.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Following recruitment of 4000 patients in the CRYO study and randomisation of 3500, the rate of surgical site infection will need to be assessed against historic control rates. These are available for both NHS and non-private providers, and are both close to 5% with no obvious differences between them. Given the lack of any substantial benefits (and increased costs) seen in the CRYO study, a simple difference of 1% between the study arms seems unlikely. However, if this were to occur then it would represent an improvement of 40% of control rates. Thus, a sample size of 4000 patients (2000 per arm) will be required to detect this with a power of 80% and 2-sided alpha of 0.05. Assuming 10% attrition (e.g. censoring due to withdrawal of consent, lack of access to medical records, death of patient prior to discharge), and a total recruitment time of 18 months, this amounts to a recruitment rate of 60patients/month. In each of 20 NHS and 20 private hospitals, the rate of consented patients should be at least one per week, if resources and infrastructure permits.

Acquired hypothyroidism is a frequent complication after thyroidectomy. When present, the condition can be treated medically, since its most common cause is autoimmune thyroiditis secondary to resection-induced thyroid tissue damage. It is considered fully reversible in most cases. After this form of thyroiditis has healed, a permanent need for levothyroxine is very rare. The study hypothesis is that an increased rate of post-surgical hypothyroidism is related to the removal or destruction of the thyroid during completion thyroidectomy rather than to the autoimmune process linked to the development of thyroiditis. This phenomenon could be explained by the fact that some normal thyroid tissue remains after thyroid lobectomy, or by the difference between the anatomical and the functional thyroid remnants left after completion thyroidectomy. Study Overview
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
We are conducting a study to investigate the impact of commercial native starch and processed starch on postprandial glycemic control in healthy adults compared with glucose. The current literature on starch processing and postprandial glucose management is weak, and our study aims to address this gap through a controlled trial in healthy adults. Our research objective is to determine whether processing native starch through extrusion, as done in the commercial marketplace, has a clinically meaningful impact on glycemic control measured postprandially in healthy individuals. Furthermore, we aim to evaluate whether commercial processing can attenuate postprandial glycemic spikes, and whether starch processing affects the gut microbiome and acute fecal short chain fatty acid (SCFA) production.

Detailed Description
-----------------
We will conduct a parallel crossover randomized clinical trial of healthy adults investigating the glycemic responses to two starch formulations as a function of extrusion-based processing. This will be a proof-of-concept study in which glucose, insulin, and SCFA concentrations will be measured as surrogate markers for starch digestion, absorption and gut microbiome activity in a fasted and postprandial state. Participants will consume a standardized meal mixed with 1.5 g/kg body mass of corn starch in one of two forms: commercial and raw. On two separate occasions, 12 to 18 hours apart, each participant will receive both starch formulations in random order. Fasting and postprandial blood samples will be collected over 3 hours, and fecal samples will be collected over 96 hours, including 48 hours after the last meal.

Official Title
-----------------
Impact of Commercial Native vs. Raw Starch on Postprandial Glycemic Control, Gut Microbiome, and SCFAs in Healthy Adults

Conditions
-----------------
Non-Communicable Disease, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Other: Native Starch
* Other: Modified Starch

Abstract:
Objective: This study assessed the efficacy and safety of the treatment strategies, 2 versus 4 sessions of low‐dose versus ultra‐low‐dose intravitreal therapy with triamcinolone acetonide, in treating diabetic macular edema (DME). Methods: The study was a prospective, randomized, comparative case series. Thirty patients with macular edema associated with diabetic retinopathy were randomly assigned to receive a single 0.4 mg intravitreal injection of triamcinolone acetonide or 3 injections 1 month apart or 6 at a time interval of 1 month. Clinical examinations were performed at 1‐, 2‐, and 3‐month follow‐ups. The primary outcome measures were change in central macular thickness (CMT) after 60 days and adverse effects. Results: The mean time from baseline to the last follow‐up visit was 122 ± 25 days. All patients completed the study. Mean CMT in the 1‐month interval group was 165 ± 24 μm (P = .05), in the 3‐month interval group was 166.67 ± 25.67 μm (P = .001), and in the 6‐month interval group was 153.4 ± 29. μm (P = .002). There were significant differences among these groups. Visual acuity after 120 days showed a trend toward improvement in all groups: 1‐month interval group, + 0.52 ± 2.6; 3‐month interval group, + 3.89 ± 2.98; and the 6‐month interval group, + 4.83 ± 3. Adverse reactions included intraocular pressure increase, glaucoma, and cataract. Conclusions: Results show that intravitreal triamcinolone acetonide therapy is more beneficial when the injection interval is gradually increased in patients with DME. Copyright © 2017, AOA Publishing, Inc.

BACKGROUND: Although the addition of radiation therapy after neoadjuvant systemic therapy (NSCT) leads to more favorable survival outcomes in women with breast cancer, it can increase the risk of local toxicity. PURPOSE: The aim of this analysis was to assess the role of the addition of postoperative radiotherapy in breast cancer patients treated with neoadjuvant systemic therapy (NST).METHODS AND MATERIALS: This randomized phase III study enrolled patients with breast cancer who were eligible for surgical treatment. There were 424 patients in the radiation therapy group and 412 in the no‐radiation group in each cohort. A propensity score methodology was used to control treatment‐related effects; patients were matched by risk‐of‐relapse score and estrogen receptor status.RESULTS: The survival curve analysis of the entire study population showed no difference between the experimental and control groups at the 15‐year follow‐up (7% vs 10%, respectively; hazard ratio [HR], 1.22; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.73‐2.03; P = .43). In a stratified analysis by low‐ and high‐risk grouping with the 15‐year disease‐free survival rate as the primary outcome variable, we found that the radiation therapy group had a better survival outcome than the control group (disease‐free survival rate of 32.7% vs 23%, respectively [HR, 1.43; 95% CI, 1.05‐1.97; P = .03) and better overall survival rate than the control group (hazard ratio, 1.41; 95% CI, 1.07‐1.87; P = .02). However, the addition of postoperative radiotherapy was associated with more acute and late adverse events.CONCLUSIONS: After neoadjuvant systemic therapy, postoperative radiation therapy may be considered an option for high‐risk patients. In the low‐risk group, no obvious benefit was observed by the administration of radiation therapy.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Antibiotic treatment is often recommended in patients who undergo oral surgery. However, it is unclear whether antibiotics improve outcomes, and the practice may contribute to the increased risk of antibiotic resistance. In a randomized control trial, we evaluated if oral surgeon residents would benefit from using prophylactic antibiotics during third molar surgery.METHODS: We included 58 patients with mandibular third molars for removal by dental residents in a randomized double‐blind two‐arm trial. We compared the amount of pain, swelling and function of mandible with antibiotics administered postoperatively. The primary outcome of the study was pain experienced at 3‐15 months postoperatively. The intervention group was administered 500 mg amoxicillin and 500 mg clarithromycin once postoperatively.RESULTS: There was no difference in pain or other parameters between the groups during the first 4 weeks postoperatively. Our results show that pain experienced postoperatively has a mean score of less than 1 on a numeric scale of 0 to 10, and pain is not statistically significant from baseline at any time point.CONCLUSION: We did not find any beneficial effect of antibiotic prophylaxis after third molar surgery on either pain, swelling or function. The effect of antibiotics on pain was minimal and short‐lived and did not benefit surgical patients.PRACTITIONER'S POINT: We conclude that there is no indication for antibiotic prophylaxis after third molar surgery.

Additionally, patients with severe thrombotic events, uncontrolled or severe cardiovascular disease, and recent major surgeries are not eligible for the trial. Patients with certain mental or physical illnesses that may interfere with participation are also excluded. These are some of the main exclusion criteria. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of the study is to compare the effects of 40.0 Hz pulsed radiofrequency (PRF) with PRF plus ultrasound on scar appearance and sensory function in the treatment of hypertrophic scars from previous burns.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a prospective, randomized, split-thigh study. Six patients with bilaterally symmetrical hypertrophic scars will be enrolled and will receive 40.0 Hz pulsed radiofrequency at 3 weeks, 2 weeks, and 1 week prior to wound excision; after wound excision, one thigh of the participant will receive PRF, and the other will receive PRF combined with ultrasound. All participants will be followed up for at least 3 days following the final treatment, and scar and sensory assessments will be conducted at 2, 4, 8, and 16 weeks after surgery on the treated skin and compared with skin of the contralateral thigh that was not treated.

[/CONSORT] [/INTRODUCTION] Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) account for approximately 31% of all deaths globally. Atrial fibrillation (AF) is associated with an increased risk of heart failure (HF), stroke, dementia, and mortality. In patients with HF, AF is independently associated with an increased cardiovascular mortality and morbidity rate. Atrial arrhythmia burden is a significant prognostic factor for CVDs and death in HF. Hypothermia, particularly core temperature <36°C, is a risk factor for adverse outcomes in patients with HF. AF was recently shown to be associated with 6.7% increased odds of hypothermia in HF patients. The prognostic and pathophysiological roles of hypothermia and AF in patients with HF have not been fully elucidated. AF-related factors, including neurohormonal activation and inflammation, may be a cause of hypothermia in HF; however, the potential role of hypothermia in AF triggering in patients with HF remains unclear. It is unknown whether hypothermia alters the severity of AF and its associated factors, including neurohormonal activation and inflammation, in patients with HF. Thus, the present study aimed to investigate the effect of percutaneous core temperature <36°C on the severity of AF and its associated factors in patients with HF. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study will provide investigators and patients information about the safety and tolerability of inosine. We will look for the effect of inosine vs. placebo on blood flow to the lungs, breathing, oxygen level and carbon dioxide level in the blood, and other factors related to breathing.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a single-center, randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled crossover study. For the first 2 visits, participants are randomized to receive 500mg of Inosine or placebo orally twice a day (morning and evening) for 2 weeks or until adverse events are observed. After the 3rd visit, the order of treatment is switched for the next two treatment periods. Before the study drug intake at the first visit, and after the study drug intake at each visit, each subject is asked to perform a 6-minute walk test as exercise tolerance assessment. Before and after 6-minute walk test, pulmonary parameters (P/F) and heart rate variability (HRV) will be monitored. Before and after the inosine or placebo intake on days 1 and day 14, spirometry, blood gas, BNP, HR, HRV, and ECG will be monitored.

A Double-Blinded Randomized Cross-Over Study to Evaluate the Safety, Tolerability and Clinical Effects of Inosine Administration in Patients With Pulmonary Hypertension
