Scientific title
=================
Demographic Factors Affecting Radial Artery Diameter in Patients Undergoing Radial Artery Access for Right Heart Catheterization

Plain English Summary
=================
Background and study aimsThe radial artery is commonly used for catheterization procedures in interventional radiology, as it offers less risk of bleeding and other complications compared to other sites. However, determining the optimal radial artery diameter is crucial for successful procedural outcomes. This study aims to examine the impact of demographic factors, including age, sex, body mass index (BMI), pregnancy status, and prior history of vasculitis, on radial artery diameter in patients undergoing right heart catheterization.Who can participate?Patients who underwent right heart catheterization at our institution between January 2017 and January 2019 will be recruited.What does the study involve?Participants eligible for inclusion will be identified through chart review. Their demographic data, including age, sex, BMI, pregnancy status, and history of vasculitis, will be recorded. The diameter of the radial artery will be measured using digital calipers prior to right heart catheterization. What are the possible benefits and risks of participating?There are no direct benefits or risks associated with participating in this study. However, the results of the study may contribute to improving patient care and understanding of radial artery diameter in interventional radiology procedures.Where is the study run from?The study will be conducted at the University of Utah Health.When is the study starting and how long is it expected to run for?January 2023 to June 2023.Who

Study Overview
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of the study was to test the hypothesis that use of a nasal decongestant spray with a known vasoconstrictor (oxymetazoline) reduces the spread of the SARS-CoV-2 virus as measured by viral load at multiple sites on a sample of subjects and nasal swabs of household contacts.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Oversight for this study has been provided by an Institutional Review Board (IRB) in accordance with Good Clinical Practice guidelines. Research subjects will be recruited by the sponsoring site and the University of Wisconsin Department of Family Medicine. The trial is designed as a randomized, prospective, placebo-controlled study of a nasal spray as one treatment option for individuals living in a household with an individual known to be actively ill with COVID-19. For the purposes of this study, COVID-19 positivity is defined by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) results. Subjects may be in a household with as few as one other individual. The control and study arms of the study are randomized with 1:1 allocation using a central web-based Randomization Service with computer-generated random blocks. Upon enrollment, subjects will be randomized to one of two arms: control vs oxymetazoline. Subjects randomized to the control arm will receive a placebo nasal spray. Subjects who experience a decrease of two or more RT-PCR levels OR are no longer positive on two consecutive testing dates at 3, 5, 7, 9 and 14 days after exposure, as compared to 2,7,11,14,17,20 and 24 days for the study intervention arm, will be eligible to enroll household or family members into the study and treated with oxymetazoline nasal spray. Data from subjects treated with oxymetazoline will be collected during an initial screening visit, and at one, three, six, seven or eight visits over 24 days. This study is performed in accordance with the ethical principles that have their origin in the Declaration of Helsinki and its subsequent amendments. All study

We are planning to conduct a three-arm study, examining fractional flow reserve (FFR), ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR), and intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) in one study arm each. The first-pass results, including lesion size and angiographic severity, will be determined based on coronary angiography results. The diameter stenosis calculated using IVUS and the IVUS-derived fractional area stenosis will be compared to the FFR results. The UFR results will be compared to both the FFR results and the severity of coronary artery stenosis determined through visual examination.

The second arm will focus on angiography as the participant group. The intervention/treatment for this arm should be the diagnostic test: ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR). By using angiography as a comparison, we can evaluate the accuracy of the new diagnostic test, fractional flow reserve (FFR). 

During the screening period, we will conduct a comprehensive search for studies in the PubMed database using keywords related to FFR and UFR. We will also perform a preliminary screening of the retrieved references to determine their eligibility for inclusion in our systematic review. We aim to ensure that all studies are relevant and provide meaningful information for our analysis. 

After selecting the selected studies, we will extract the relevant data for analysis. This will involve collecting data on the study's characteristics (e.g., study design, sample size, participant demographics, etc.), as well as the key outcomes of interest (e.g., sensitivity, specificity, accuracy, etc.) for FFR and UFR. We will also summarize the qualitative and quantitative findings of the included studies to provide a comprehensive understanding of the current evidence on FFR and UFR in the assessment of coronary artery stenosis. 

During the writing and reporting phase, we will synthesize the collected data and present our findings in a clear and concise manner. This will involve preparing tables and figures to illustrate the study characteristics and key outcomes, as well as summarizing the qualitative findings from the review of the literature. We will also discuss the strengths and limitations of the included studies and provide recommendations for future research in this area. 

Throughout the review process, we will engage in peer review and constructive discussion to ensure the scientific rigor and accuracy of our analyses. We will also work closely with the editorial advisory board, consisting of experts in the field of coronary artery stenosis assessment, to ensure that our review meets the highest standards of evidence-based medicine. 

By integrating all of these steps, we plan to conduct a high-quality systematic review of the accuracy of FFR and UFR in the assessment of coronary artery stenosis. The findings of our review will provide valuable insights for healthcare professionals, policymakers, and researchers working in this field.

The age requirement should be set at 18 years or older, and written informed consent is essential. Additionally, participants should have intermediate coronary lesions with diameter stenosis ranging from 30% to 80% as estimated by visual examination from coronary angiography.

Participants should be excluded if they are ineligible for diagnostic IVUS or FFR examination, have undergone prior coronary artery bypass grafting of the interrogated vessels, experienced myocardial infarction within 72 hours of coronary angiography, or have severe heart failure. Serum creatinine levels greater than 150 umol/L or glomerular filtration rates below 45 ml/kg/1.73 m2 should also be considered exclusions. Furthermore, individuals with allergies to the contrast agent or adenosine, life expectancy of less than 2 years, IVUS pullback that does not cover the entire lesion, or severe myocardial bridge in the interrogated vessel should be excluded from the study.

Based on the information you provided, I suggest having two study arms. The first arm will focus on pressure wire-based fractional flow reserve (FFR) as the participant group. The intervention/treatment for this arm should be the diagnostic test: fractional flow reserve (FFR). This arm is necessary as FFR is a well-established standard reference for assessing the functional significance of coronary artery stenosis. By using pressure wire-based FFR as a comparison, we can evaluate the accuracy of the new diagnostic test, ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR).

The second study arm should involve participants who will undergo intravascular ultrasound (IVUS)-based ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR). The intervention/treatment for this arm should be the diagnostic tests: ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) and intravascular ultrasound (IVUS). This arm is important as it focuses on the new diagnostic test, UFR, which is the main intervention being evaluated in this trial. By combining UFR with IVUS, we aim to assess the functional significance of coronary artery stenosis in a more comprehensive manner. Abstract:
Background: CAR‐T cell therapy has emerged as a promising treatment for multiple myeloma (MM). Despite initial success, many patients relapse after CAR‐T cell treatment. Studies have shown that relapse in MM frequently occurs due to heterogeneity and genomic changes. Therefore, individualized treatment strategies are needed to address the challenges of relapsed MM. Recently, ICI201, a GPRC5D‐targeting CAR‐T cell therapy, has achieved significant anti‐tumor activity in some patients with relapsed MM. However, many patients relapse after ICI201 treatment. We propose a randomized, controlled study to investigate the efficacy of two treatment strategies for relapsed MM after ICI201 treatment: a proteasome inhibitor plus bortezomib vs. lenalidomide. Methods: This is a prospective, single‐center study designed to investigate the efficacy of two treatment strategies for relapsed MM after ICI201 treatment: a proteasome inhibitor plus bortezomib (arm A) vs. lenalidomide (arm B). Inclusion criteria: 18‐75 years old; relapsed MM after ICI201 treatment; ECOG score 0‐2; adequate organ function; informed consent. The primary endpoint of this study is the overall response rate (ORR) between two treatment strategies. The secondary endpoints are progression‐free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), safety and adverse events. Discussion: This study investigates the efficacy of two treatment strategies for relapsed MM after ICI201 treatment, which has important clinical implications for individualized treatment of MM. Introduction:

Multiple myeloma (MM) is a hematological malignancy characterized by the clonal proliferation of plasma cells in the bone marrow, resulting in excess immunoglobulin production and organ damage. Despite advancements in treatment, relapsed/refractory (R/R) MM remains a clinically challenging disease, necessitating the development of novel therapeutic options.

One promising approach is chimeric antigen receptor (CAR)-T cell therapy, which has demonstrated remarkable efficacy in other hematologic malignancies. CAR-T cells are genetically engineered T cells redirected to target specific antigens expressed by cancer cells. In the case of MM, GPRC5D, a highly expressed surface antigen, has emerged as an attractive target for CAR-T cell therapy. Preclinical studies of GPRC5D-targeted CAR-T cells have demonstrated potent antitumor activity against MM cell lines and patient-derived xenografts.

Abstract:
Aims: Erectile dysfunction (ED) is the most frequent male genital sexual dysfunction, with approximately 52% of men over 40 years old. Current ED treatments include oral drugs, penile injection, vacuum pump, implantable rod, and surgical techniques. There are no studies evaluating the use of an innovative vacuum assistance device (P‐shot pump) in the treatment of ED. Methods: This is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to analyze in primary care the effects of the P‐shot pump on the intensity of sexual desire, in men with ED at the time of prostate resection (P0) and during the healing process (P30). For recruitment, patients with symptomatic BPH submitted to surgical treatment (transurethral adenomectomy) by the surgeon were randomly distributed into two groups: Group 1 (G1) received the P‐shot pump intervention (n=10) and group 2 (G2) did not receive any intervention (control group) (n=10). All participants answered the Sexual Desire Scale developed by Bancroft before surgery (P0), and 30 days after surgery (P30). Participants answered questions on the presence or absence of difficulty in sexual activity and the degree of difficulty. These questions were used to compare the intensity of sexual desire between participating groups and to identify the influence of surgery in the course of sexual desire. The results obtained during the study were compared using descriptive and bivariate analytical methods. The level of significance adopted was 5%. Results: The result of the chi‐squared test showed a significant difference between the groups (p=0.021), both when the total sexual desire score was measured and for each question (p=0.003, p=0.012, and p=0.041). Conclusions: Patients with a history or previous risk factors for sexual desire decreased after prostate resection. The use of the P‐shot pump contributed to sexual rehabilitation and helped maintain the intensity of sexual desire in these patients.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is a type of lung cancer that originates from epithelial cells. The current standard of care for the treatment of completely resected pIB-IIIA NSCLC with common EGFR mutations (Del19 or L858R) is adjuvant chemotherapy followed by osimertinib. Osimertinib is approved as a second-line treatment for patients with metastatic NSCLC that has progressed after platinum-based chemotherapy. However, some patients experience resistance to osimertinib treatment, leading to disease progression. The development of resistance mechanisms to osimertinib is known to occur in up to 60% of patients who have been treated with osimertinib for a long duration. The proposed research is aimed at identifying molecular prognostic factors and resistance mechanisms to osimertinib adjuvant treatment in completely resected pIB-IIIA NSCLC with common EGFR mutations. The study seeks to determine specific genetic mutations that may affect patient survival, disease recurrence, and the ability of osimertinib to control the disease. By collecting samples of tumor and plasma at different time points, we will study the genetic profile of the tumor and the development of resistance mechanisms to osimertinib. These findings could help researchers in the development of new treatment strategies to prevent disease recurrence and improve patient outcomes. Therefore, the study will be of great significance in exploring the development of targeted therapies for lung cancer and will further enhance our knowledge of the biological behavior of EGFR-mutated lung cancer.

Abstract

Background
-----------------

Abstract:
Background: Persistent ductus arteriosus (PDA) affects 10 to 20% of premature newborns. The administration of betamethasone (BTM) for the treatment of bronchopulmonary dysplasia, an approach commonly used in neonatology, is associated with an increased risk of PDA. Methodology: The objective of this monocenter cohort study is to examine the impact of repeated administration of systemic BTM on the closure of DA in premature infants with PDA and bronchopulmonary dysplasia by measuring the evolution of DA diameter according to administration routes of BTM. Results: From January 2018 to December 2022, 247 subjects were included in our study group. A comparison of baseline characteristics between the BTM and non‐BTM groups showed significant differences in gestational age (31.8 ± 0.8 versus 29.8 ± 0.8, P = .03) and duration of surfactant therapy (13.4 ± 0.3 versus 7.4 ± 0.2, P < .0001). A comparison of the distribution of baseline characteristics between subjects in whom the DA closed and those in whom the DA persisted showed significant differences in gestational age (31.9 ± 0.5 versus 29.3 ± 0.6, P < .001) and surfactant treatment (13.0 ± 1.1 versus 8.0 ± 0.9, P < .001). The probability of the DA closing was higher in the BTM group (90% versus 61.7%, P = .02). Conclusion: Betamethasone, which is commonly used in neonatology, increases the chances of PDA closure in premature infants. Further investigation is needed to assess whether the repeated use of BTM reduces the risk of bronchopulmonary dysplasia in these infants.

Abstract:
Objective : To assess the effect of percutaneous closure using collagen plug for closing the patent ductus arteriosus on aortopulmonary collateral flow in neonates with pulmonary hypertension. Methods : A prospective clinical investigation conducted on randomly selected term and preterm infants with persistent patent ductus arteriosus admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit of Mansoura University Children's Hospital was included. They were undergone balloon‐occlusion to occlude the ductus arteriosus (DA) using collagen plug. Aortic coarctation and branch pulmonary artery stenosis were found by transthoracic echocardiography using two‐dimensional, color Doppler ultrasonography and three different views. The presence of aortopulmonary collateral flow was assessed using two‐dimensional, color Doppler ultrasound. Results : The study included 30 cases. The mean age at admission was 5 days. The mean gestational age at delivery in the cases assigned the duct treatment was 26.5 ± 1.48 weeks, and in the cases assigned the coarctation treatment was 35.26 ± 1.07 weeks (P < 0.05). There was a difference between the two groups as to the mode of delivery, which was 58.3% caesarean section in the DA group, while none of the patients in the coarctation group was delivered by caesarean section (P < 0.05). No aortopulmonary collateral flow was detected in the patient treated for patent ductus using collagen plug to occlude the patent ductus. Conclusion : No aortopulmonary collateral flow was detected using the percutaneous collagen plug to occlude the patent ductus arteriosus in the term and preterm neonates.

Abstract:
Introduction: Ankle sprains are the most common injury in sports. The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of functional ankle braces (FAB) on the stability of the posterolateral ligament (PLL) and proprioception and the balance of ankle joint in patients with recurrent ankle sprains. Methods: Forty patients with recurrent ankle sprains were included in the study. The patients consisted of the 20 patients in the functional group and the 20 patients in the no brace group, randomly chosen. The patients were evaluated through range of motion (ROM). A functional ankle stabilizer was applied for 2.5 hours per day for 5 weeks to the patients in the control group. In the control group, the participants were asked to wear FAB during daily activities. Proprioception and balance tests were applied. The results were evaluated with the Wilcoxon test. Results: There was no difference between the functional group and the control group in terms of proprioception and balance (proprioception p=0.951, balance p=0.198) and in terms of active and passive range of motion (p>0.05). Conclusion: Ankle stability, proprioception and balance tests should be made in patients with recurrent ankle sprains. ROM values are less affected by the external stabilizer.

The rationale for this arm is to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of this combination therapy in a phase 1/2a dose-escalation study. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
In the USA and worldwide, there is a significant shortage of registered pharmacy technicians. The shortage is predicted to worsen with the aging out of thousands of current technicians. Hundreds of pharmacy educational programs have been established in the past 20 years, but it is difficult to predict the exact number of new pharmacy technicians graduating and available to fill the position of practicing technician. Pharmacy technician students do not require completion of an educational program nor registration to begin practicing as a pharmacy technician. This lack of educational and training standards makes it difficult to estimate the number of future pharmacy technicians. To accurately estimate workforce projections for pharmacy technicians, enrollment data for new pharmacy technician graduates can be used with population growth, and job-related turnover (i.e., attrition) and retirement can be used with job-related transition (i.e., advancement) rates. This protocol is designed to describe the enrollment of pharmacy technician students in the first semester of 2016-2017 through 2020-2021 to estimate the future number of newly trained technicians who can be expected to register, seek employment, and become working pharmacy technicians in the US.

However, the efficacy of these tailored interventions among women who abuse drugs in the real world of diverse outpatient treatment settings is unknown. Aim 1 of this study will test the efficacy of a tailored gender-focused brief intervention (TGFi-B), compared to a non-tailored intervention (B), to reduce alcohol use among women being treated for opioid use disorder. Women will be randomized 1:1 (50-50) to either receive TGFi-B or B in addition to the usual care treatment protocol at the New Hanover County Treatment Outpatient Program (TOP). Aim 2 of this study will test the efficacy of the intervention using an implementation-effectiveness trial design, in which the intervention is delivered by treatment staff (therapy assistants or substance abuse counselors) according to a manualized treatment protocol. All participants will receive a standard behavioral intervention at baseline, followed by motivational enhancement therapy-like sessions. The Aim 1 hypotheses are that compared to B, TGFi-B will: (1) lead to greater reductions in alcohol use; (2) lead to greater improvements in risk risky sex; (3) lead to greater increases in self-efficacy for refusing alcohol in gender-typical social situations; and (4) lead to lower HIV risk attitudes. Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a highly prevalent and serious condition, and there are currently no proven effective therapies for patients with OSA who have failed continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) due to intolerance or non-adherence. Moreover, the majority of patients prefer surgery to CPAP. Recent studies have demonstrated that the tonsils and adenoids are important sites for the treatment of OSA. Tonsillectomy is commonly performed for the treatment of tonsillitis. But endoscopic tonsillectomy/adenoidectomy causes pain, hemorrhage, and fever, which decreases the compliance of surgery. Partial tonsillectomy is less damaging to the palatine arch tissues, and the recovery is less painful than total tonsillectomy. In previous studies, partial tonsillectomy has been shown to reduce the adenoid tissue volume in the nasopharynx and improve subjective symptoms and objective findings of OSA in children. Therefore, we want to study the effect of partial tonsillectomy on adults with OSA. The aim of this pilot study is to assess the therapeutic effect of partial tonsillectomy on adult OSA. 

Brief summary in lay language
=================
Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a sleeping disorder in which a person's breathing stops and starts repeatedly during sleep. This can happen hundreds of times a night. The cause of OSA is a blockage in the airway (narrowest opening in the neck) causing an obstruction to the flow of air at the top of the throat. OSA has been linked with daytime fatigue, high blood pressure, an increased risk of heart disease, and depression. CPAP therapy, which involves wearing a mask over the nose while sleeping, is often prescribed for patients with OSA. In fact, CPAP therapy is the first treatment recommended for these patients. However, some patients do not respond to CPAP therapy because they have intolerance or non-adherence to CPAP, in which case treatment is necessary. Currently, there are no proven effective therapies for these patients, and they often require surgery. The most common surgery is adenoidectomy or tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy for the treatment of OSA in children. An

Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Patients with Spontaneous Coronary Artery Dissection (SCAD) have increased cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. The mechanism underlying this phenomenon remains poorly understood. Sympathetic overactivity and impairment of neurovascular function have been proposed as potential contributors to the development and progression of cardiovascular disease. This study aims to investigate the role of the sympathetic nervous system and neurovascular function in patients with SCAD using quantitative measurement and ultrasound-based imaging with a control group of healthy volunteers. The study will include participants with SCAD and healthy controls matched for age, gender and body mass index (BMI). The study participants will undergo a series of tests to assess their sympathetic nervous system and neurovascular function including an arterial stiffness test, an echocardiogram, carotid ultrasounds, elastography, Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) and microneurography with sympathoexcitatory maneuvers. By comparing the results of these tests, the study hopes to elucidate the role of the sympathetic nervous system and neurovascular function in the development and progression of SCAD. The findings of this study may identify novel therapeutic targets for the management of SCAD and potentially other cardiovascular conditions.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD) is a rare but life-threatening cause of acute coronary syndrome. The exact pathophysiology of SCAD remains poorly understood, and there is growing evidence to suggest that sympathetic nerve hyperactivity and impaired neurovascular function may contribute to the development and progression of the disease. The current proposed research aims to investigate the role of the sympathetic nervous system (SNS) and neurovascular function in patients with SCAD using quantitative measurement and ultrasound-based imaging. This research will involve the recruitment of patients with SCAD (n = 20) and healthy controls (n = 20) matched for age, gender and body mass index (BMI

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study is being conducted, simultaneously, at the University of California San Diego, Shands Jackson-ville Hospital/University of Florida, Medical College of Wisconsin/Froedtert Hospital, and Massachusetts General Hospital. The purpose of this study is to understand whether the VQm PHM correctly measures the respiratory-related physiologic parameters and to observe whether the VQm PHM can be used effectively with hospitalized patients. The VQm PHM is a new, non-invasive device that estimates respiratory system function. The VQm PHM is used by placing it on the fingers of the hand. When this is accomplished, the VQm PHM automatically obtains respiration rates and heart rates. When placed on the hand, the VQm PHM estimates total ventilation, exhaled tidal volume, exhaled dead space, and exhaled dead space-to-tidal volume ratio. In addition, exhaled CO2 is estimated. We will use the data collected by the VQm PHM and the data collected routinely by ICUs in the respective institutions to test the accuracy of the VQm PHM. These analyses will be done both at the bedside and at the clinical center in an off-line manner. We will also compare the VQm PHM values at bedside and off-line to see if they are concordant. In addition, we will see if there is a significant change in respiratory function (compared to the usual clinical measures obtained at the bedside) and/or cardiac function (compared to echocardiography) when patients exhibit clinical changes such as the development of hypoxemia, the development of atelectasis, and the presence of new pneumonia. We will also observe whether the VQm PHM can be used by ICU personnel for the following purposes: evaluating hemodynamic stability, identifying the early signs of inadequate oxygenation or ventilation, detecting the early signs of atelectasis, and detecting the early signs of hypoxemia and pneumonia. For the purposes of this study, we will examine one VQm PHM per subject. Subjects will receive their routine clinical care

A randomized, controlled trial of preprocedural intranasal dexamethasone on the incidence and severity of gastrointestinal bleeding after endoscopic mucosal resection for gastrointestinal tumors

Abstract:
Background and Study Aims: Gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB) is the most common untoward effect of endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR), which usually occurs within one month after EMR. GIB is the second most common complication of EMR after ulcer formation. It has been suggested by previous studies that preprocedural steroid therapy decreases the incidence of GIB. However, the evidence for preprocedural steroid therapy in the prevention of GIB is scarce. So, the purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of preprocedural intranasal dexamethasone on the incidence and severity of GIB following EMR for the treatment of gastrointestinal tumors. Materials and Methods: This is a prospective, randomized, controlled trial of 120 patients scheduled to undergo EMR for gastrointestinal tumors at the Zhejiang Provincial People's Hospital from June 2022 to June 2024. The patients will be randomly divided into two groups. Those in the intervention group will receive intranasal dexamethasone once a day one day prior to EMR, while the control group will not receive any drugs. The primary endpoint will be the incidence of GIB within one month after EMR. Secondary endpoints include the incidence of GIB within 30 and 90 days after EMR, the severity of GIB, the incidence of ulcer formation, and the incidence of adverse reactions. Conclusion: This is the first study to evaluate the efficacy of preprocedural intranasal dexamethasone in the prevention of GIB after EMR. If effective,

Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a Phase 1b/2 study with a sequential open-label design to assess the safety, tolerability, feasibility, and preliminary activity of TmPSMA-02 CAR T cells in patients with metastatic castrate-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC). After undergoing lymphodepleting lymphocyte-depleting therapy with cyclophosphamide and fludarabine, patients will be infused with a single dose of TmPSMA-02 CAR T cells in a sequential escalating dose cohort, starting from 107 (lowest) to 5e8 viable CAR T cells per dose. After initial screening and eligibility evaluations, patients will receive a maximum of 3 cycles of low-dose oral denosumab therapy prior to enrollment, followed by 4 doses of TmPSMA-02 CAR T cells infusion (Day 0, 7, 9, 11). Eligible patients will be treated with lymphodepleting lymphocyte-depleting therapy with cyclophosphamide and fludarabine at a reduced dose of 140mg/m2 per day on Days -5 and -4 before the first dose of TmPSMA-02 CAR T cells, and 120mg/m2 per day for Days -3 and -2. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study investigates the pharmacokinetics, safety, and efficacy of buprenorphine hydrochloride tablets 2 mg for treatment of opiate withdrawal in patients undergoing transient interruption of opiates for knee replacement surgery.

Detailed Description
-----------------
At this time, there is no standard medication for outpatient opioid withdrawal following transient discontinuation of opioids for knee replacement surgery. In addition, the withdrawal symptoms for opioids are less tolerable than those for alcohol. The development of safe withdrawal medications has therefore been deemed extremely important. Although the effectiveness of buprenorphine as an outpatient anti-withdrawal medication for alcohol abuse has been reported in previous studies, its application as an outpatient treatment for withdrawal symptoms of opioids has not been sufficiently studied, and its pharmacokinetics in this setting are unknown. In this study, the pharmacokinetics (PK),safety and effectiveness of buprenorphine were investigated in patients suffering from opioid withdrawal at 6, 12, 24, and 36 hours after administration.

Abstract:
This paper reports the feasibility and efficacy of the "Kaoyosokai," a health education program to prevent obesity in children aged 6‐7 years old. The program targeted a high risk age group and focused on home activity and nutrition. An uncontrolled, pre‐post comparison study was analyzed from children between 6 and 7 years old who participated in the program. The results showed that after 12 weeks of home‐based health education, the intervention group increased total energy expenditure by an average of 376 kcal/day; the mean and median body mass index (BMI) decreased by 0.44 kg/m2, and the median weight decreased by 1.6 Kg. Additionally, children's activity levels increased during the school day and after school. The program was found to be highly feasible because it met its goals and most children and parents participated fully; nevertheless, the program can be further improved by integrating some physical activity into the curriculum during school hours to better engage participants.

Intervention Description: Connect-Home Plus will be delivered in the skilled nursing facility and via telephone after discharge. It will introduce organizational structure to support delivery of transitional care processes, including the use of electronic health record (EHR) templates, Connect-Home Plus Toolkit, and staff training. The intervention will consist of two steps. In Step 1, SNF nurses, therapists, and social workers will develop a Transition Plan of Care and prepare the patient and caregiver to manage the illness and functional needs. In Step 2, a dementia caregiving specialist will make three calls to the patient's home within 30 days of discharge. The intervention will focus on key care needs such as home safety, symptom management, medication reconciliation, function and activity, and coordination of follow-up medical care.

Absolutely. The experimental arm, labeled as the Intervention arm, aims to test the effectiveness of the Connect-Home Plus program in improving transitional care for patients with Alzheimer's Disease and other dementias and their caregivers. By introducing new organizational structures and processes, we aim to enhance the delivery of transitional care in skilled nursing facilities and after discharge. This arm includes the development of a Transition Plan of Care, preparation of patients and caregivers, and follow-up calls by a dementia caregiving specialist. The intervention focuses on key care needs, such as home safety, symptom management, medication reconciliation, function and activity, and coordination of follow-up medical care. This study arm is crucial to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and impact of the Connect-Home Plus program on patient and caregiver outcomes.

Indeed. The inclusion of structured processes and follow-up support plays a vital role in improving patient outcomes, reducing caregiver burden, and enhancing the overall quality of care during the transition from SNF to home. The two-step intervention approach ensures comprehensive addressing of key care needs, and the use of technology and training tools further enhances transitional care delivery. By evaluating the impact of the Connect-Home Plus program, this study arm will provide valuable insights into the potential benefits of tailored transitional care for individuals with Alzheimer's Disease and other dementias.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This trial of the Voyager intravascular ultrasound system aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of treatment with the Voyager system for atherosclerotic renal and peripheral arterial disease (AR/PAD) patients with an angiographic lesion located within the superficial femoral artery (SFA), popliteal artery, or tibial artery. Lesion location determines treatment protocol. This is to be the first randomized trial of IVUS-guided percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) versus standard percutaneous therapy for AR/PAD patients. Enrolment is planned for up to approximately 30 AR/PAD patients in the United States who are presenting without symptoms at the time of elective revascularization. Randomization will be accomplished during the procedure and stratified by the location of study lesions. The study subjects will be followed up for 12 months.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Treatment of atherosclerotic disease (ASD) with intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) was approved by the FDA in 1996 for coronary applications. IVUS-guided treatment with coronary stenting was first performed in 1995. Currently no FDA-approved indication for peripheral applications of IVUS exists. In a previously completed un-randomized prospective single-center clinical trial using the Voyager system to guide stenting (the 'MARLON' trial), a 100% success rate was achieved with all endovascular lesions treated. Moreover, a significant reduction of technical complications was demonstrated when Voyager-guided stenting was performed. Thus the investigators now propose to conduct a randomized investigation of the safety, and efficacy of IVUS-guided treatment versus best medical therapy using standard percutaneous interventional techniques (e.g. balloon angioplasty and stent placement) for the treatment of atherosclerotic renal and peripheral arterial disease (AR/PAD) patients with an SFA, popliteal artery, or tibial artery lesion.

This trial is the first of its kind for electronic cigarettes, and we'll be comparing the effectiveness of Nicotine Replacement Therapy and Electronic Cigarettes for smoking cessation in Pakistan.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a randomized, single-blind, placebo-controlled three-arm study with 2 parallel treatment groups on the efficacy (primary outcome: the 7-day point prevalence abstinence rate - PPA7) and safety (primary safety parameter: adverse events ) of EC and NRT (gum and patch) compared to a control group (placebo patch). It is a pilot study with 90 participants who will receive either nicotine gum, electronic cigarette, or placebo patch. The study is designed to evaluate the effectiveness of using ECs in the same manner as that of nicotine gum (a medically accepted smoking cessation aid) to assist users to quit smoking, relative to a placebo patch.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will test the hypothesis that electronic cigarette (EC) and nicotine gum will yield higher rates of 7-day point prevalence abstinence (PPA 7) than placebo, but with comparable adverse effects. The primary outcome for this study is the 7-day point prevalence abstinence rates (PPA-7). Secondary outcomes include continuous abstinence rates (CAR), smoking reduction rates, expired carbon monoxide (CO) levels, number of cigarettes per day (CPD), and adverse effects. The study will be conducted in Pakistan using a randomized, single-blind, placebo-controlled parallel-group design with three arms: EC, Nicotine gum, and placebo patch. The planned sample size is 45 in each arm, resulting in a total of 135 participants. The sample size calculation was based on a pilot study conducted by one of the authors and the power analysis was done using G*Power version 3.1.9.7. The EC study will use a medically-approved device (Apollo E-Vaporizer) containing a certified nicotine concentration of 6mg/mL. The EC study will use high-quality Nicotine gum (Nicorette) with 2 mg nicotine per piece and will provide sufficient numbers of patches in

Like in the first arm, participants will use a daily nicotine patch, but with a fixed 1-mg nicotine lozenge or sublingual use of gum or lozenge for ad libitum use. Participants will be provided with a three-month supply. This arm represents an effective and commonly used option for smoking cessation.

Thank you for providing the design details. Based on the information you've shared so far, I have some suggestions for the study arms. The first study arm could be an active comparator arm, where participants receive Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT). The NRT used will be a combination therapy involving transdermal nicotine patches combined with faster-acting oral products like gum or lozenges. The strength of nicotine patches will range from 7 to 21 mg, and for gum or lozenges, the strength will be 1-4 mg. Participants will use a daily nicotine patch along with ad libitum use of the faster-acting lozenge to manage nicotine cravings. A 12-week supply of NRT will be provided. This arm represents the standard treatment for smoking cessation and allows us to compare the effectiveness of EC against a recognized and proven method.

For the second study arm, we can have an experimental arm where participants are randomized to receive Electronic Cigarettes (EC). Study design and rationale {8}
Study design
The study design is a multicenter, open-label, randomized, controlled, 2-arm, blinded end-point analysis (BEA) trial.
Study population
The study population includes adults (age ≥18 years) with newly diagnosed MM who have undergone high-dose chemotherapy with autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT) consolidation and autologous stem cell collected within 18 months of randomization.
Randomization and stratification
The patients are randomly assigned 1 : 1 at a central computerized allocation system with at least 2 participating sites at a time. Patients will be centrally randomized based on their eligibility status at the time of randomization, using an unstratified computer-generated block randomization scheme with variable block sizes to ensure a 1:1 allocation ratio. Patients are stratified by the following factors: MRI/PET positivity/negativity, MSS/SD/Hi-R- ISS stage, and cytogenetics status (normal or abnormal).
Blinding
The participants will enroll in this protocol on the basis that neither they nor the staff that conducts the trial will know whether they received lenalidomide or iberdomide until after all the data have been collected.
Intervention
The control arm employs the current standard of care (SOC) for the newly diagnosed MM population, based on the findings from the TCVP (thalidomide, cyclophosphamide, bortezomib, dexamethasone) regimen combined with high-dose melphalan and ASCT consolidation.
For patients who are ineligible for full-dose lenalidomide, the protocol allows dose reduction to a 15–25 mg dose as tolerated, which is standard practice for lenalidomide and similar drugs in all diseases treated by the NMTRD. If a patient is unable to tolerate the reduced dose (either intolerable adverse events or laboratory toxicity), he/she may be administered no lenalidomide or placebo.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The objective of this study is to investigate the safety and tolerability of the combination therapy with Cemdisiran and Pozelimab following treatment with eculizumab or ravulizumab in patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) who are refractory to or are intolerant of these drugs due to an insufficient therapeutic response or intolerable side effects.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is an open-label, non-randomized, 52-week Phase 3 study, evaluating the long-term safety, tolerability, and effectiveness of the combination regimen of Pozelimab and Cemdisiran in a select group of participants with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) who completed treatment in the parent study R3918-PNH-2021 (NCT05133531) or have a documented C5 polymorphism rendering them refractory to eculizumab or ravulizumab. The primary objective of this study is to determine the long-term safety and tolerability of this combination regimen in participants with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This multi-centre, randomized controlled trial will study the feasibility of a universal prophylaxis scheme (oral ciprofloxacin 750 mg daily) for all patients undergoing laparoscopic colorectal surgery.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Laparoscopic colorectal surgery, which consists in the reduction of the abdominal wound, has increased with improved laparoscopic skills. The use of pneumoperitoneum to distend the peritoneal cavity can reduce postoperative pain and hospital stays. However, intra-abdominal bacterial translocation during surgery can affect wound integrity and has been associated with an increase in wound infections and abdominal insufficiency syndromes. The use of antibiotics peri-operatively is recommended by the French Agency for the Safety of Health Products to reduce the burden of pathogenic bacteria in the abdominal cavity. However, the best regimen is not well established and is not adapted to all procedures. Oral antimicrobials have the advantage of an antibacterial efficacy that is independent of the duration of the drug level in the bloodstream and of the peritoneal compartment. An oral dose 1 hour before skin incision is likely to be taken up by the peritoneal cavity during surgery. Propylaxis of abdominal insufficiency syndrome should not be forgotten. Its frequency varies between 0 and 24%. It is a complication often associated with bacterial translocation. Treatments are symptomatic and only supportive. The objective of this study is to evaluate the impact of a prophylactic regimen with ciprofloxacin on the reduction of surgical site infection rates based on the CDC definition: infection that occurs within a radius of 30 days from the beginning of surgery.

Official Title
-----------------
Use of Oral Prophylactic Ciprofloxacin for All Laparoscopic Colorectal Surgery: A Multicentre, Randomized Controlled Trial

Abstract:
Patients who are unable to undergo the surgical treatment of chronic pancreatitis due to various medical comorbidities often require medication treatment. Treatments such as ursodeoxycholic acid, octreotide acetate, and antioxidants are used in the treatment of chronic pancreatitis. The aim of the study was to observe postprandial pain of the patients with chronic pancreatitis in the group who received vitamin E and ursodeoxycholic acid combined medication therapy after failure of previous treatments, and to make an estimation. A total of 31 patients with chronic pancreatitis who applied to outpatient clinic in our clinic between October 2018 and April 2022 were included in the study. The patients were evaluated using the visual analog scale. The patients were divided into 2 groups. 20 patients who received treatment with 800 mg/day Ursodeoxycholic Acid and 400 mg/day of vitamin E were included in Group 1, while 11 patients who received combination therapy with 800 mg/day Ursodeoxycholic Acid and 400 mg/day of vitamin E were included in Group 2. Patients in Group 2 were more severely symptomatic compared to Group 1. It was determined that the visual analog scale score of the Group 2 was significantly lower compared to the Group 1 (p=0,004). It was determined that there was a significant improvement in patient quality of life after 6 weeks of treatment. In conclusion, this results suggest that combination therapy with Ursodeoxycholic and Vitamin E in the treatment of chronic pancreatitis patients with intractable pain may be beneficial.

Abstract:
Introduction: Patients participating in a clinical trial can be difficult to identify, enroll, and engage. The Inside Clinical Trial Study (ICTS) is designed to understand the experiences, barriers, facilitators, and drivers that influence decisions related to clinical trials. The goal of the study is to leverage the lessons learned to improve the clinical trial process for patients, improve clinical trial access, and enhance patient‐centricity of cancer clinical trials. Methods: Using the PRECEDE model, a qualitative study of a single‐site, phase II, open‐label, multicenter, randomized, active‐controlled trial evaluating the safety and activity of cabozantinib in the neoadjuvant treatment of sarcoma was conducted. A total of 140 semistructured qualitative interviews were conducted with adult patients and/or caregivers of patients with specific rare cancer diagnoses. Results: The median age of participants was 57 years and most were white, female with a 12th‐grade education. Participants perceived clinical trial participation to be challenging due to: (1) the lack of patient support; (2) the perceived risk of cancer recurrence; (3) barriers in the clinical trial process and associated expectations of clinical trial participation; and (4) the inconvenience of time and location. The overall experiences patients had with their clinical trials were overwhelmingly positive. Specifically, participants expressed: (1) an appreciation for the availability of clinical trials and their accessibility; (2) satisfaction with the study nurses and physicians; (3) appreciation for study‐provided social support and emotional and psychological support; (4) improved access to cancer information and clinical trial information and (5) improved communication between physicians and patients. Conclusion: While most study participants experienced positive effects of clinical trial participation, they identified challenges associated with clinical trial participation. The results of this research provide the opportunity to tailor information and improve patient support to address the challenges identified so that patients make informed treatment decisions. Copyright © 2016 International Society of Pharmacoeconomics and Outcomes Research (ISPOR).

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Background and Rationale: Lung cancer is a major cause of mortality worldwide and the incidence of lung cancer is increasing among never-smokers. The overall 5-year survival rate is about 15%. The discovery of oncogenic driver mutations in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) has enabled the targeting of these oncogenic drivers using tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKI). Despite the improved effectiveness of TKIs in treatment of lung cancer, a significant proportion of patients treated with TKIs develop resistance and subsequently relapse. It is unknown when and why resistance develops. Methods: We propose to leverage a unique database of patients treated with TKI as part of a phase I study (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT00753346) to evaluate whether there is an association between clinical outcome and longitudinal measures of TKI resistance. This retrospective cohort study will leverage existing patient data, including longitudinal plasma and tissue biopsies, pre- and post-treatment radiologic response data, and clinical outcome data (time on treatment, progression free survival , and overall survival). A multi-step approach will be utilized to identify prognostic and resistance markers by combining machine learning and immunoassay technologies. Discovery and validation will be conducted using blood samples. We will leverage the translational component of the parent study to examine the translatability of the model to a new patient cohort and its clinical utility. The study will examine mechanisms of early TKI resistance to optimize future treatment strategies for patients.

Detailed Description
-----------------

The incidence of lung cancer has been increasing in younger patients across all gender and race and ethnicity subgroups. The overall survival rate for patients younger than 50 years has increased significantly over time

Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: Social media platforms can become powerful communication channels regarding health awareness. However, limited research has characterized the current online public discourse surrounding rheumatic diseases. This study aims to comprehensively describe an online discussion landscape regarding social awareness of rheumatoid arthritis (RA).METHODS: We used Vantage Social's global dataset of 140 billion posts from 10 January 2014 to 20 November 2015 obtained from 696 million Facebook users. The posts were categorized based on contextual and content information to extract a set of 128,685 discussions around RA from a total of 71 million unique users. These posts, classified as user‐generated discussions, were analyzed using machine learning classification models. We determined the proportion of discussions focused on each category's main theme. We identified two themes in the dataset: (1) personal accounts related to the illness itself and (2) conversations related to how the illness impacts the user's life and their experiences with those who have RA. These themes and subcategories were used to derive a set of five categories to characterize the social media posts: (1) seeking knowledge and information, (2) physical or mental health burden, (3) social burden, (4) social experiences, and (5) personal experiences. Top three main topics were identified within each category.RESULTS: The study found that the proportion of discussions focused on personal experiences (44.8%, 57,924 posts) was overwhelmingly dominant compared to the proportion of discussions focused on information‐seeking/gathering (21.8%, 28,312 posts), physical or mental health (7.9%, 10,513 posts), social burden (12.4%, 15,698 posts), and social experiences (9.1%, 11,705 posts). Study hypothesis

The primary endpoint is the ability of Choline PET/CT to correctly predict survival and time to clinical progression in patients with PSA recurrence of prostate cancer following radiotherapy. The second endpoint is the diagnostic accuracy of Choline PET/CT in predicting the metastatic potential of PSA recurrence in prostate cancer post radiotherapy. We want to investigate the feasibility and safety of early cessation of sedation and TTM in patients with a favorable EEG pattern. Our primary outcome measure will be the ventilator free days (VFDs) within the first 14 days after admission to the ICU. Secondary outcome measures include the length of mechanical ventilation, duration of sedation, and neurological outcomes using the Glasgow Outcome Scale Extended (GOSE) score at discharge and 3 months post-admission. groundtruth:
I'm glad you agree. Now, let's summarize the full study arms we've designed:

Study Arms:
1. Experimental: Early cessation of sedation and TTM
   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes patients who will undergo early cessation of sedation and targeted temperature management (TTM) after a cardiac arrest with a favorable EEG pattern.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The intervention involves stopping sedation and TTM early, within 12 hours of identifying a favorable EEG pattern, and potentially weaning from mechanical ventilation if appropriate.
   - Reasoning: This arm is essential to assess the feasibility and safety of early weaning from ICU treatment in patients with a favorable EEG pattern. By comparing outcomes in this group to the standard care group, the study can determine if early cessation of sedation and TTM is a viable option for these patients.

2. No Intervention: Standard Care
   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm consists of patients who will receive standard care, including sedation and targeted temperature management (TTM) for at least 24-48 hours post-cardiac arrest.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The control group will not undergo early cessation of sedation and TTM, as per standard care protocols.
   - Reasoning: This arm serves as a comparison group to evaluate the impact of early cessation of sedation and TTM in the experimental group. By having a control group receiving standard care, the study can determine if the experimental intervention leads to better outcomes compared to the standard approach. This arm helps establish the baseline for comparison and provides valuable insights into the potential benefits of early weaning from ICU treatment.

The following are typical research activities for an observational study: 
- Collecting saliva samples from periodontally healthy participants
- Conducting a diagnostic test to measure the levels of salivary biomarkers in the samples
- Analyzing the test results to identify correlations between salivary biomarkers and periodontal health
- Evaluating the diagnostic accuracy of the test

We will compare the salivary biomarkers between periodontally healthy participants and those with gingivitis, treated periodontitis, periodontitis Stages I & II, and periodontitis Stages III and IV. 

Overall, the goal of the study is to evaluate the diagnostic capability of salivary biomarkers in assessing periodontal health and disease.

Study population
=================
Healthy participants:
Inclusion criteria:
- Aged 18-65 years
- Periodontally healthy (pocket depth ≤ 3 mm and Bleeding on Probing score ≤ 10%)

Bleeding on Probing (BOP) is a commonly used measure of periodontal health. It is an indication that the gums are inflamed and may be an early sign of periodontal disease. Gingival crevicular fluid (GCF) is a fluid that surrounds the teeth and is present in the space between the gums and teeth. GCF can be analyzed to determine the presence or absence of inflammation and disease. 

Gingivitis:
Inclusion criteria:
- Aged 18-65 years
- Periodontal pocket depth ≥ 3 mm and ≤ 5 mm
- Bleeding on Probing score ≥ 10%

Treated Periodontitis Stable:

- Aged 18-65 years
- Periodontal treatment completed at least 3 months ago
- No signs of periodontal disease recurrence (pocket depth ≤ 3 mm and Bleeding on Probing score ≤ 10%)

The treated periodontitis group will include individuals who have successfully completed periodontal treatment. They will undergo the diagnostic test for salivary biomarkers to determine if these biomarkers can predict the relapse of periodontal disease.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this study is to compare and evaluate the differences in microbiota of periodontal pockets following open flap debridement (OFD) versus conventional periodontal therapy in patients with chronic periodontitis.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Aim of this study is to compare the changes in bacterial diversity in periodontal pockets following surgical open flap debridement (OFD) versus conventional periodontal therapy in chronic periodontitis patients. Periodontitis is one of the most common, chronic, bacterial infections of mankind. It is estimated that 75% of the population over 35 years of age has or is at risk of developing this disease. Current treatment usually involves scaling and root planing (SRP), but in the presence of diseased soft tissue, pockets depth 6-7mm, deep infrabony defects, or severe bone destruction, surgical treatment is required. Open flap debridement (OFD) is the current gold standard for the treatment of periodontitis, with high success rates reported when the correct amount and quality of scaling and root planing (SRP) are applied properly. The conventional therapy includes: 1. Preoperative antibiotics to reduce the level of disease-causing bacteria before surgery and help prevent bacterial regrowth; 2. Removal of all bacterial calculus within the periodontal pocket; 3. Reduction and recontouring of inflamed tissue in the affected teeth; 4. Local administration of antibiotics directly into periodontal pockets; 5. Fiberoptic curettage to remove loose connective tissue and other debris. Conventional periodontal therapy involves: 1. Systemic administration of antibiotics to inhibit the growth of microorganisms; 2. Local debridement of diseased soft tissue; 3. Abstract:
Background: Physical inactivity is a well‐known risk factor for many non‐communicable diseases (NCDs) yet there are challenges to promoting physical activity. There is a need to develop effective interventions which are low in cost and easily accessible to promote sustained engagement in physical activity. This study examines the effect of the provision of feedback from a fitness tracker on physical activity and health outcomes in a randomized controlled trial. Methods: We conducted a 2‐arm parallel trial in China from 2019 to 2021. Participants were recruited through community posts and social media, and informed consent was obtained from over 1,000 participants in 3 Chinese towns in Hunan province. Random assignment was stratified by age (< 40 and ≥ 40 years), sex, and employment status. Participants were randomly assigned to receive motivational feedback or educational feedback. The intervention was implemented over 3 months, and participants received daily online video feedback based on their daily activity level. The main outcome measures were daily steps and exercise minutes per week by physical activity monitors which participants wore over 3 months. Results: In total, 1,133 participants (60.9% female) completed the trial, with an average age of 37.3 (range 18‐90). The intervention was well‐received, with 95.8% adhering to the 14‐day intervention period. Adherence with physical activity monitoring was high, with the mean number of days of wearing the device being 66 days. There was a significant difference between the two groups in the mean number of days per week wearing the device (1.6 days versus 1.4 days, p < 0.001). At the end of the intervention, daily steps and exercise minutes per week were significantly higher in the motivational feedback group than in the educational feedback group (difference 238 steps/day, p < 0.001 and difference 11 exercise minutes/week, p < 0.01, respectively). Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) provides a non-invasive method that allows for the real-time monitoring of neural activity by measuring the Blood Oxygen Level-Dependent (BOLD) contrast. It is possible to see the area of increased neural activity before and after the drug administration, and if a difference in the activity before and after the drug administration exists, it demonstrates the therapeutic impact of the drug. The study's goal is to demonstrate the therapeutic effect through the increased activation of the brain region, the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC), by applying theta-burst TMS (TBS) over the left prefrontal cortex to the DLPFC, in participants with Parkinson's Disease (PD) who are experiencing motor impairments or a decline in executive function. The TBS-induced brain activity changes will be determined by comparing the fMRI results before and after drug administration, in both the participants with the application of TBS and the control group who only received drug administration without the TBS method.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Four healthy controls and one participant with PD each were selected to participate in the study. The clinical evaluation was performed for all participants at all visits. These evaluations included the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE), Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA), and Clinical Dementia Rating (CDR). All of the MRI procedures used an S12 Excite magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scanner (GE). Subjects were examined using the 3 Tesla (3T) MRI system in the Philips Inc. (Best, The Netherlands) Achieva platform. The patients were scanned separately with the following parameters: T2-weighted image (T2WI) coronal image with repetition time (TR)=6000 ms, echo time (TE)=120 ms, 50 slices, 408×345 mm2 field of view (FOV); T1-weighted image (T1WI) sagittal image with 3D inversion recovery (IR): TR=8

Abstract:
In Japan, the number of patients requiring liver transplant (LT) has increased over the past 20 years. The objective of this study was to compare the outcomes of LTs with the aid of a liver support system (LSS) with conventional liver resection or living donor liver transplantation in patients with de novo liver failure. We carried out a cohort study on adult patients with severe non hepatitis viral liver failure. We divided the patients into the following 3 groups: Group I: LT with LSS treatment using the Maquet LF 100 device before LT. Group II: LT after conventional liver resection performed before LT. Group III: Living donor liver transplantation. There were no differences among the 3 groups regarding the presence of hepatic encephalopathy (HE), jaundice, or coagulopathy. Complications after operations were 29 % in Group I, 40 % in Group II, and 26 % in Group III. The incidence of portal vein thrombosis (PVT) was 13 % at LT, and the rates showed no differences among the 3 groups. Although no patients died within 3 months after LT, 2 patients in Group I experienced HE and a high mortality rate due to systemic infection because of the use of the LSS. To reduce the mortality rate and adverse events related to the use of LSS, we recommend living donor liver transplantation or liver resection to facilitate LT at the acute stage of liver failure.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study will evaluate the efficacy and efficiency of using customized tongue shields for correcting the shape of upper jaws among skeletally immature pediatric patients who have a problem with crowding or have orthodontic extraction appliances. Specifically, this study aims to analyze the differences in outcomes between conventional and newly formed tongue shields when used in combination with orthodontic treatment.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and efficiency of using customized tongue shields in orthodontic treatment for correcting the shape of upper jaws among skeletally immature pediatric patients. Methods: In this study, we will randomly assign participants to two groups: a control group and an experimental group. The control group will receive traditional orthodontic treatment, while the experimental group will receive the same treatment plus a customized tongue shield for the upper canine fossa. Participants in both groups will undergo 3D imaging at the beginning and end of the treatment to evaluate the differences in outcomes between the two groups. The study duration for each participant will range from 12 to 24 months. The primary outcome measure will be the correction of upper jaw shape. Results: The primary outcome measure of this study will be the correction of upper jaw shape as reflected by 3D imaging. This is expected to provide valuable information and offer clinical evidence on the advantages of using customized tongue shields in orthodontic treatment. The data collected will play an important role in future research and clinical practice.

Official Title
-----------------
Observational Prospective Cohort Study for Correction of Upper Jaw Shape in Pediatric Patients Using Customized Tongue Shields Combined With Orthodontic Treatment: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Skeletal Class II Division 1, Crowding

Intervention / Treatment

* Other: Tongue shield

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Four hundred Chinese adults need a panoramic imaging and will be included. We will provide all the subjects with an orthodontic headgear to help them keep a fixed posture. There will be 3 different interventions which are fruit leather on the tongue, a chewing gum strip on the tongue, and a celluloid matrix between the teeth.

Detailed Description
-----------------
There will be 400 Chinese people need to take a panoramic imaging at the Oral Health Research Center of Peking University School of Stomatology in two days. They will be divided into four groups. We will take one picture for each subject at the same time. In each visit, a group of 25 subjects will be required to wear an orthodontic headgear to assist with the accurate and stable positioning of the head. Each subject will be randomized into three groups where they will perform a routine in addition to what an orthodontic headgear provides. One group of subjects, who will not have additional interventions during the panoramic imaging, will be the control group. For each subject in this group, we will only take the initial image without offering any interventions. A second group of subjects will receive fruit leather on the tongue as an intervention. For this group, the orthodontic headgear will be provided to ensure that the head remains fixed and stable during the whole process. The subjects of the third group will have strips of chewing gum on the tongue as an intervention. Again, the orthodontic headgear will help maintain this position for the duration of the panoramic imaging process. The fourth group of subjects will receive a celluloid matrix between their teeth. This will be a thin plastic cover that will be positioned between the teeth, again with the assistance of an orthodontic headgear.

Official Title
-----------------
Impact of Different Behavioural Interventions on the Reduction of the Most Common Error in Panoramic Radiography

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The objective of this study is to determine the mean bias, mean absolute relative deviation (MARD) and bias adjusted mean absolute relative deviation (Banderol) of fourteen automated, FDA/CE certified, blood glucose monitoring systems (BGMS) against a reference, standard method under conditions representing clinical practice.

Detailed Description
-----------------
In a prospective, open, randomized, repeated measurement crossover fashion, a total of 95 subjects will be included and enrolled at two measurement sites. Each subject visits the measurement site twice for a period of 2 minutes on day 1 and between 16.00 and 17.00 on day 2. The BGMS to be tested will be randomly assigned to each subject. At the time of measurement, the blood will be collected within 3 seconds using one of the fourteen BGMS for each measurement site. For each measurement site there is a reference measurement method (RMM) in use which performs the blood sugar measurement using venous blood via gas analysis at the medical institute. After each measurement the BGMS data and the reference values will be transferred directly from the test sites to the database. Each subject serves as his/her own control and will be measured four times at day 1 and once at day 2 after the fasting time of 8 hours. The results of the measurements will be analyzed in conjunction with the reference system via a statistical procedure.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The study aims to evaluate the system accuracy of 14 blood glucose monitoring systems (BGM) in comparison to a reference method. The target population is male or female patients with hypo-, eu- or hyperglycemia who have signed the written informed consent and are older than 18 years. The main objective is to evaluate the system accuracy of 14 blood glucose monitoring systems (BGM) according to DIN EN ISO 15197:2015. The study will consist of 150 subject visits over the course of 24 months. The study design includes visits with experimental, reference and glucometer test arms. The study design will allow the monitoring of inter-subject variability and intra-subject variability of the systems. The total number of sample points per subject is up to 372, which includes up to 127 points in the reference method arm and up to 62 points in the experimental arm, respectively.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Treatment for smoking cessation aims to address the complex issue of tobacco addiction to support individuals with behavioral and psycho-social needs. The prevalence of tobacco use in rural populations presents a severe public health challenge, increasing the need for tailored, mobile treatments. This study evaluates the use of a novel text-message smoking cessation intervention, Take a Break, in conjunction with nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) sampling in rural Pennsylvania. This study aims to examine the effects of tailored text messages and NRT sampling in a randomized controlled trial (RCT).

Detailed Description
-----------------
Smoking has decreased in the U.S. but remains prevalent among rural populations. Smokers in rural areas are less likely to make use of cessation services such as counseling, pharmacotherapy, or both, when compared to their urban counterparts. Treatment for smoking cessation aims to address the complex issue of tobacco addiction to address the behavioral and psycho-social needs of smokers. Rural and low-income smokers may present with more severe addiction than others, making them more difficult to treat. This research aims to evaluate the use of a novel text-message smoking cessation intervention that uses adaptive challenges and an app-based program for rural Pennsylvania residents. This project aims to 1) Examine the efficacy of a behavioral intervention: text-message based cessation support with or without NRT sampling (TAKE AB) to engage tobacco users into quitting and 2) Test the effect of TAKE AB and NRT sampling versus NRT sampling only on tobacco use, abstinence, negative consequences of tobacco use, and negative reinforcement of tobacco use.

Smoking Cessation Study for Rural Populations

- The standard program is a set of actions or steps that can be taken to improve the quality of healthcare delivery. Typically, these actions are aimed at addressing a specific problem or need, and they may involve different healthcare professionals working together to provide care. An example of a standard program might be a set of actions or steps designed to improve the management of an illness or condition, such as diabetes. Such a program might involve regular check-ups and blood tests, as well as education and counseling to help patients manage their diabetes effectively. The standard program may be delivered by healthcare professionals such as doctors, nurses, and dietitians working together.
- The enhanced implementation program, on the other hand, is a type of program that aims to support healthcare professionals in implementing the standard program effectively. This might involve additional training or resources, as well as ongoing support and monitoring. The goal is to ensure that the standard program is implemented consistently and effectively, in order to improve outcomes for patients.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to test the effectiveness of a smartphone-based smoking cessation application called Take a Break in rural areas. The application combines evidence-based behavioral intervention methods with gamification elements to enhance engagement and motivation. Additionally, participants will receive an over-the-counter nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) sample pack.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a single-blind, randomized, controlled trial with four study arms. The study aims to recruit 2,100 participants aged 18-75 years who smoke more than 4 cigarettes per day and are willing to quit smoking. They will be screened and selected based on the study inclusion criteria, which include geographic location in the state of Tennessee, owning a smartphone, and the potential to participate in the 10-week intervention. The study will utilize a randomized block design with two block sizes: 2 and 4. The ratio of 2:2 will be used for the comparison between groups A-D in each block. Group A will participate in the Take a Break intervention and receive nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) sampling. For group B, which is the enhanced program, the only difference is that they will also receive a community paramedicine contact and referral to smoking cessation resources. Group C will interact with the Take a Break program and act as an incentive arm. In this group, they will not receive an incentive for completing the study; however, they will be placed in a prize pool. Group D will not participate in the Take a Break program and serve as a control group. Only group A will receive NRT sampling.

Take A Break - Rural: A Single-Blind, Multisite, Randomized, Controlled Trial of a Mobile Smoking Cessation Application in Rural Tennessee

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
A total of 800 rural smokers will be recruited. We are recruiting in five counties, so we are aiming to recruit 160 smokers per county across the five counties. This sample size distribution will be determined by geographic distribution across the target counties based on the rurality of the area. We will follow up with the participants 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, 8 months, 10 months, and 12 months after their enrollment and compare the difference in the quit rates and other outcomes among the participants. Quit rates will be measured by confirming the outcome with pharmacy prescription data and validated quitlines data. Self-reported quit rates will also be analyzed by telephone follow-up.

Detailed Description
-----------------
RATIONALE: Rural smokers are less likely to get access to smoking cessation services than urban smokers. Community paramedicine programs have potential to bridge the gap in access to smoking cessation services for disadvantaged populations, such as rural residents. In addition, gamified interventions have recently shown promising results in the field of smoking cessation. The aim of this study is to address the challenges of limited access to smoking cessation services and low motivation for cessation among rural smokers. To do so, we designed a community paramedicine program with a 13-week personalized interactive text messaging intervention using gamification strategies. We will recruit 800 rural smokers (total) across five counties and assess the impact of the intervention on the cessation rate, relapse rate, and motivation to quit smoking, as well as other biomarkers (carbon monoxide, exhaled carbon monoxide, and cotinine), and quality of life. We plan to conduct a longitudinal pilot study including a 1-month pre-intervention, a 13-week intervention, and a 12-month follow-up period to assess the effects of the community paramedicine program on our primary and exploratory outcomes. To estimate the diagnostic accuracy of shear wave dispersion imaging (SWDI) for detecting suspicious breast lesions, we prospectively recruited 182 patients with suspicious calcifications and microcalcifications on breast tomosynthesis (BT). SWDI results were blindly correlated with histology results based on the area underneath the curve (AUC) and receiver operator characteristic (ROC) curve analysis. SWDI provided an AUC of 0.78 (95% c.i. 0.72‐0.85) for the detection of malignancy compared with microcalcifications (0.62 (0.55‐0.69)) and BT (0.58 (0.51‐0.66)). SWDI showed a sensitivity of 75% and a specificity of 81%. The combination of SWDI and BT significantly enhanced the AUC (0.87 (0.81‐0.92), p = 0.001). However, the addition of SWDI to BT did not enhance the specificity (2 %) or sensitivity (48 %).
