INTRODUCTION: Intramucosal carcinomas (IMCs) of the stomach represent a distinct type of mucosal gastric carcinoma with a unique pattern of invasion and infiltration into the gastric folds. They have high incidence rates among young people and in the distal stomach. They are different from other gastric carcinomas both for their clinical features and their therapeutic and prognostic implications. The purpose of this study was to characterize the endoscopic appearance of these cancers to better define them as a separate entity. METHODS: Prospectively, the diagnostic yield and the clinical and endoscopic differences between IMCs of the stomach and other types of gastric carcinomas were analyzed by retrospectively reviewing the endoscopic features of 186 gastric carcinomas (136 non‐neoplastic lesions, 50 non‐IMCs, and 125 IMCs) with the endoscopic appearance and histologic findings. RESULTS: Of the 186 gastric cancer cases, 53.2% were IMCs and 46.8% were non‐IMCs. Histologically, 95.4% of the IMCs and 42.9% of the non‐IMCs were well‐differentiated tubular adenocarcinomas. Abstract:
Background: Non‐alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and obesity are common comorbidities in heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) patients. Previous studies demonstrated that the clinical course and outcomes for patients with NAFLD or obesity were different from those without. However, the specific effect of obesity and NAFLD on HFpEF patients remains to be elucidated. We aimed to evaluate the clinical profiles, characteristics, and prognosis of HFpEF patients with NAFLD and obesity. Methods: We retrospectively reviewed the clinical data of patients with HFpEF who were enrolled in a prospective database. The primary outcome was a composite endpoint of the 2‐year all‐cause mortality rate between the normal weight group, obese group, and NAFLD group. The secondary outcomes included the occurrence of all‐cause death, all‐cause hospitalization, heart failure hospitalization, stroke, and cardiac arrest among HFpEF patients. Results: A total of 2064 HFpEF patients were included. There was a significant difference in the incidence of cardiac arrest in normal‐weight patients with NAFLD (2.5% in obese group, 5.8% in NAFLD, and 1.5% in the normal‐weight group, P<0.001), but the 2‐year all‐cause death did not differ among the normal‐weight group, obese group, and NAFLD group (P=0.147). The cumulative risk of all‐cause death at 2 years was greatest for obese patients with NAFLD (7.9%) compared with normal‐weight patients with NAFLD and obese patients (P=0.027). We retrospectively evaluated the incidence and time to development of MDS and its acute myeloid leukemia (AML) transformation.RESULTS: We identified 1989 patients with VL‐ML B‐ALL at diagnosis who did or did not receive EGF or MGF. After a median follow up of 5.4 years (95% confidence interval [CI], 5.2‐5.6 years), myeloid/erythroid leukemias (AML, MDS + AML) developed in 42 patients (2.1%, 95% CI, 1.4‐3.0%). Abstract:
The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effects of isometric handgrip exercises and lower‐limb exercises in community‐dwelling older adults in Taiwan. This randomized controlled trial was conducted with a parallel‐group design. A total of 95 older adult volunteers were randomly divided into a control group and an intervention group. The intervention group performed unilateral and bilateral isometric handgrip exercises at 4 positions of the hand, and one‐legged weight‐bearing lower‐limb exercises for 2 sets at 50% of each participant's voluntary maximum. The control group participated in social educational activities. Both groups underwent 36‐week training sessions twice a week, for a total of 32 sessions. The primary outcome was grip strength, and the secondary outcomes were walking speed, sit‐to‐stand (STS), five times sit‐to‐stand (FTS), Timed Up and Go (TUG), and dynamic balance, as measured by the Single Leg Reaching Test (SLRT). All outcomes were assessed at a 6‐month follow‐up. Both groups showed improvements from baseline in the measured outcomes compared to the pretest. However, the intervention group showed better improvements in posttest performance for all assessments. The intervention group's outcomes were significantly better than the control group for both the TUG and FTS tests. Isometric handgrip exercise and weight‐bearing lower‐limb exercise are both useful for improving function in older adults. The results of this study suggest that isometric handgrip exercise and weight‐bearing lower‐limb exercise may be effective non‐pharmacological interventions for improving the function and quality of life of older adults.

Introduction
Sarcopenia is the gradual loss of skeletal muscle mass and strength. It occurs due to the simultaneous effect of decreased muscle mass and reduced muscle strength, which can lead to reduced mobility, decreased physical activity, and poor quality of life.

Background
=================
A high proportion of patients with Crohn’s Disease (CD) experience loss of response (LOR) to adalimumab (ADA) treatment. Several approaches to intensify antitumor necrosis factor (TNF) therapy have been studied in patients (pts) with LOR on ADA, including adalimumab dose escalation and optimization, as well as switching to another biologic agent. Currently, the 2019 European Crohn's and Colitis Organisation (ECCO) guidelines recommend dose intensification for pts who have a clinical response to first-line biotherapy but have experienced LOR without biomarker evidence of loss of response upon ADA discontinuation. However, these recommendations are based on a small number of randomized controlled trials (RCTs), including the recently published STOP-CD  trial. Additional RCT evidence is needed to validate guidelines, assess the optimal treatment sequence, and identify predictive biomarkers to guide the most effective approach. 

This trial is designed to compare the efficacy of vedolizumab (Ved), a gut-tropic, integrin α4β7 antagonist, with adalimumab with dose enhancement (ADE), which involves adjusting the dose in patients losing response.

Brief Summary

To compare the efficacy and safety of Vedolizumab versus Adalimumab in patients with loss of response or biomarker activity to adalimumab on first line.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Background and rationale Crohn's Disease patients with loss of response or biomarker activity to Adalimumab on first line. The study aims to investigate whether patients with Crohn's disease who have initially responded to adalimumab but have experienced loss of response or biomarker activity benefit from switching to vedolizumab versus adalimumab with dose intensification. Methods An international, randomized, multicenter, open-label, Phase 4 non-inferiority study. Patients with moderate to severe Crohn's disease who have previously responded to adalimumab but have lost response or developed biomarker activity to adalimumab will be randomized 1:1 to receive either vedolizumab or adalimumab. The primary endpoint is the proportion of patients in clinical remission at Week 52, as assessed by the Simple Endoscopic Score for Crohn's Disease. Other clinical assessments, including symptomatic, imaging, and inflammatory markers endpoints, will be evaluated. Adverse events will also be monitored throughout the trial.

Background and aim of the studyThe aim of this prospective double-blind, placebo-controlled, multicentre study is to compare two dosage regimens to be used for maintenance treatment in the Crohn's disease population. Hypothesis This study aims to evaluate the superiority of a continuous low dose therapy over treatment interruption. 
Main research questions (1) Is continuous drug administration superior to treatment by treatment interruptions in maintaining remission in patients with Crohn's disease? (2) Is continuous drug administration associated with a greater risk of drug withdrawal due to adverse events? Methodology A prospective randomized controlled cross-over study that includes a treatment regimen according to the current standard (80 mg subcutaneously every two weeks at the time of inclusion) or a high dose followed by intensive maintenance administration of 108 mg subcutaneously every 14 days for 6 months during a cessation period (no drug administration). Both treatment strategies will be followed by 6 months of treatment with open control of the investigator's choice. The treatment regimen has been selected according to the current guidelines: If, after 6 months of induction therapy, a good response is noted, the drug is switched in the second year to one of the 2 treatment strategies (either high dose or cessation). After 6 months of the treatment strategy the therapy will be changed to the other strategy and the patients will again be randomly assigned to one of the treatment strategies. At the end of the 24-month treatment period, the patients are again randomly allocated to one of the 2 treatment strategies and undergo endoscopic investigation. The patients are reassessed after 6 months. The response will be assessed every 14 days using a telephone checklist. After the first year, the patients will be re-examined every 4 months using telephone contact. Abstract:
PURPOSE: We developed and examined the impact of the vitamin energy shot (VES)‐ a small, convenient, and low‐dose energy drink that contains caffeine, vitamins, minerals, and L‐Carnitine, on subjective cognitive performance over an extended period of time, relative to the leading commercial energy drink.METHODS: The present randomized, controlled study was designed to compare VES and Red Bull performance effects over a 6‐hr period and to investigate possible biochemical mediators.RESULTS: The VES was found to elevate ratings of alertness to a greater extent than Red Bull and maintain this effect at 2‐, 3‐, and 4‐hrs postconsumption. VES did not alter arousal or mood as a function of time when compared to Red Bull. Plasma L‐Carnitine and caffeine concentrations were elevated at 6‐hrs relative to the baseline for Red Bull and VES conditions, respectively.DISCUSSION: VES was effective at increasing ratings of alertness and maintaining this effect for at least 4 hrs post‐consumption. Both beverages resulted in elevations of L‐Carnitine and caffeine. The observed differences in cognitive outcomes between VES and Red Bull may reflect the lower levels of L‐Carnitine and caffeine observed following the VES.IMPLICATIONS: The current results indicate that the VES results in increased cognition and may be a less concentrated alternative for healthy adults seeking acute cognitive enhancing effects relative to the leading commercial energy drink.

Brief Summary

Hypotheses: Efficacy H1: Bacillus coagulans will reduce serum C-Reactive Protein (CRP), as compared to a control supplement formulated with an inactive microbial component. Primary objective: As measured by ELISA, a reduction in baseline serum C-reactive protein (CRP) at week 6 will be found in participants taking the active supplement compared to the control. Secondary objectives: As measured by ELISA, a reduction in baseline interleukin-1 beta (IL-1 beta), interleukin-6 (IL-6), and interleukin-8 (IL-8) will be found in participants taking the active supplement compared to the control at week 6. This report serves to summarize a study to evaluate the effects of Bacillus coagulans on serum CRP in overweight and obese adults. The primary objective of the study is to assess the difference in change of serum CRP after 6 weeks from baseline in participants receiving Bacillus coagulans in a proprietary supplement compared to participants receiving a placebo supplement. To assess the effect of Bacillus coagulans on serum CRP, this pilot study recruited 55 overweight and obese participants. Forty-four (44) participants completed the study. After 6 weeks of supplement ingestion, there was no statistically significant difference in the reduction of CRP in those taking the supplement as compared to those taking the placebo. These results support the use of Bacillus coagulans in larger trials examining this interaction.

Study details

Brief summary in scientific language
=================
Background: Non-anastomotic biliary strictures (NAS) are a significant challenge in patients following liver transplantation. The gold standard management is endoscopic retrograde cholangiography (ERCP) with stent placement, with conflicting evidence on optimal timing and frequency of ERCP interventions. This observational patient registry study aims to evaluate the effect of endoscopic-intervention timing on clinical outcomes in patients with NAS following liver transplantation. Methods: In this single-center prospective observational study, patients with NAS following liver transplantation will be evaluated using biliary endoscopic retrograde cholangiography (ERCP) procedures during a 12-month follow-up. The primary efficacy endpoint is 1-year biliary clinical complications requiring re-interventions, including cholangitis, recurrent strictures, or liver transplant rejection in patients with NAS identified by biliary endoscopic retrograde cholangiography. The primary safety endpoint is mortality during the follow-up. Secondary endpoints include adverse events, cost-effectiveness assessment, biliary stricture resolution, and impact on quality of life. The study will be conducted at a tertiary referral center in Canada, and the statistical analysis will be based on Kaplan-Meier survival curves, Cox-regression models, and univariate and multivariate correlations analysis. The registry is anticipated to enroll 150 patients, with funding provided by the Canadian Institutes of Health Research.

Background/Objectives
-----------------
With the introduction of liver transplantation, the number of living donor liver transplantation (LDLT) has increased rapidly in Korea, accounting for 75% of all liver transplantations in 2020. LDLT is considered a treatment option with low risk for graft and patient survival compared to de-novo liver transplantation (D‐LT) . While the primary graft non-function (PNG) rate is significantly lower in LDLT than in D‐LT, the development of biliary complication is a major problem that can lead to serious complications such as liver cirrhosis, hepatic abscess, and even mortality . Among the factors that lead to biliary complications after LDLT, ischemia‐reperfusion injury of the bile duct is known to be the main cause, with about 40~ 60% of cases reported . These biliary complications can be divided into early and late biliary complications, with early onset occurring within 30 days of surgery and late onset occurring 30–90 days after surgery . The incidence of biliary complications after LDLT is high, with an average of 10–70% , and is more common in LDLT than in D‐LT due to the smaller caliber of the bile duct . Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
The main objective of STARTER is to confirm the long-term efficacy, and to assess safety and immunogenicity of tocilizumab treatment in patients with giant cell arteritis (GCA).

Detailed Description
-----------------
Giant cell arteritis (GCA) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the medium and large-sized arteries. The main treatment option is a high dose of oral steroids, with slow steroid tapering to keep inflammation of the vessel wall under control. A major unmet need is the need for a pharmacological treatment to allow early, and possibly rapid, dose reduction of steroids, while maintaining disease control over the long term. STARTER is a phase 2/3 study of tocilizumab in patients with GCA. Part A of this study is a 68 week, randomized, double-blind (drug & placebo), active-controlled, multicenter study of tocilizumab 162 mg (iv or sc) vs placebo (iv) + background standard of care (SoC), and tocilizumab 86 mg (iv) + background SoC. Approximately 270 patients with active GCA who are on oral SoC with a 17-item disease activity score (DAS17) ≥ 2, (at Screening) and ≥ 1.5 despite oral SoC for > 6 months will be randomized in Part A. Aside from investigational therapy (IT), all patients will receive SoC, which include non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and/or prednisone. Primary objective of the study is to determine maintenance of GCA remission through the end of week 68 (EoW 68) as defined by DAS17 ≤1 AND modified Medical Research Council (mMRC) polyarteritis nodosa ≤ 1 AND C-reactive protein (CRP) ≤ 3 mg/L. (DAS17 of 2 or more, or modified MRC polyarteritis nodosa of 2 or more, or CRP of 3 or more defined the criteria for active GCA at baseline per investigator judgement.)

Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Pilot study of an internet-based communication aid intervention for couples with Primary Progressive Aphasia. PPA is a neurodegenerative speech and language disorder that involves gradual loss of language ability, often accompanied by a decline in behavioral and cognitive function. Aphasia is also known as language disorder. Individuals with PPA experience changes in speech and language that interfere with communication and daily life activities, such as reading, writing, and speaking. The intervention will be provided by speech-language pathologists. The intervention is designed to enhance the participation in activities of daily living of people with PPA by using personalized training stimuli and online-video interactions. The intervention is delivered via the internet, so it can be provided from a distance through web-based platforms such as Skype and Facetime. The study hypothesis is that the new intervention will improve people's ability to communicate with their spouse, improving their quality of life and the quality of their relationship. The study consists of two arms: Treatment group: All participants will participate in the intervention during the study period. The treatment involves using online-video interactions using personally salient training stimuli and participation in activities of daily living. The treatment will be provided by speech-language pathologists trained in treating PPA. Control group: The control group will receive usual care during the study period. This arm is only designed as a control group for this study and will not be given a treatment. The control group will not be involved in any experimental procedures.

Detailed Description
-----------------
PPA describes a disease characterized by a chronic progressive loss of ability to form and use language. The course of the disease depends on various individual factors. The disease can run for five years but with varying degrees of severity and in different ways. Some people may lose a lot of their language capacity early on, quickly reaching a steady state. Others go on to a gradual deterioration over many years. There are differences in how language development occurs in children with various types of aphasia. In children, the speech and language difficulties are usually the same type as in adults. The intervention will be provided by speech-language pathologists. The intervention is designed to enhance the participation in activities of daily living

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of external cephalic version for twin pregnancies with antenatal problems through a randomised control trial.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The aim of this trial is to evaluate the effectiveness of external cephalic version (ECV) for twin pregnancies with antenatal problems in improving the outcome of twin pregnancy. The following specific objectives will be explored: To evaluate the effectiveness of ECV in twin pregnancies with antenatal problems in improving the outcome of twin pregnancy in terms of: Percentage reduction in the number of preterm and unplanned deliveries Reduction in the number of preterm and unplanned deliveries under obstetric care Reduction in the duration of pregnancy after ECV in the study group compared with the control group Reduction in the duration of hospital stay for preterm and unplanned deliveries in the study group compared with the control group Reduction in total cost of deliveries in the study group compared with the control group To evaluate a decrease in the incidence of postpartum haemorrhage in the study group by applying ECV for twin delivery compared with those cases that are delivered without ECV Reduction in the incidence of fetal or neonatal morbidity or mortality in twin deliveries in which ECV is applied In all twin deliveries in which ECV has been attempted in the study group, maternal and fetal parameters will be recorded preoperatively, and fetal parameters will be recorded on the day of delivery. The primary outcome will be the reduction of the adverse neonatal outcomes related to preterm labour, which can be assessed by means of the clinical and laboratory assessment of the fetus or neonate, including respiratory distress syndrome and/or chronic lung disease requiring intensive care unit (ICU) admission. Secondary outcome will be the reduction of maternal complications, such as infection or postpartum haemorrhage, and the cost of delivery.

Effectiveness of External Cephalic Version in Twin Pregnancies With Antenatal Problems: A Randomised Control Trial

Twin

Abstract:
Background: Although the impact of intrauterine reperfusion of ovarian stimulation (OS) cycles for the treatment of female infertility has been studied in meta‐analysis, it remains unclear whether reperfusion improves the pregnancy and implantation rates among high responder patients. Thus, we aimed to assess the clinical impact of early intrauterine reperfusion in high responder patients. Patients and methods: This study was retrospectively performed using the clinic's data for patients who were treated with frozen embryo transfer (FET) between January 2011 and December 2015. A total of 1182 high response patients who underwent first FET cycles were randomly assigned to two groups, including 684 patients in the reperfusion group and 527 patients in the no‐reperfusion group. The clinical outcomes and perinatal outcomes were compared between the two groups. Results: Among the 1182 patients, 99.1% of them had a total of 2‐4 transfers while 63.6% of them had undergone one transfer. In the no‐reperfusion group, the transfer interval (median of days, 21.0 versus 7 days, P < 0.0001) and the number of thawed embryos (two embryos, 75.7% versus 83.5%, P < 0.0001) were significantly shorter than in the reperfusion group. The cumulative clinical pregnancy rate (CPR) was significantly higher in the reperfusion group than in the no‐reperfusion one within 1 year (33.2% versus 28.3%, P = 0.01). Although the perinatal outcomes were similar between the two groups, the abortion rate of the reperfusion group was significantly higher (15.3% versus 8.9%, P = 0.01). Conclusions: Early intrauterine reperfusion could not improve the pregnancy outcomes in high response patients.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The main goal of this study is to evaluate whether the external cephalic version (ECV) procedure is more effective in women with non-vertex presenting twin. An anticipated benefit of this study is that it would provide information regarding the success rates of the ECV procedure in this specific population while accounting for demographic and medical factors.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The main purpose of this study is to evaluate whether the external cephalic version (ECV) procedure is more effective in women with non-vertex presenting twin. During the second trimester of pregnancy, between 32 and 35 weeks gestational age, the ECV procedure can be performed in conjunction with tocolysis with the intent of inducing a fetal head-down position. The procedure is performed by applying gentle traction and pressure to the uterus while the fetal head is in the vaginal canal. While there is evidence that the ECV procedure is effective in a general population of pregnant women with a singleton fetus, there is limited evidence that the procedure is effective in women with twin pregnancies. The outcomes of interest in this study are the pre-intervention and post-intervention cephalic presentation of the twin fetuses. The investigators hypothesis is that more women in the twin group will have successful external cephalic version (ECV) procedure.

Of course, the control group will receive standard care for CIPN. The hot compressing group will wear a hot compress on their hands and feet before and after chemotherapy, aiming to improve the microcirculation of the peripheral nerves and increase the blood supply to the fingertips, toes, and palms. The cold compressing group will wear cold compresses on their hands and feet before and after chemotherapy, hoping to reduce the thermal damage to peripheral nerves and reduce the damage caused by chemotherapy. The design of each group was based on the scientific literature and expert consultation. The temperature control for the hot compressing group was set based on the results of in vitro experiments and animal experiments, which showed that temperature control in the range of 37-38 degrees Celsius could improve microcirculation, increase blood flow, and reduce oxidative stress. The temperature control for the cold compressing group was set based on the studies of other scholars, which showed that temperature control in the range of 12-18 degrees Celsius could reduce thermal damage and reduce the risk of peripheral nerve damage.

It will involve hot compresses applied to the hands and feet for 20 minutes. Heat application is believed to increase blood circulation, reduce inflammation, and relieve pain and discomfort associated with chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN). The use of hot compresses has been found to be effective in managing various forms of pain, including neuropathic pain, which is the type often experienced by chemotherapy patients. Research suggests that heat application can increase blood flow to the nerve endings, allowing for faster healing and reducing sensitivity to pain. Moreover, it has been found that applying heat to the lower extremities can help reduce muscle spasms and increase mobility. 

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
CIPN is the most common chronic chemotherapy toxicity in outpatients, and it is associated with impairments in various areas of quality of life. In this study, patients diagnosed with CIPN were randomly assigned to a control group and an experimental group to perform thermal compress therapy after administration of oxaliplatin. The results showed that in comparison with the control group, the experimental group showed significant improvement in nerve-related symptoms and quality of life, and the incidence of CIPN was reduced. In addition to the above results, this study also provided a basis for the prevention and treatment of CIPN, and this study may provide some clinical evidence for clinical nursing and treatment. The results show that the incidence of severe CIPN was reduced from 15.9% to 7.0%.The incidence of low-grade neuropathy was also reduced from 25% to 14.4%, and the incidence of medium-grade neuropathy was reduced from 25% to 9.7%.

Abstract:
Background: There are limited data on the pharmacokinetics of remimazolam in young patients. Our aim was to evaluate the disposition characteristics of remimazolam in children aged six to 18 years. Methods: We conducted a post‐hoc analysis of data from children enrolled in a prospective, randomized, controlled, open‐label parallel‐group phase II trial of remimazolam. In the parent study, remimazolam was administered at 0.1 mg/kg to 106 pediatric patients. After induction, patients were maintained with remimazolam at a dose of 0.06 mg/kg/h. Population pharmacokinetics for the adult drug was developed by the study sponsor to extrapolate pediatric pharmacokinetics based on the weight of the individual patients. Results: The median age of the children (n = 38) included in this post‐hoc analysis was 10 years (range, 6‐18). The median weight of the children was 18.7 kg (range, 5.4‐39.0), and the median dose of remimazolam received at induction was 0.09 mg /kg (range, 0.02‐0.14). After induction, the median maintenance dose was 0.05 mg/kg/h (inter‐quartile range, 0.04‐0.05). The terminal elimination half‐life was 29.2 min and the clearance was 0.055 L/kg/min, which are comparable to those for adults (27.5 min, 0.050 L/kg/min). Conclusion: Pharmacokinetics of remimazolam appears to be similar in adults and children, where an age‐normalized weight‐based dosing approach may be used in pediatric patients. Study of efficacy and safety of ZHDIXU injection in treatment of severe pneumonia combined with acute respiratory distress syndrome in patients with novel coronavirus pneumonia

Abstract:
Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of ZHDIXU injection in treating patients with novel coronavirus pneumonia (COVID‐19) complicated with severe pneumonia or mild‐to‐moderate acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Methods: Forty consecutive patients with severe pneumonia or mild‐to‐moderate ARDS caused by COVID‐19 confirmed by nucleic acid test were assigned to test group A (20 cases) and control group B (20 cases) according to the order of onset date. Group A was treated with ZHDIXU injection, while group B was treated with a conventional therapy regimen combined with mesenchymal stem cell therapy. The clinical symptoms, laboratory indicators, pulmonary lesions on chest CT, and oxygenation indexes were assessed, and pulmonary function was evaluated before and 14 days after treatment in the two groups, with 80 cases as the final analysis set. The incidence of adverse reactions was also compared. Results: Both groups showed significant improvements in clinical symptoms and laboratory indicators and significant recovery of pulmonary function after treatment. The clinical symptoms, laboratory indicators, pulmonary lesions, and oxygenation indexes between the two groups showed no significant differences before treatment or 14 days after treatment. The improvements in clinical symptoms, laboratory indicators, pulmonary lesions, and oxygenation indexes 14 days after treatment were better in the group A than the group B. The proportion of patients with the improvement of pulmonary function in the group A was more than the control group, and the recovery rate of pulmonary function was significantly higher than that in the control group (P<0.05). The incidence of adverse reactions in the two groups had no significant difference. Conclusion: ZHDIXU injection can effectively improve the clinical symptoms, pathogenesis, lung lesions, and oxygenation indexes in patients with COVID‐19 complicated with severe pneumonia or mild‐to‐moderate ARDS. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The 68 Ga-FAPI-46 radioligand has the potential to detect, characterize and monitor solid tumours. The hypothesis is that tumour-derived levels of FAP are elevated in cancer and that quantitative assessment of 68Ga-FAPi-46 accumulation in tumours with subsequent analysis of the biodistribution on PET -CT will predict treatment response and prognostics. It is important to use an accurate method for quantification of 68Ga-FAPI-46 data. Therefore, the investigators will implement a novel method for the assessment of 68Ga-FAPI-46 uptake using quantitative analyses. This new method will enable precise 68Ga-FAPI-46 measurements and furthermore this will enable the assessment of treatment response and the prognostic assessment when administering 68Ga-FAPI-46 in combination with treatment. A potential side effect of a nuclear medicine procedure can be low rate irradiation. This is a clinical PET study where a combination of clinical examination, ECG, clinical lab tests and a computerized tomodensitometry (CT) of the neck, abdomen, and pelvic area will be performed. The purpose of clinical examination of the neck, abdomen, and pelvic area in connection with the tracer is to assess if there is any clinical difference in these specific areas of the body after 68Ga-FAPI-46 intake.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The aim of the study is to evaluate the quantitative assessment of 68Ga-FAPI-46 uptake in solid tumors using 4 categories: nonexpressed, mild expression, moderate expression, and strong expression, and the aim is to investigate the differences between the different categories of FAPI-46 expression. Density quantification (volumetric) will be performed in this trial. The investigators will investigate if 68Ga-FAPI-46 PET/CT can discriminate patients in different FAPI-46 expression categories and furthermore, if there is any difference between the expression categories assessed by 68Ga-FAPI-46 PET/CT and tumors without

Randomization will be stratified in a 1:1:1: 1 ratio.  Block randomization schemes using random permuted blocks of size 4 with fixed block size will be used.  The method used will be the minimization method. Minimization has two primary goals: Minimizing the average difference between groups and maintaining a balance within each stratum. The minimization algorithm will use a stochastic permuted block design to construct random allocation sequences.

The intervention in this arm is the administration of Adalimumab. By including a positive control group, we can compare the efficacy of 608 to an established treatment for AS, which in this case is Adalimumab. This comparison will provide valuable information on the potential of 608 as a new treatment option.

The final arm will be the Placebo Comparator: Placebo. Patients in this arm will receive a Placebo subcutaneous injection. The intervention involves administering a Placebo. The placebo arm is crucial to assess the true effect of 608 in treating AS. By comparing the outcomes in the placebo arm to the active treatment arms, researchers can determine the specific benefits of 608 beyond the placebo effect. This helps establish the actual efficacy of 608 in AS patients.

Abstract:
Background: Dissolvable tobacco products (DTPs) have increased in popularity among teenagers and young adults in many countries. The popularity of these products may be related to ease of disposal and the lack of an offensive smell. DTPs pose several hazards to oral health, which are more pronounced in some products when compared to other smokeless tobacco. However, most studies conducted to date have been of a retrospective nature, often in populations that have been exposed to DTPs for extended periods. Moreover, many product‐specific studies lack reliable data on the nicotine content of the products evaluated. Objective: This study aimed to compare the nicotine delivery and content of the pouch‐based ZONnic range (BAT GmbH, Dortmund, Germany) in four different product types, one without and three with added flavour. Participants and method: Twenty‐four healthy participants were studied across two visits. For each product, five pouches were held under the lower lip for a duration of 25 minutes at each visit. The mean salivary nicotine concentration (Cs, ng/ml) at each time was calculated. The number of participants who achieved a nicotine concentration ≥ 10 ng/ml (Cs ≥ 10 ng/ml, P10), and the proportion of participants who exceeded this concentration (Cs > 10 ng/ml, A10) were determined. Nicotine content (NC, mg) was determined using HPLC. Results: For the first two visits, 24 subjects were recruited, of which 20 subjects completed all testing. Product A yielded a mean ± SD Cs of 5.82 ± 3.80, while product B yielded 3.70 ± 3.41; product C yielded 5.45 ± 3.77, and product D yielded 6.57 ± 4.22. P10 (Cs ≥ 10 ng/ml) was detected in 4/20 subjects for product A; 2/20 subjects for product B; 6/20 subjects for product C; and 9/20 subjects for product D (Cs > 10 ng/ml) was detected

Brief Summary

The aim of the proposed study is to evaluate the anti-inflammatory effects of nimodipine in subjects with a history of recent stroke. The investigators plan to recruit 30 individuals with a history of stroke and to randomly allocate them to receive nimodipine or a placebo for 3 months. After the first 3-month treatment with nimodipine or placebo, participants will be given the option to continue receiving nimodipine for an additional 3 months, and those who choose to do so will be given nimodipine. Detailed Description
-----------------
The aim of the proposed study is to evaluate the anti-inflammatory effects of nimodipine in stroke patients with recent stroke history. The investigators plan to recruit 30 individuals with a history of stroke and to randomly allocate them to receive nimodipine or a placebo for 3 months. After the first 3-month treatment with nimodipine or placebo, participants will be given the option to continue receiving nimodipine for an additional 3 months, and those who choose to do so will be given nimodipine. By evaluating oxidative stress, inflammation, and brain function, the study will investigate the effects of nimodipine on the brain and blood of participants. Nimodipine is a calcium channel blocker with anti-inflammatory and anti-oxidative stress-related properties that have been shown to improve cognitive function and quality of life in patients with stroke. Although there have been studies on its application in stroke treatment, there are no detailed evaluations of the anti-inflammatory effect of nimodipine in stroke patients with a history of recent stroke. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and tolerability of a single 240 mg dose of CXD-101 dosed once daily

Detailed Description
-----------------
Phase I is designed to evaluate the safety and tolerability of ascending doses of CXD-101 as well as conduct pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamics assessments. Treatment periods will extend up to 28 days in each dose level with an average of 19 days in a single treatment period for each participant. The screening visit includes a pharmacogenomic assessment of a participant's ability to metabolize CYP2C19 substrates and a urine drug screen. All participants will be admitted to the Clinical Research Unit (CRU) at the National Institutes of Health (NIH) for 28 days (up to 68 days in total for each dose escalation cohort). There are up to 20 participants in each dose escalation cohort across multiple doses. In the event that a dose is not tolerated, a safety run-in period will be implemented prior to escalating to the next dose. Dose escalation will occur following a decision based on the Data and Safety Monitoring Board (DSMB). The total dose exposure will be 240 mg per day of CXD-101.

An Open-label Study to Determine the Safety, Tolerability, and Pharmacokinetics of CXD-101 Dosed Once Daily in Healthy Subjects

Excellent. Based on the information you've provided, I suggest designing three study arms. The first arm will be Experimental: Ampli-01, 3 mg nicotine pouch. The second arm will be Experimental: Ampli-01, 6 mg nicotine pouch. And the third arm will be Active Comparator: ZYN Cool Mint Mini Dry, 6 mg nicotine/pouch. Each arm will involve a single 30-minute use of the assigned product on three separate occasions. How does that sound?

Certainly! The first arm, Experimental: Ampli-01, 3 mg nicotine pouch, is designed to assess the effects of a lower dose nicotine pouch on daily users compared to higher dose options. It allows for comparison of different nicotine strengths and their impact on pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and subjective effects. The second arm, Experimental: Ampli-01, 6 mg nicotine pouch, is essential to evaluate the effects of a higher dose nicotine pouch on daily users. By comparing the 6 mg pouch to the 3 mg pouch and a comparator product, researchers can determine the differences in outcomes between varying nicotine strengths. The third arm, Active Comparator: ZYN Cool Mint Mini Dry, 6 mg nicotine/pouch, serves as a reference point for comparison with the experimental arms. By including a well-established nicotine pouch product with a similar nicotine strength, researchers can assess the performance of the test products in relation to an existing standard. This arm helps to validate the study results and provide context for the findings.

METHODS
General
Background and objectives
Coccydynia is a pain condition commonly affecting adults that occurs above the area of the sacroiliac joint, due to coccygeal trauma, childbirth, or other risk factors 1. Coccydynia can be related to the levator ani muscle . This muscle is connected to the coccyx which may induce or worsen coccydynia and pelvic area pressure. The levator ani muscle could be hypertonic in patients with coccydynia, leading to further stiffness and pain . The levator ani muscle is part of the pelvic floor, and thus, treatments that address this region could be effective.
Finding an appropriate treatment for coccydynia is challenging, and several treatments have yielded mixed or inconclusive results in studies 2, 3, 4, 5. Among these treatments, the physical therapy modalities of manual therapy, pelvic floor muscle training, heat therapy, and core stability and strength training show promising short-term results for chronic coccydynia.
In a systematic review of 23 randomized clinical trials conducted from 2000 to 2020, manual therapy was found to be as effective as standard care treatment in managing non-neurogenic coccydynia . In addition, the addition of spinal manipulative therapy to core stability and plyometric exercises was effective in improving pain, range of motion, disability, and quality of life 9.
Another systematic review of physical therapy interventions for coccydynia included 24 studies published between 2

# Protocol for a Phase II Single-Arm, Open-Label, Single-Center, Exploratory Study Evaluating the Safety and Efficacy of JL952 in Patients With Atopic Dermatitis

Abstract:
Atopic dermatitis (AD) is chronic and is recognized as a relapsing‐remitting skin disease. There are currently no treatments targeting the underlying pathophysiological mechanism of AD, and immunosuppressants are generally prescribed to treat the symptoms. Therefore, there is a clear unmet medical need for more effective and safer interventions that can achieve a durable remission. JL952 is a humanized monoclonal antibody that specifically blocks the function of IL‐6, which contributes to the pathophysiology of AD. This study aims to assess the efficacy and safety of JL952 in improving the signs and symptoms of moderate to severe AD in adult patients who are eligible for systemic treatment. A total of 15 patients diagnosed with moderate to severe AD will be enrolled and receive JL952 80mg intravenously for 44 weeks. In this open‐label, single‐arm, exploratory clinical trial, the primary endpoint is the proportion of patients who achieve Investigator's Global Assessment (IGA) score of 0 or 1 with the Skin Clearing Index (SCI) ≥75 at Week 24. Secondary efficacy endpoints include the proportion of patients achieving IGA score of 0 or 1 with SCI ≥75 and SCI ≥90, the changes in eczema area and severity index (EASI), and the proportion of patients achieving success in Investigator's Global Assessment (IGA) and Skin Clearing Index ≥ 0.5 from baseline. The safety assessments will include adverse events (AEs), laboratory tests, vital signs, physical examinations, electrocardiograms, and immunogenicity assessments. Our study aims to investigate the efficacy and safety of JL952 in adult patients with moderate to severe AD. This study will help to evaluate whether JL

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The objective of this study is to test the efficacy & feasibility of a 12 week group based exercise intervention program in a multi-centre randomised controlled trial for patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) referred for surgical intervention. The study is a multi-centre parallel group two treatment comparator trial of a 12 week exercise intervention versus usual care in patients referred for in-patient surgical management of PAD.

Detailed Description
-----------------
A total of 360 patients will be enrolled in a two treatment comparator study using a nested randomized controlled trial design. The primary endpoint (change from baseline in treadmill exercise duration) will be assessed after 12 weeks of intervention in patients with peripheral artery stenosis referred to hospital for surgical intervention. The intervention will be a group based exercise program developed by a multidisciplinary core group, including exercise physiologists and cardiovascular surgeons. The exercise program will include aerobic, resistance and balance exercises to address deficits identified using the Cardiorespiratory Physical Fitness Scoring Criteria. The Cardiorespiratory Physical Fitness Scoring Criteria, which incorporates both aerobic and muscular fitness domains, is a validated scoring system for exercise capacity. Patients will be referred by a cardiologist or cardiovascular surgeon, and enrollment will occur at two study centres. The primary hypothesis, which will be examined in an exploratory manner, is that the 12 week group based exercise intervention will significantly improve exercise capacity as measured by treadmill exercise duration, than standard care. In addition the secondary outcomes of disease specific patient-reported quality of life, generic quality of life, self-efficacy for exercise and depression will be assessed. The impact on physical activity, health economic and cost effectiveness data will also be examined. The exercise program will be conducted at each study centre. The duration of the program will be 12 weeks, consisting of one supervised class per week (of one hour duration). Follow-up outcomes will be assessed at baseline (T1) and 12 weeks (T3) of intervention. In addition, health economic data will be obtained using validated health economic

Intervention Description:: As described in the protocol, it is a pilot study to develop and verify a clinical process of CoMBI-SMI (an intervention to identify factors specific to behavioral problems and provide behavioral interventions based on each patient's cognitive representation by cognitive model). The following six procedures are followed in the clinical process.
1) Conceptualization process: Identify factors specific to behavioral problems.
2) Coding process: Classify the factors identified in the conceptualization process into three types of cognitive models (beliefs, goals, and motivation) and formulate cognitive models.
3) Identification process: Identify cognitive models that explain the patient's current behavior, and identify the cognitive model most in need of modification to enable behavioral change.
4) Projection process: Formulate a behavioral plan that aims to modify patients’ cognitions based on the identified cognitive models.
5) Real-time modeling process: Use the cognitive models to understand the behaviors of patients in real time, and use them to intervene by providing behavioral guidance to the patients.
6) Follow-up and evaluation of the intervention's effectiveness: Check whether the intervention was successful by conducting an interview and using an assessment scale.

Abstract:
Introduction: To determine whether preoperative three‐dimensional (3D) printing of distal radius fractures has positive effects on the quality of fracture reduction and improves operative efficiency. Methods: Four hundred patients with acute distal radius fracture were included. One hundred of the patients were randomly assigned to the 3D printed model group and 300 to the control group. We compared radiological and clinical efficacy between the two groups for 6 months. Results: Seventy‐nine of the 100 patients in the 3D printed model group received high quality fracture reduction in the initial operation. The primary operation rate was 99% (69/70). Only 36 patients in the control group received high quality fracture reduction in the first operation, which was statistically significant [63.2% vs. 23.2% (control vs. 3D printed model), χ2 = 17.722, P = 0.000, RR = 1.882, 95% CI = 1.305 to 2.728]. The length of surgery was longer in the 3D printed model group [61.18 ± 14.80 (min) vs. 75.38 ± 25.15 (min), t = −3.505, P = 0.000, d = 0.598]. Conclusions: Preoperative 3D printed models are helpful for the quality of fracture reduction. However, they increase the duration of surgery. Randomized controlled trials with larger case series and longer follow‐up intervals are warranted to validate the accuracy of 3D‐simulated distal radius reduction and fractures in complex cases.

Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
In this randomized controlled trial, we want to evaluate whether 3D printed models can improve the quality of fracture reduction, which is associated with a better clinical outcome. We will compare the outcomes of distal intra articular radius fracture's reduction between two groups in patients: those who undergo open reduction and internal fixation without a 3D model (control group) versus who undergo open reduction and internal fixation with a 3D model (study group).

Detailed Description
-----------------
We will enroll patients from one hospital and one orthopedic clinic. Both institutions use the same surgical approach for treating distal intra-articular radius fracture (OVH - open volar hour glass) and similar implants (distal radius plate, LCP for Ligacon plate). After meeting all the inclusion and exclusion criteria, the participants (n = 100) will be randomized in 4 blocks (n = 25 per block) into two groups: control group and study group. The patients in the study group will undergo preoperative planning with the 3D model and open reduction and internal fixation with a 3D model. The patients in the control group will undergo open reduction and internal fixation without a 3D model. We will assess the outcomes of fracture reduction in the two groups using the postoperative CAT-scans. We will use quantitative parameters (radius ulnar length discrepancy and lateral tilt) to evaluate the fracture reduction. The participants will be followed postoperatively in an outpatient clinic at four months for clinical and radiological assessment and for a questionnaire about the satisfaction with the surgical result.

Official Title
-----------------
Effects of 3D Printing and Planning on the Quality of Fracture Reduction in Patients With Acute Distal Radius Fractures - A Randomized Controlled Trial

Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the safety, tolerability, and preliminary efficacy of submacular yttrium aluminum garnet laser photocoagulation (SMYAG) for the treatment of minimally classic and retinal pigment epithelial‐lifting neovascularization during the stabilization phase after photodynamic therapy (PDT) in patients with age‐related macular degeneration (AMD).DESIGN: Two prospective phase 2 trials were performed. The first was a randomized controlled trial to compare laser photocoagulation (SP) to a combination of SMYAG plus PDT and to SMYAG without PDT. Twenty‐four patients were randomized to 1 of 3 treatment groups: SP alone (n = 9), SMYAG without PDT (n = 6), and SMYAG with PDT (n = 9). The second study evaluated SMYAG treatment for eyes with neovascular AMD secondary to retinal pigment epithelial and choroidal atrophy. Nine patients received SMYAG laser treatment followed by PDT.MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: The primary study outcome included best‐corrected visual acuity (BCVA), lesion closure, PDT dose delivered, and adverse events.RESULTS: Lesion closure was greater with SMYAG+PDT (79%) compared to SP alone (39%) or SMYAG without PDT (28%) (P < .05). There was no significant difference in BCVA gains among the study groups. There was no relationship between the PDT dose delivered and either lesion closure or BCVA change. There were no serious complications related to these trials.CONCLUSIONS: SMYAG+PDT improved complete lesion closure with minimal morbidity in eyes with minimally classic and retinal pigment epithelial‐lifting neovascularization AMD. The mechanism for the effect of SMYAG could involve choricapillaris destruction that subsequently alters the local and systemic vascular response to PDT.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The project aims at determining the role of the interplay between genetics and environment in shaping the effects of caffeine on sleepiness, fatigue, mood, executive functions and perceived well-being in healthy adults.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is an intervention design clinical trial with healthy participants. The study lasts 9 days, with two experimental visits (one on Day 5, the other one on Day 7). In each visit participants will complete two experimental sessions - one at 8:45 a.m. and one at 4:30 p.m., at the Cerebra Laboratory at UCC, with two interventions (caffeine 6 mg/kg and placebo), each one on different days. These interventions will be randomized, controlled, double-blind and cross-over between them. All participants will be given 6 mg/kg of caffeine in the morning session on one of the visits (0.6 mg caffeine/kg from Day 1 to Day 15 and 1.2 mg caffeine/kg from Day 16 to Day 20 of each 35-day cycle) and 6 mg/kg of placebo (0 caffeine) in the morning session of the other visit. Morning testing is preceded by an overnight fast (water only from midnight onwards) and completed over the course of approximately 14 hours by about 4 p.m. On the 7th day participants will go to the laboratory again to complete another two experimental sessions, with the intervention order switched.

Official Title

The Interplay Between Genetics, Stress, and Sleepiness: Moderating Effects of Caffeine on Cognitive and Mood Functions

Certainly! Here are the detailed interventions/treatments for each study arm:

1. Experimental: Para-Sartorial Compartment (PACS) Block + Femoral Triangle Block (FTB) + IPACK block
- Procedure: Para-Sartorial Compartments (PACS) Block
  - This intervention was selected because it has the potential to optimize analgesia by skin coverage of the upper third of the surgical incision. The intervention will be performed as follows:
    - The intermediate femoral cutaneous nerve will be visualized at the supralateral level of the sartorius muscle, in a duplicature of the fascia lata.
    - The needle will be inserted at the same puncture site as for the femoral triangle block, with a latero-medial orientation in the plane (intracanalar compartment).
    - In addition to the injection performed in the femoral triangle, two injections of 5 mL of 0.5% ropivacaine + epi 1:400 000 will be performed in addition, below the sartorius muscle (subsartorial compartment) and above the sartorius muscle (suprasartorial compartment).
- Procedure: Femoral Triangle Block (FTB)
  - The high frequency linear ultrasound probe will be positioned midway between the superior edge of the patella and the anterosuperior iliac spine. It will then be moved to visualize the apex of the femoral triangle, confirmed by visualization of the sartorius muscle laterally and the long adductor medially.
  - The needle will be inserted with a latero-medial orientation in the plane.
  - The initial injection will be a single injection of 15 ml of 0.5% ropivacaine + epi 1:400 000 under the sartorius muscle, lateral to the femoral artery, at the level of the apex of the femoral triangle.
- Procedure: Infiltration between popliteal artery and capsule of the knee (IPACK) block
  - It will be performed in order to block the sensory branches of the innervation posterior to the knee with 15 ml of ropivacaine 0.3% + epi 1:400 000.

Abstract:
The purpose of this study was to investigate the safety and efficacy of a single or combined administration of low doses of ozone therapy in adult patients diagnosed as having systemic sclerosis. A randomized, double‐blind and placebo‐controlled trial was conducted. Patients were randomly assigned to either ozone therapy, low‐dose interferon or placebo. Each treatment was applied once weekly for three weeks. Seventeen patients completed the study, ten patients in each group. No severe side effects occurred, except two episodes of mild fatigue in the ozone therapy group. The clinical improvement was assessed using a blinded modified Rodnan score. No differences in the time course of improvement between the groups were observed. In conclusion, a single dose of 300 mg of ozone had no efficacy in the treatment of systemic sclerosis, and should not be used at this dose level. This treatment was well tolerated without many side effects.[Corrected]

Study design

Study type
=================
Observational non-interventional

Description
=================
This will be an observational case-controlled study involving healthy subjects and patients with PTB. The healthy subjects are included in order to observe a reference population when evaluating the efficacy of therapy with moxifloxacin in PTB patients. The patients with PTB are those who were already being treated at the Centro Español de Tuberculosis (CET) in Madrid, Spain. The study design is noninterventional to avoid unnecessary risk exposure, and thus a randomized, sham controlled, double-blind study was not performed. Therefore, patients diagnosed with PTB were treated with standard therapy, i.e., combination treatment, according to the National and Clinical Guidelines for treatment of PTB (National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence, London, UK, 2008 & updated), and the WHO-endorsed Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP) guidelines, 2017 edition (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention). The criteria for enrollment of the healthy subjects included normal and regular chest x-ray and a negative QuantiFERON-TB Gold in Tube test. The criteria for PTB enrollment included either sputum conversion in a month or three (if sputum was initially negative), or the presence of at least smear positive microscopy test results. Subjects who presented with MDR-TB or XDR-TB were excluded from the study. Healthy subjects received no medications for the duration of the study, while patients already diagnosed with PTB were given the treatment as indicated by the RNTCP. Patients diagnosed with PTB upon completing therapy with at least 3 months after the start of the therapy showed a chest x-ray and an ex vivo QuantiFERON-TB Gold in Tube test at least 2 months off of any anti-tuberculosis therapy since completing the standard therapy with follow-up for at least 1 year.

Study information
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
In 2007, a total of 95 children, aged 5 months - five years, were included in a multicenter non-randomized trial comparing oral and topical azithromycin administration for the treatment of non-purulent otitis media (Cochane Database of Systematic Reviews). This study demonstrated that azithromycin alone was not inferior to amoxicillin/clavulanic acid for the resolution of pain and the resolution of middle ear fluid. A total of 89 children were included in a non-randomized study using topical azithromycin monotherapy to treat non-purulent acute otitis media (COCHRANE). This study confirmed effectiveness of this monotherapy for efficacy in children for a period of 12 days or at the end of the treatment period. The study took place in France over a period of 1 year.

Observational study in 200 children aged 5 months to 5 years of age, non-affiliated with the social security system without medical insurance, and consulting for an acute non-purulent otitis media in the two participating centers: Marseille and Montpellier

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of the present study is to evaluate the use of recombinant alpha interferon (rIFN) combined with 9-17 days of imatinib (Gleevec) as an adjuvant chemotherapy after total mesorectal excision (TME) in colon cancer. All patients who were scheduled for TME and met the eligibility criteria were included. Eligibility criteria were as follows: histological confirmed adenocarcinoma of the colon. This study was conducted between February 2013 and April 2016 at Mie University Chiba Hospital. Patients received three months of treatment with rIFN at a dose of 250,000 KU/ml intravenously, and imatinib to the same dose for 9 to 17 days after surgery. The primary endpoint of this study was recurrence free survival.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The aim of the present study was to evaluate the use of the combination therapy of recombinant alpha interferon (rIFN) and 9 - 17 days of imatinib (Gleevec) as an adjuvant chemotherapy after total mesorectal excision (TME) in colon cancer. All patients who were scheduled for TME and met the eligibility criteria were included. Eligibility criteria were as follows: histological confirmed adenocarcinoma of the colon without metastasis or synchronous multiple primary cancer. Patients received three months of treatment with rIFN at a dose of 250,000 KU/ml intravenously, and imatinib to the same dose for 9 to 17 days after surgery. This study was conducted between February 2013 and April 2016 at Mie University Chiba Hospital. The primary endpoint of this study was recurrence free survival.

The study aimed to investigate the frequency of postoperative fever in cardiac surgery patients and examine the relationship between body temperature curves and the development of postoperative cardiac complications.

Brief summary
=================
There are no clear-cut guidelines for measuring body temperature in postoperative patients in the medical community, which means there is a lot of room for improvement. Two common practices include continuous temperature monitoring and single daily temperature measurements. Continuous temperature monitoring may hold some benefits in earlier detection of infections, but the evidence for this claim is mixed. Single daily temperature measurements are a relatively inexpensive and easy-to-use method that remains popular among many medical professionals.The purpose of this study is to measure the diagnostic accuracy of continuous temperature monitoring using the Steadytemp® devices. We aim to compare the performance of continuous temperature monitoring to standard daily temperature measurements in patients with major abdominal surgeries.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The purpose of this study is to assess the bioequivalence of single subcutaneous injection of Dupilumab (SAR231893) in relation to a reference Dupilumab product. METHODS: This is a randomized, single‐dose, double‐blind, two‐period, parallel‐group, two‐sequence, two‐way crossover study. Eligible healthy volunteers would be enrolled in this study in the United States. Participants will receive a single subcutaneous injection of 450 mg Dupilumab (SAR231893) in Period 1 and a single subcutaneous injection of 450 mg Dupilumab in Period 2, stratified by sequence in each arm. In the first period study arm, all 125 participants will receive 450 mg dupilumab (SAR231893) subcutaneously. In the second period study arm, all 125 participants will receive two single doses of dupilumab, in two injections separated by a 7‐day interval. The study is designed to determine bioequivalence between product A and product B in the 292‐hour PK parameters. 125 participants were planned to complete two periods in this study. All study participants will receive 14 days of a washout period after each single subcutaneous injection in period 1 and period 2.

Background
=================
Aims
-----------------
To evaluate the effect of neoadjuvant therapy with Oxaliplatin,Capecitabine and Serplulimab(PD-1 inhibitor) with short course radiotherapy in downstaging the locally advanced rectum cancer.

Design
=================
Intervention
-----------------
The intervention group will receive Oxaliplatin and Capecitabine. In the chemotherapy block, the Oxaliplatin will be injected weekly at a dose of 100mg/m2 intravenously for 6 weeks. The Capecitabine will be given orally on a dosage of 1250 mg/m2 twice daily for 3 weeks. Serplulimab 240mg will be administered intravenously at day one of each cycle and for 3 weeks. During the radiotherapy block, the radiation dose will be 25 Gy in 5 fractions on days 4 to 8, followed by Oxaliplatin 100 mg/m2 intravenous injection and Capecitabine 1000mg/m2 twice daily on day 1 to 14. The total radiation dose will be 50.4 Gy divided into 25.2 Gy/16 fractions. Following the radiation, the radiation block repeated once after 2 weeks with the same regimen. After the completion of neoadjuvant treatment, the patients will undergo surgical resection of the rectum cancer, and the pathological efficacy after surgery will be evaluated.

Study Overview
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
Bioresorbable polymer scaffolds and drug-eluting balloon (DEB) can be used for the treatment of in-stent restenosis lesions. In this single-center (Zhejiang Provincial People's Hospital) randomized trial, a total of 112 patients who needed DES implantation for in-stent restenosis were randomized at a 1:1 ratio to undergo a Bioresorbable scaffold implantation or a DES plus DEB (a total of 48 patients in each group). Procedures were monitored and reported by experienced operators, and the results were compared and analyzed to determine whether the two strategies differed in terms of technical success, in-stent late lumen loss, rate of in-stent restenosis and target lesion failure (TLF, i.e. death, myocardial infarction, clinically driven target revascularization) during the follow-up period.

Detailed Description
-----------------
In-stent restenosis is the main cause of re-intervention in the stented segment after PCI, with a high incidence rate. Drug-eluting, biocompatible polymer stents were introduced as the current stent treatment standard for coronary atherosclerotic lesions in 2006. But with the improvement of long-term follow-up outcomes in recent years, stent thrombosis still brings a risk of mortality, and restenosis still occurs in the stented segment in some patients, which eventually leads to the need for re-intervention at a high risk. There are many methods that could lead to improved results. The use of new scaffolds made of biodegradable polymers seems to be a good option, the drug is released directly to the stent segment in a controlled manner in a short time period. DEB in the stented segment may also cause neointimal disruption in part. The current study investigates whether the biological scaffold or drug-eluting stent can achieve better treatment results in the treatment of in-stent restenosis lesions.

-----------------
This is a multi-center international prospective, randomized, open-labeled, controlled study that is designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a 6-month single intra-articular injection of hyaluronic acid and PRP in patients with unilateral osteoarthritis of the hip or knee joint.

E.9.1.1 Title of the trial for lay people, in easily understood, i.e. non-technical, language: Validation Study of a Peri-intervention Diabetes Management Algorithm (DIAPI) for Endos

The standard approach for peri-intervention diabetes management is the "usual care" approach, which is to adjust patients' diabetes medications as necessary before their procedure. Since diabetes management often involves changes to medication and care, it is important to compare the DIAPI approach to the "usual care" approach in a naturalistic setting.

In the "Experimental: DIAPI" arm, patients will go through the DIAPI algorithm, which is a peri-intervention diabetes management algorithm for patients with type 2 diabetes. The algorithm recommends changes to preprocedural and postprocedural medication and diet plans. The reasoning behind this design is to evaluate the effectiveness of the DIAPI algorithm in managing peri-intervention diabetes and reducing peri-intervention complications.

Certainly. In the "Active Comparator: Usual Care" arm, patients will receive usual care for their diabetes during their peri-procedural period. This means they will follow the treating-physician's recommendations instead of using the DIAPI algorithm. The reasoning behind this arm is to have a control group for comparison. By comparing the outcomes of patients receiving usual care to those receiving care based on the DIAPI algorithm, we can determine the efficacy and safety of DIAPI in managing peri-intervention diabetes.

Of course. In the "Experimental: DIAPI" arm, patients will receive the care for their diabetes recommended by the DIAPI algorithm during their peri-procedural period. This means they will follow the orders generated by DIAPI. The reasoning behind this arm is to test the effectiveness and safety of the DIAPI algorithm in managing peri-intervention diabetes. By implementing DIAPI's orders, we can evaluate whether the algorithm provides optimal and personalized treatment that leads to better outcomes compared to usual care. This arm will help determine if DIAPI can simplify the complex task of peri-intervention diabetes management while ensuring patient safety.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a prospective, randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled trial of Gelofusin, intravenously administered, in the treatment of patients with severe acute pancreatitis due to ischemia or alcoholic etiology.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Patients with AP with severe multiorgan failure were enrolled in the study as soon as they were diagnosed with AP. Gelofusin (20mg/Kg) was administered intravenously over 1.5hr for all the patients in the study. All the patients received standard support in an intensive care unit. The patients were then assessed with regards to clinical findings, organ system dysfunction and severity scores at baseline and at 24 hours, 48 hours, 72 hours and 14 day of follow up, after baseline assessment. These assessment were done by a separate intensivist, who was blinded to the treatment groups, at each visit. A single patient assessment visit was also permitted by telephone in case of transfer of the patient to a different hospital unit. During the first 33 patients, the trial was done in a double blind manner. Gelofusin was diluted in 1 litre of 5% glucose while placebo, consisting of 1 litre of 5% glucose alone, was prepared. An unblinded nurse, who only performed the interventions, was the only person, who knew the contents of the infusion bottles. All data in the interim part of this trial were analyzed without unblinding the results.

Official Title
-----------------
A Multicentric, Double Blind, Randomized, Placebo-Controlled Trial of Gelofusin in the Treatment of Patients With Severe Acute Pancreatitis Due to Ischemia or Alcoholic Etiology

The deficit can be caused by a lesion in the somatosensory and motor cortex. There is no effective conventional therapy for this deficit. To solve these problems, in this study the investigators will try to determine the effect of a protein supplement called gelofusine in these stroke patients.

However, the changes in CK levels during BE progression to esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) are unclear.METHODS: In this study, we performed a nested case‐control study with a matched‐pair design based on a prospective cohort study that recorded the longitudinal follow‐up of patients with BE. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The objective of the present study is to examine whether a pharmacist-led multifaceted intervention to promote health and prevent medication related problems in nursing homes reduces morbidity and mortality in residents of nursing homes.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Aim and objectives The aim of this study is to examine whether a pharmacist-led multifaceted intervention including pharmaceutical and lifestyle counselling reduces morbidity and mortality in residents of nursing homes. Secondary aims are to assess the effectiveness and cost effectiveness of a pharmacist-led intervention on resident functioning, depression, quality of life, and medication use. Design This research is a prospective, controlled, randomized, study with pre and post intervention measurements. At baseline, residents at the control nursing homes will be assessed on their general health and function. Thereafter they will receive the intervention that consists of 2-3 multidisciplinary meetings and 6 home visits by a trained pharmacist over a 26-week period. After 26 weeks, resident general health and function will be reassessed to determine the difference. The main study parameters are the prevalence of depression, depression score, Quality of Life (QoL), use of and number of prescribed medicines and the prevalence of possible and definitely inappropriate medicines at baseline and at 26 weeks. Patients and methods This is a prospective, controlled, randomized, open trial. Two hundred residents in sixteen nursing homes (31 residents per nursing home) will be included. Nursing homes will be pair matched and randomly assigned to the intervention group (the control group has the opportunity to implement the intervention after 26 weeks). The intervention consists of 2-3 meetings of the nursing home team with the pharmacist and six home visits by the pharmacist over a six-month period. The primary endpoint is the difference in the number of hospital admissions between participants at intervention and control nursing homes. Secondary outcomes are the general health status (WHOQOL-BREF), functional abilities (Barthel Index), depression (Geriatric Depression Scale) and quality of life (Quality of Life Questionnaires, Dartmouth

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This 8 week, double-blind, randomized placebo-controlled trial will assess the efficacy and safety of dexibuprofen/aspirin in adult patients with acute pain after bunionectomy. This clinical study will evaluate the efficacy of the study drug in terms of pain and inflammation by analyzing the degree of pain and inflammation during movement and 1-hour post-movement. The study will also evaluate whether using the study drug can relieve the pain caused by the bunion operation of the participants in an effective and safe manner.

Detailed Description
-----------------
When performing a clinical study on patients with bunion surgery pain, most experts use the visual analogue scale (VAS) or questionnaires for pain assessment. In this study, we will assess the efficacy and safety of dexibuprofen/aspirin in adult patients with moderate to severe acute pain after bunion surgery by analyzing the changes in the degree of pain and inflammation during movement, post-movement, and total daily movement, assessed using the VAS questionnaire. The study drug tablets are single-dose 200mg/25mg enteric-coated tablets of 6 drugs. Patients who meet the selection criteria are randomly assigned to the two groups in a 1:1 ratio. A VAS or questionnaire on pain and inflammation are performed on the patients in both groups, but the group assigned to the active drug group receives the drug (dexibuprofen and aspirin), and the placebo group receives a placebo of the study drug.

Official Title
-----------------
A 4-week Double Blind Randomized Placebo Controlled Study on the Management of Postoperative Pain After Foot Bunion Surgery With Dexibuprofen/Aspirin

Chronic Pain, Pain

Intervention / Treatment

* Drug: Dexibuprofen/aspirin

Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Objective: To evaluate the effect of PET-CT imaging and pathological examination on the differential diagnosis of Knee joint osteoarthritis after injury and inflammation. Methods: The study included 92 patients with knee joint trauma. Sixty-four of them underwent PET-CT, and 28 of them were not scanned by PET-CT for other reasons, using the KL-6 and WOMAC pain score to evaluate the effect of PET-CT examination on the diagnosis of knee joint pathology and treatment decision-making.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Background: Knee joint inflammation and trauma are common problems in orthopedic wards, and the accurate distinction and classification of knee joint trauma and inflammation are conducive to the formulation of reasonable treatment plans and achieve good prognosis. However, there are still many shortcomings in imaging examination. PET-CT imaging can realize effective imaging and functional imaging of the body at the same time, so the application value of PET-CT in the differential diagnosis and treatment of knee joint inflammation and trauma is very high. Objective: To evaluate the ability of PET-CT examination to evaluate the bone marrow of knee joint trauma and inflammation, combined with clinical and laboratory indexes to detect the degree of bone damage and evaluate the efficacy of anti-inflammatory and analgesic drugs. Methods: From November 2016 to October 2018, 64 patients diagnosed with knee joint trauma were randomly divided into two groups, and the control group was scanned by PET-CT. The treatment effects were evaluated by the KL-6 and WOMAC pain scoring method.

Official Title
-----------------
Application of PET-CT in the Diagnosis and Treatment of Osteoarthritis After Knee Trauma and Injury

Conditions

Knee Joint Inflammation and Trauma

* Diagnostic Test: PET-CT examination

Abstract:
PURPOSE: Few clinical studies have investigated the effect of physical activity on knee osteoarthritis (OA). This study aims to evaluate the effects of exercise prescription on knee OA patients and compare it to existing exercise programs. METHOD: This study is a prospective cohort study involving knee OA patients. In this study, 30 patients (15 men and 15 women) will be randomly assigned to the following two groups: the study group (15 men and 15 women) will receive physical activity with an exercise program developed on the basis of previous rehabilitation studies, and the control group (15 men and 15 women) will receive the standard physical activity program recommended for adults. An exercise instructor will conduct 12 weekly exercise sessions with each participant in the study group. The subjects in the control group will participate in community‐based physical activities and receive the recommended home exercise program. The outcomes were measured at baseline and at 12 weeks. RESULTS: In the study group, significant improvements in the visual analog scale (VAS) and Functional Index Score (FIS) were found after 12 weeks. However, no significant improvement was observed in the control group. CONCLUSION: This study showed that physical activity with an exercise program based on previous rehabilitation studies could be beneficial for knee OA patient. Further studies evaluating the effect of customized exercise program in knee OA patients are warranted.
