Intervention Description:: This study will use a combination of pain medications and psychological treatments to help manage chronic pain. The study will use three different pain medications for pain management: pregabalin, tramadol, and morphine. Pregabalin is a medication that works by blocking certain chemicals that are responsible for transmitting pain signals in the brain. It may be effective in treating neuropathic pain, which is pain that is caused by nerve damage. This is the most commonly used drug for neuropathic pain that will be used in this study. Tramadol is a medication that is similar in structure and function to morphine, acting on the same pain receptors in the brain and spinal cord. It is also effective in treating moderate to severe pain, but it has less potential for abuse and addiction than morphine. Morphine is a natural Opioid, which is derived from the poppy plant. It works by attaching to the same pain receptors in the brain and spinal cord as endorphins, which are the body's natural pain killers. This makes it a potent and effective pain reliever, but it also has a high potential for abuse and addiction. In this study, we will compare the effectiveness of these three medications in reducing pain and improving function for patients suffering from chronic pain.

PURPOSE: This study aimed to investigate the associations of the modified Diet in Renal Disease equation and clinical parameters with estimated glomerular filtration rate measured by 99mTc‐MAG3 clearance in chronic hemodialysis patients. MATERIALS AND METHODS: This study included patients receiving chronic hemodialysis at our hospital between January 2020 and January 2022. The association between the modified Diet in Renal Disease equation and calculated glomerular filtration rate, measured glomerular filtration rate, and clinical parameters were analyzed, and the accuracy of the modified Diet in Renal Disease equation and calculated glomerular filtration rate at predicting measured glomerular filtration rate was compared. RESULTS: A total of 175 subjects were included in this study. The sensitivity and specificity of the modified Diet in Renal Disease equation and calculated glomerular filtration rate at predicting measured glomerular filtration rate were 61.4% and 89.3%, respectively. The sensitivity and specificity of the modified Diet in Renal Disease equation at predicting measured glomerular filtration rate of 6.6 mL/min/1.73m2 or lower was 75.0% and 86.8%, respectively. Background
=================
The Fibrodysplasia Ossificans Progressiva (FOP) Registry has been collecting patient data since 1995 and has been widely recognized as a comprehensive database of FOP with rigorous collection methods.  Previous studies based on FOP registry have demonstrated that it is a viable source of data for longitudinal data research; these studies provided invaluable information about the natural history of the disease and outcomes of treatments.  HealthVerity Marketplace provides a single-source solution for integrated, longitudinal data across electronic medical records (EMRs) and claims data sources, and its FOP cohort represents one of the largest cohorts of the FOP Registry to date. The availability of these databases presents an opportunity to conduct a unique retrospective non-interventional study to further our understanding of the disease and its outcomes.  The study will help address the lack of understanding of the natural history of the disease and outcomes of treatments, which are key factors in developing effective strategies for managing and treating FOP.  The proposed work is expected to create an unprecedented dataset that will enable high-quality analyses to address critical questions about the natural history of FOP and outcomes of treatment.  It will also serve as a valuable resource for future studies, and may potentially lead to improved outcomes and quality of life for patients with FOP. The endpoints of the trial are the occurrence of disease exacerbations, the occurrence of asthma attacks, and lung function test results. Asthma exacerbations are events in which worsening signs or symptoms such as attacks, coughing, wheezing, chest tightness, and dyspnea occur. Asthma attacks are events in which those symptoms are especially bad. The lung function test results are taken using a peak flow meter. A peak flow meter is a device used to measure the maximum amount of air that can be blown out in one second. Using the results of these tests, we can decide whether you are taking part in the study as intended.

This is an investigator led open label study to assess the effects and safety of different concentrations of DA-OTC-002 on the scalp in subjects with hair loss. 2.1 Primary objective The primary objective of the study is to assess the effects and safety of different concentrations of DA-OTC-002 (topical) formulations to investigate the hair loss. 2.2 Secondary objectives The secondary objective of the study is to evaluate the effects and safety of DA-OTC-002 by assessing other measurements (i.e., clinical, phototopic). 3.1 Background and rationale The reason we want to conduct this study is that this is a pilot study to further characterize and assess the safety of DA-OTC-002 applied topically to the scalp. We want to develop and test a treatment for age-related hair loss. 3.1.1 Background Aging is associated with physiological changes and decreased hair thickness, density, elasticity, and pigmentation as well as an increase in hair follicle miniaturization in men and women. 3.1.1.1 Human hair growth The human hair cycle is divided into 3 main phases as anagen, catagen and telogen. It has been reported that the hair cycle is under the control of androgenic and sex hormones which trigger melanin production. Melanin production and hair regrowth are also influenced by a variety of vitamins. 3.1.2 Hair follicle miniaturization (HFM) and hair loss Hair loss in both men and women has three forms including male pattern baldness (MPB), female pattern hair loss (FPHL), and age related hair loss. Hair growth is an important aspect of how we present ourselves to the world; yet, 50 % of men and women experience hair loss at some point in their lives. Male pattern baldness (MPB) is a hormonal mediated phenomenon that affects all ethnicities and it is often the first sign of androgenetic alopecia. Androgenetic alopecia is characterized by a progressive decline in the number of follicles in the donor area along with an increase in hair loss. Male pattern baldness is diagnosed as Norwood-Hamilton (N-H) pattern

Objectives: Despite the frequent occurrence of ablation induced paresthesia of the upper extremity, the mechanism of this paresthesia has not been elucidated. This study aimed to clarify the mechanism of ablation induced paresthesia of the upper extremity. Methods and Results: The authors investigated the relationship between ablation induced paresthesia and various parameters related to ablation of the right ventricular outflow tract and epicardium. A total of 172 patients, who agreed to undergo radiofrequency ablation (107) and cryoballoon ablation (65), were divided into three groups (Group‐A, Group‐B, and Group‐C) and four subgroups (Subgroup‐A ‐ Group‐A, Subgroup‐B ‐ Group‐B, Subgroup‐C ‐ Group‐C and Subgroup‐D ‐ not applicable). Univariate logistic regression analysis was used to determine the factors that affected ablation‐induced paresthesia. A multivariate logistic regression analysis, adjusted for age, sex, and heart rate, was performed to identify the independent determinants of ablation‐induced paresthesia. Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curve analysis was performed to assess the diagnostic accuracy of each potential predictor of ablation‐induced paresthesia of the upper extremity. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Pancreatic cysts are one of the most frequent incidental findings on cross-sectional imaging studies. These cysts are observed in 8-10% of individuals undergoing abdominal imaging, but only 3-5% of these cysts are malignant. Although the majority of pancreatic cysts are benign, this finding is often difficult to assess initially, raising clinicians' suspicion and the need for unnecessary, invasive, costly, and potentially dangerous procedures such as endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration (EUS-FNA). Therefore, there is an unmet need for simple, noninvasive methods to make the diagnosis of pancreatic cysts. In patients with pancreatic cysts, plasma and cytological markers of pancreatic cyst malignancy are not available, and diagnostic imaging is expensive and invasive and does not detect early stage malignancies. This study aims to examine the clinical potential of a new blood-based protein-molecular assay to screen for and assess pancreatic cyst malignancy. If this study proves to be successful, it will have a significant impact on the management of patients with pancreatic cysts by providing an accurate and noninvasive method for early diagnosis and risk stratification. Additionally, it could potentially reduce the cost of care by eliminating unnecessary and potentially harmful procedures such as EUS-FNA.

Detailed Description
-----------------
A prospective study of patient plasma samples following EUS-FNA cyst fluid and biopsy samples (if available) from both malignant and nonmalignant pancreatic cysts will be conducted to demonstrate the ability of the proteomic assay to discriminate between malignant and nonmalignant pancreatic cysts. Plasma cytokines and miRNAs will be measured and analyzed to identify associations between the diagnostic assay and clinicopathological characteristics including the patient's age, gender, smoking history, BMI, previous history of pancreatitis or pancreatic cancer in the patient, the presence or absence

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The current standard for treatment of early stage, low grade endometrial cancer is surgical staging and surgical debulking. Approximately 20% of patients undergo surgery to debulk bulky or extensive disease and are not candidates for surgical staging or resection. We plan on enrolling 120 subjects into this pilot study. Subjects will undergo preoperative pelvic CT scan followed by 3D-conformal external beam radiation therapy (EBRT) to the pelvis. They will receive a total of 50 Gy in 25 fractions. If residual disease is found at the time of operative staging a hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy will be performed. Following completion of EBRT patients may have a bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and hysterectomy if this was not previously done to eliminate residual disease. Adjuvant pelvic radiation will be given to patients who have surgical staging and resection. Patients will undergo a follow up imaging study at the end of radiotherapy (CT or ultrasound) and 3 months following completion of radiation.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This pilot study will employ prospective data regarding overall response (CR/PR) and pathologic response (CR/GPR) in low grade endometrial cancer. The hypothesis for evaluating the efficacy of preoperative (neoadjuvant) radiation in this disease is feasible. This study is designed to study this novel approach using modern radiation techniques for treatment of endometrial cancer. If, as preliminary data suggests, the response to preoperative radiotherapy is high, the next step will be to design a randomized trial to demonstrate this therapeutic approach is effective. The main objective of our study is to collect information regarding the toxicity of preoperative radiation, the feasibility of this approach, and the pathologic response to pelvic radiation in low grade endometrial cancer. The clinical response to neoadjuvant radiation observed in the study will help provide an evidence-based estimate of the chance of a pathologic complete response (and decrease the associated operative morbidity)

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to explore the safety and tolerability to determine the Maximum Tolerated and/or Recommended Phase II Dose of CC-90007 in participants with relapsed and/or refractory leukemia.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This will be a multi-centre, open-label, phase I trial done at multiple centers in the USA, Europe and APAC region. CC-90007 will be administered in 3 week cycles and consists of a screening period followed by 1 cycle of lead-in at half the MTD / RP2D before the dose escalation phase. All participants will be treated for a minimum of 2 years or until documented progression or unacceptable toxicity. Dose escalation scheme of CC-90007 is via a 3+3 design. This is a safety and tolerability first study.

A Phase I/ II Study of the Safety and Efficacy of CC-90007, a Beta7 Specific, DARPin T-Cell Engagement Protein in Patients With Relapsed or Refractory T Cell and NK-cell Malignancies

Abstract:
Objectives: To determine the safety and efficacy of recombinant human granulocyte colony‐stimulating factor (rhG‐CSF) and oral iron in patients with cancer and neutropenia in a randomized double blind study using randomized assignment of patients to the same block size. Study Design: Forty of 90 patients were randomly assigned to rhG‐CSF or placebo, and the other 15 patients, previously enrolled, served as a control group, to avoid the time constraints and difficulty in locating veins in patients with neutropenia and hematologic malignancies. All patients in the control group did not receive rhG‐CSF or placebo and 15 patients in groups A and B received intravenously 2.5 microgram/kg/day granulocyte‐CSF (rhG‐CSF) for 5 days or placebo for ten days after a course of the chemotherapy, and 10 to 15 mg of oral iron, according to the patient's hematological status and clinical judgment. Results: There was a statistically significant difference between the control group and groups A, B, and C in the median number of granulocytes per liter before starting chemotherapy on day 10 compared to the median neutrophil count at the end of the second cycle. Group A had a median neutrophil count of 2,400 per liter (range 1,197‐4,663), while group C had a median neutrophil count of 2,224 per liter (range 1,264‐2,744). The median duration of antibiotic therapy and the frequency of antibiotic‐related side effects were similar between the groups, even though 40 percent of patients in group B developed iron toxicity, with no apparent difference in morbidity or mortality. Conclusions: Because of the promising results of the rhG‐CSF arm of the study, the use of rhG‐CSF in combination with oral iron as the standard preventive treatment of neutropenia in cancer patients is recommended.

2023-05-24
Introduction
Eradication of in-transit metastases (ITM) is becoming an important treatment strategy in treating patients with melanoma . It has been shown to improve overall and progression-free survival (OS, PFS) rates and can be performed with minimal morbidity to the patients . The most common treatment for ITM is surgical excision, but it can be challenging due to the disseminated nature of melanoma, making it difficult to resect every metastatic lesion. Moreover, surgery itself could lead to local recurrence, and systemic therapy would be the only option for patients. Therefore, other alternatives, such as radiation therapy, might be considered for non-surgical candidates or for patients who failed to surgical resection. However, the efficacy of stereotactic ablative radiotherapy (SABR) for the management of ITM remains unclear, and it has mostly been investigated in phase 1/2 trials. A prospective study on ITM management with interstitial brachytherapy (IB) reported that local control (LC) for ITM was 89% after IB alone and 92% after IB in combination with palliative external beam radiotherapy (EBRT) . A phase 2 study on SABR with a median dose of 19.5 Gy in 1 fraction for primary ITM demonstrated 12 month LC rates of 83%  and long-term PFS rates of 61%  suggesting that SABR could be an effective treatment for ITM patients, though it may be associated with some acute toxicities. As ITM is a relatively rare disease, many centers have not enough experience to determine the most appropriate fractionation and dosage to use in treatment. Therefore, it is necessary to explore and evaluate the optimal treatment strategy for ITM, including the number of fractions as well as its efficacy and tolerability of SABR using a conventional dose and fractionation regimen.

What do you think about this design?

Certainly. Adaptive SBRT is a precise radiation technique that allows for the safe delivery of ablative radiation doses. It utilizes diagnostic quality onboard imaging incorporated within radiation treatment machines. This technology enables the generation and delivery of radiation plans specific to the patient's anatomy at the time of treatment. The goal of this study is to utilize adaptive radiation therapy to deliver ablative radiation with low toxicity rates in a patient population with technically challenging disease.

Absolutely! Maximizing target coverage while maintaining a grade 3+ toxicity rate no greater than 10% is one of the key objectives of this trial. The inclusion of patients with technically challenging disease will allow us to evaluate the safety and efficacy of adaptive SBRT in this specific population. This arm will provide crucial information for future treatment strategies.

Absolutely. In Treatment plan I, patients will undergo leukapheresis to collect healthy T cells from their blood. These T cells will be engineered to produce a chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) that recognizes prostate stem cell antigen (PSCA). This will allow the T cells to find and attack the patient's cancer cells. Patients will also undergo lymphodepletion therapy with fludarabine and cyclophosphamide, which will help to clear the way for the CAR T cells to infiltrate the cancer. The patients will receive the infusion of the CAR T cells intravenously, followed by infusions every week for three weeks afterward. In Treatment plan II, patients will receive the same interventions as in Treatment plan I, but with the additional administration of radiation therapy. External beam radiation will be delivered during the first week of CAR T cell therapy and again during the second and third weeks of treatment. The radiation will target the patient's prostate if it is still present, and any metastatic sites that are identified on the scans. 2.1. Tissue acquisition

groundtruth:
Certainly! In Treatment plan I (PSCA CAR T-cells), patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer would undergo leukapheresis to collect their T cells. These T cells would then be modified in the laboratory to express the PSCA-specific CAR receptor. The modified T cells, known as PSCA-CAR T cells, would be infused into the patients intravenously up to 3 times during the study. Additionally, patients would undergo lymphodepletion therapy, bone scans, CT scans, tumor biopsies, and collection of blood, stool, and urine samples.

In Treatment plan II (PSCA CAR T-cells, radiation), patients would undergo the same interventions as in Treatment plan I, but with the addition of external beam radiation therapy. The radiation therapy would be administered in 2 doses and is intended to further target and destroy cancer cells. The rest of the procedures, including leukapheresis, lymphodepletion, imaging studies, and sample collection, would be the same as in Treatment plan I.

The absence of phlebitis and catheter-related bloodstream infections will be evaluated during follow-up visits at one week, one month, and one month after the procedure. The catheter will be deemed to be functional if it can be accessed at least 75% of the time and remains in place for a minimum of 30 days. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Background: Stroke is a disease caused by hemorrhage or narrowing of blood vessels, and is a major cause of death and disability worldwide. The prevalence of stroke has reached a critical juncture in Taiwan. Physical activity can improve health-related quality of life and prevent diseases, but there is a lack of a systematic study on the effects of physical activity on ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke patients. Purpose: This study aims to conduct a prospective cohort study, including outpatient and inpatient stroke patients. The purpose is to investigate the influence of physical activity on various physical and physiological indicators, including physical health, mental health, and neurological function. Methods: The subjects of this study were outpatient and inpatient stroke patients in Taipei City Hospital Daan Branch, and the inclusion criteria were as follows: Stroke patients who are 18 years old and older at the time of the survey (including ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes), stroke duration of at least 4 weeks, with no history of cardiovascular disease or other neurological disorders, and those who do not have communication and cooperation problems. In addition, other exclusion criteria were those who received a caution from their specialist physician about physical activity, other orthopedic and neurological diseases that could affect physical activity, or those who could not cooperate with mobilization. This study used a self-developed questionnaire, which was filled out over 4-8 weeks, and was assessed by the American Association of Functional Fitness (AAF), European Physical Activity Questionnaire (EPAQ), EuroQol-5 Dimensions-3 Levels questionnaire (EQ-5D-3L), and Short-Form 36 Health Status Survey (SF-36).

Five Study Arms for A Multifaceted Intervention to Improve Walking Function in Stroke Survivors

Study Overview
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
A 6-month multifaceted motor recovery treatment for hemiparesis, called SPRING, was designed based on available brain recovery plasticity research. SPRING integrates two existing evidence-based treatments, Neurodevelopmental training and sensorimotor training, to target impaired gait patterns, improve mobility, and address physical, social, and environmental factors that contribute to poor functioning and disability.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Background: Stroke is a leading cause of disability worldwide, with stroke survivors frequently describing poor physical mobility and dependence in daily activities as major concerns. Unfortunately, current interventions for improving walking function post-stroke use different approaches and techniques, yet none have been developed to address the multiple factors contributing to poor mobility. Objectives: The overall objective of the study is to determine the efficacy of a combined Neurodevelopmental Training and Sensorimotor Training (SpringBoard) program to improve functional ambulation for persons with stroke. Specific Goals and Hypotheses: •The primary goal of the study was to determine the effectiveness of a 6-month comprehensive multifaceted treatment of Neurodevelopmental Training (NDT) and Sensorimotor Training (SMT) to improve functional mobility, as measured by the 10-Meter Walk Test (10MWT). We hypothesized that participants in the SMT+NDT group would experience greater improvement in the 10MWT at 6-months compared to their same-time of year (SMy) assessment compared to participants in the other two groups (SMT, NDT). •The secondary goals of the study were to evaluate the effects of the treatment on other function measures (i.e., Functional Ambulation Categories (FAC), Rivermead Mobility Index (RMI), and

Study Design for Improving Gait Speed Following Stroke: a Randomized Control Trial

Abstract:
Background: Improving physical activity and enhancing gait are important treatment outcomes in patients with stroke. The benefits of a home‐based training programme have previously been evaluated, although only to the extent of 3 months follow up. Further follow‐up is necessary to assess the longer term impact of the intervention. Objectives: The aim of this study was to evaluate whether participation in a home‐based, monitored, lower limb strengthening and gait retraining programme, as part of usual care following a lower limb stroke, leads to positive changes in gait speed and physical activity 1 year post‐stroke which are maintained at 2 years. Design: A randomized control trial was conducted. Participants received intervention training for a period of 16 weeks. Outcomes were assessed at baseline, 12 months and 24 months. Participants: Volunteers (n=54) with a stroke affecting their lower limb gait, were randomized into 'usual care' and 'usual plus intervention' groups. Intervention: After 16 weeks, outcomes were reassessed (12 months) and then again after 8 months (24 months). Measurements: Gait speed measured using 10 metre walk test as the primary outcome measure. Secondary outcome measures included the Short Physical Performance Battery, timed up and go test, Physical Activity Scale for the Elderly and Stroke Related Quality of Life Questionnaire. Results: Participants in the intervention group demonstrated statistically significant improvement in gait speed (P=0.01), lower limbs strength (P=0.02) and balance (P=0.04) in addition to improvements on the secondary outcomes. The intervention group also maintained their physical activity levels throughout the study (P=0.006). There was no difference between the intervention and control groups in relation to stroke related measures. Conclusions: The intervention programme was effective in improving gait speed and strength, with improvements in gait speed seen to be maintained up to 2 years post‐stroke.

The main purpose of the study was to investigate the correlation between the time course of plasma concentrations of α‐tocopherol and their tissue concentrations in human fat during prolonged supplementation of vitamin E. Eight healthy human volunteers received a baseline dose of 400 IU vitamin E per day for at least 3 mo before undergoing a single‐arm liposuction procedure. The samples for the determination of alpha‐tocopherol concentrations were taken before the operation and 1, 3, 7, 15, 30, and 60 days after the initial vitamin E treatment. Results: The concentration of α‐tocopherol in plasma decreased rapidly to a level of 10% in 10‐14 days in all subjects. The initial half‐life of plasma vitamin E was 7‐14 days. In the fat tissue, this decrease continued to a level of 1% to 10% within 1‐3 wk. Half the initial concentration was reached between 2 and 3 wk. No significant increase in plasma vitamin E over basal levels was observed during this period. It is concluded that supplementation with a single dose of 400 IU vitamin E results in a half‐life for α‐tocopherol in plasma of 7‐14 days. In human fat, the half‐life of α‐tocopherol is considerably longer.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to investigate the effect of a 12-week exercise program in which the participant works at a 70%-85% heart rate range (known as HIIT) on improving their health. The study will include 30 participants from both the United States and China. Participants will be selected based on their heart rate and heart rate variability. The aim of the study is to reduce the participant's heart rate and heart rate variability by 12%. The investigators will examine if a heart rate of 85% or more will improve the participant's health in several ways.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this research study is to examine the effect of a HIIT (High Intensity Intermittent Training) exercise training program in a weight training gym as opposed to an internet or mobile app-based home training program on HR (heart rate) and HRV (heart rate variability) in young adults. The study aims to increase the participant's heart rate during exercise sessions and therefore improve their perceived effort and motivation during a 12-week exercise program. The study will evaluate heart rate and heart rate variability in the participant and determine if the program can decrease the participant's HR and HRV by 12%. The investigators have recruited the following participants: 30 undergraduate participants. The age range for the participants is 18-35 years of age and the gender is both male and female. The study will be conducted in a weight training gym. The study will consist of five time periods: Week 1, Week 3, Week 6, Week 9, and Week 11. Each time period will be 3 months in duration. At the start of the study, the participants will have to attend an introductory session where they will meet with the study personnel and familiarize themselves with the study. During the introductory session, the participants will receive a consent form and instruction on its completion. The participants will need to attend the study gym for an hour twice per week for 12 weeks. At the end of the trial, the participant will receive a certificate from the study team.

Study Overview
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
The study aim is to assess the impact of yoga on thoracolumbar flexibility and mobility in long-distance runners by comparing two groups of subjects: one practicing yoga and another doing conventional strength and endurance exercises. The primary endpoint measures the relative change in mobility of a group of long-distance runners practicing yoga compared to their peers not practicing yoga over a 12-week period.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Thoracolumbar flexibility in long-distance runners has been reportedly decreasing. We hypothesized that the reduction of thoracolumbar flexibility might have resulted in lower extremity overloads, especially in long-distance runners. Therefore, improving thoracolumbar flexibility is important, yet this aspect of injury prevention is understudied. Yoga is a promising option for runners to reduce lower extremity and lumbar-related symptoms. In addition to improved thoracolumbar flexibility, yoga encourages participants to become more self-aware, a crucial aspect for injury prevention. The main objective of this study is to investigate the impact of yoga on thoracolumbar flexibility and mobility in long-distance runners and compare the results with a group of runners who do not practice yoga. We will measure the flexibility and mobility of both groups using a tape measure, clinical assessment, and a movement capacity test. After baseline assessment, yoga training and/or strength and endurance exercises will be performed for 12 weeks. At the end of the intervention, we will compare the results from both groups. Our hypothesis is that the yoga group will experience a significant change in thoracolumbar flexibility and mobility, leading to improved postural alignment and reduced stress on the lower extremities. This will lead to reduced risk of lower extremity and lumbar-related injuries, improved performance, and better overall health in long-distance runners. The results of this study can provide valuable insights into the importance and benefits of yoga for improving running-related performance and reducing injuries. The findings will also contribute to the development of more effective training programs for long-distance runners.

Official Title

An Evaluation Method for Thoracolum

In the Sham Comparator: Sham tDCS arm, participants will attend five in-person visits in Week 1 for the administration of sham transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS). From Weeks 2 to 9, they will receive weekly sham tDCS sessions before the scheduled yoga sessions. The sham tDCS sessions will mimic the sensation of current without actual stimulation. Participants will also participate in the same yoga program led by a certified instructor.

Abstract:
Introduction: Postoperative pain after a total knee arthroplasty (TKA) remains a burden for patients and clinicians. In addition to opioids, intra‐articular injections with bupivacaine could provide pain relief in knee replacement surgeries. This study was designed to investigate if the pain experience can be reduced and better controlled using an intra‐articular infiltration of ropivacaine at the end of surgery in addition to patient‐controlled intravenous morphine administration. Methods: In this randomized, double‐blinded, controlled trial conducted on 142 patients (71 in each group) undergoing TKA, either bupivacaine 0.5% (control group, n=71) or ropivacaine 0.5% (intervention group, n=71) was injected into the joint before suturing, in addition to intravenous analgesia with morphine for 48h. The primary outcome was the numerical rating scale (NRS) pain scores for 48h. Pain scores at rest and with movement were measured for 48h with NRS scores, the total morphine consumption in milligrams, nausea and vomiting scores, and side effects such as headache, urinary retention or confusion. Results: NRS scores at rest after 48h of surgery showed a significant difference between groups in favour of the intervention group (p=0.036), as well as postoperative NRS scores whilst mobilizing (p=0.026), without any significant difference in terms of total morphine consumption. Discussion: Adding an intra‐articular ropivacaine injection to standard intravenous morphine analgesia in patients undergoing TKA can significantly reduce the severity of postoperative pain 48h after the operation.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of SIM01 as compared to placebo in non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) patients. SIM01 is an oral lipid-soluble dietary supplement composed of 20% omega-3 fatty acids (Eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), Docosahexaenoic Acid (DHA, Docosapentaenoic acid (DPA) and 80% phospholipids (PL) extracts) from fish. It is a composition standardized to a minimum of 70% omega-3 PL (EPA PL, DPA PL) obtained by fractionation of fish fish oil (Fish Oil) following double steam distillation process. The primary objective is to evaluate the effect of SIM01 compared to placebo on aminotransferase (AST), alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT), and, as secondary objectives, intrahepatic lipid content and histologic changes, on metabolism and fibrosis assessment, and on metabolic parameters.

Abstract:
Background: Inflammation has been reported to be associated with cardiovascular (CV) disease and related risk factors among women. A dietary pattern rich in carbohydrates with a low content of dietary fibre and antioxidants as well as high in saturated, polyunsaturated and trans fatty acids has been shown to be associated with an increased risk of cardiometabolic dysfunction, whereas a diet rich in fruit, vegetables, whole grains and lean meat has been shown to improve glycaemic control and vascular function. The present study aimed to examine, through a randomized controlled dietary intervention, the effect of a 4‐month intervention based on the Scandinavian Dietary Approach to Stop Hypertension Patten (DASH) on CV risk markers in a premenopausal cohort. Methods: Subjects were randomized to a DASH intervention or to a control group with free choice diet for 4 months, in which two 5‐week measurement periods were separated by a 2‐week follow‐up period. 42 women aged 35–50 years were recruited to participate in the study. Dietary intake was monitored by 24 h recalls and assessments of anthropometric variables, blood pressure, lipids, inflammatory markers, and endothelial function were conducted before and after the intervention. Results: Reduction in saturated fat and trans fat intake was observed for the DASH intervention compared to the control group. In addition, the decrease in systolic and diastolic blood pressure (−1.6%, p = 0.018 and −1.8 %, p < 0.001) and in the oxidized low‐density lipoprotein level (−5.0 %, p = 0.031) were only observed in the DASH group. There was also a decrease in lipoprotein(a) (−7.2 %, p = 0.013) and the inflammatory marker Tumour Necrosis Factor‐alpha (‐12.1 %, p = 0.037) among those in the DASH group.

Study Design for a Phase III Open-Label Extension Study of the Randomized Phase 3 E2202 trial (E2202-OLE).

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study is an open-label extension (OLE) of the randomized phase 3 study, E2202. The first randomized, active controlled, study designed to define the optimal dose for Zanubrutinib (Z) based on efficacy, toxicity, and patient tolerability in combination with rituximab (ZR) and bendamustine (BR) in newly diagnosed, transplant-ineligible MCL (E2202) patients will be amended to treat the patients who have discontinued E2202 with ibrutinib, venetoclax (V), or a combination of ZBR with V (ZVR) with continued single-agent treatment with ZR + BR until completion of treatment, and will then be able to transition and continue on the E2202 ZVR treatment until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity.

Detailed Description

This is an open-label extension (OLE) study to be sponsored by BeiGene. The main purpose of this study is to assess the safety/tolerability of the ongoing ZR BR combination therapy and to continue to evaluate the efficacy benefits of ZR BR combination therapy in transplant-ineligible patients as long as possible. The eligibility criteria for E2202 and the eligibility criteria for transition are exactly the same. If the patients meet the eligibility criteria and have finished two courses of their therapy in the first study, they can be eligible for the OLE study regardless of patient status in the first study. Abstract:
Introduction: One of the great challenges for an RCT (randomized controlled trial) is the distribution of participants' allocation to each study arm. Methods: In this study, we aimed to determine the performance of permuted and optimal block randomization for allocation concealment of participants in an RCT with two arms, under the assumption that the number of participants in each group can be determined by an exponential distribution. Based on the available population size and required sample size, we determined the number of required blocks in the permuted block randomization, such that the permutation probability becomes at least 80% for both groups. The effectiveness of permutation size, the number of blocks and the number of blocks per arm was tested in statistical models that showed good results in terms of allocation concealment and also determined the optimal design. By conducting 50,000 simulations, we tried to generate the most common results. Results: By comparing the effectiveness of different randomization strategies, we found that in the first block of an RCT with 2 arms, there are 83, 326, and 651 cases of imbalance in the allocation of the first participant to the two treatment groups. These figures, based on an RCT size of 100 subjects, indicate that using 6 blocks in the study, which was determined to be the most effective design based on our analysis, leads to an almost equal number of participants in each arm. In contrast, when only 1 block is used for randomization, the number of participants allocated to each arm is highly imbalanced, reaching 213 in one treatment group and 77 in the other, which significantly increases the error. Conclusion: The results of this study show that the use of permuted block randomization with a higher minimum permutation probability can be a useful method for randomizing the allocation of clinical trials, especially when participants are allocated to multiple study arms or when the study involves a long follow‐up period. It is important to note that this study was conducted numerically, based on assumptions about the distribution of the observed population. Abstract:
Introduction: The majority of patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) initially start mechanical ventilation as a temporary measure when the loss of function of respiratory muscles makes it difficult to maintain adequate breathing. However, a survey of 1278 patients participating in a US clinical trial showed that long term mechanical ventilation support was used by about half of them to prolong life. The decision to use long term mechanical ventilation in patients with ALS is usually based on a combination of the patient's disease stage and functional status, and this decision impacts survival in these patients and their families. Long term mechanical ventilation support might prolong life, however, may also require a high level of care and have a negative impact on quality of life for both patients and their partners and children. Aim: The purpose of the study is to investigate patient‐reported differences in perceived quality of life, mood, and health outcomes for ALS patients and their partners and children who accept long‐term mechanical ventilation support. Methods: The study design is a prospective observational, longitudinal study nested within a larger ongoing randomized controlled trial (RCT) involving patients with ALS. The study aims to enroll about 100 ALS patients and 200 of their partners and children to the existing cohort for this study. Participants will be randomized to either the group undergoing long‐term mechanical ventilation support or the group receiving standard of care. Participants will be followed at baseline and then monthly for five years. Discussion: There are three aims of the study: The first aim is to examine the possible effect of ALS trajectories on the care trajectory for ALS patients who start long‐term mechanical ventilation support. The second aim is to describe the decision‐making process for starting long‐term mechanical ventilation compared to standard care with home non‐invasive ventilation (NIV) support. The third aim is to describe the patient‐reported quality of life outcomes in both groups.

Abbreviations:
ALS: amyotrophic lateral sclerosis; RCTs: randomized controlled trials

Abstract:
Background: Chronic low back pain (CLBP) is a major public health problem that affects individuals and communities worldwide. It represents an enormous burden in terms of cost to the healthcare system and it is considered a priority research area. In Canada, CLBP is estimated to affect between 15% and 39% of the population and is associated with substantial health‐related quality of life impairment, work absenteeism and associated societal costs. Objectives: This paper presents a protocol for the implementation of the CANBACK‐II randomized controlled trial (RCT); the primary purpose of which is to examine the outcomes of chiropractic care provided within a group setting for the prevention of recurrent low back pain. An economic evaluation will also be conducted to document costs of different treatment patterns. Design/methods: CANBACK‐II is a multi‐site, single‐blinded, randomized controlled trial (RCT) comparing the cost and clinical effectiveness of up to 20 weekly group‐based, spinal manual therapy visits (N=80) or a control program that consists of a single visit from a chiropractor to discuss self‐care strategies (N=80). The trial will be conducted across Ontario, Canada. Participants with an episode of acute low back pain will be recruited at five University of Waterloo (UW) clinics as well as private community chiropractic offices. Inclusion criteria are: between 18 and 80 years, an episode of low back pain for at least the last 2 weeks prior to the index visit, pain intensity over the previous 24 hours of between 4 and 10 on a numeric pain rating scale (NPRS), and ability to comprehend English or French. Brief summary
=================
Hernia is a common surgical condition affecting an estimated 5% of adults, with an increased risk of complications such as incarceration, strangulation, and death. As a result, the accurate diagnosis of hernias is critical for proper treatment and prevention of complications. However, the diagnosis of abdominal wall hernia, which accounts for approximately 85% of all hernias, can be challenging due to a lack of consensus on diagnostic criteria. There is an urgent need to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of the different methods used to diagnose abdominal wall hernia and to determine which method yields the most accurate results. As the first part of this project, the diagnostic accuracy of clinical examination, computed tomography (CT), and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for diagnosing abdominal wall hernia in adults will be compared.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Major risk factors that have been implicated in the etiology of acute kidney injury (AKI), such as heart surgery, cardiac catheterization, major surgical procedures, sepsis, and others, have been established. However, a clearer understanding of AKI pathophysiology is necessary to develop effective treatments and prevention strategies. Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is a major form of AKI and may result from ischemia and/or nephrotoxins. ATN is characterized by a reduced ability of the tubular cells to pump water and electrolytes into the urine, which leads to a decrease in urinary output and volume overload. The investigators recently published preliminary data on a novel approach to treat ATN in rats injected with the nephrotoxin gentamicin. The novel approach was to provide a high-molecular weight (HMW) hyaluronic acid (HA), which interacts with cell surface hyaluronan receptor complexes to facilitate cell proliferation and increased expression of the epithelial sodium channel in the tubular epithelium. They showed that pretreatment with the HMW HA reduced ATN after gentamicin administration. The investigators plan to test this approach to inhibit ATN induced by kidney ischemia/reperfusion in non-human primates. This is a pivotal step in preparation for clinical trials in humans. Ischemia-reperfusion causes acute tubular necrosis in animals and humans. Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is the most common form of acute kidney injury (AKI) and increases morbidity and mortality. ATN is also associated with chronic kidney disease. Ischemia-reperfusion kidney injury is a pre-clinical model to evaluate potential preventive and/or therapeutic strategies in humans. The pre-clinical studies will provide data that will guide future clinical trials.

Abstract:
Stroke management has improved significantly in recent years. However, the transfer of patients from primary stroke centers to specialized tertiary centers remains one of the key challenges. Telemedicine has emerged as a potential solution to improve the speed and accuracy of stroke management. This study aims to assess the impact of a standardized mobile telephone loop system in patients who undergo mechanical thrombectomy for acute ischemic stroke. Methods: We conducted a monocentric cohort study of prospectively collected data on all consecutive patients with an indication for mechanical thrombectomy. The patients were allocated to 3 periods: (1) a baseline period prior to the introduction of the telestroke system, (2) an implementation period where the telestroke system was introduced, and (3) a post‐implementation period where the system was in use but not actively promoted. Time in minutes between hospital stroke team activation and endovascular thrombectomy procedure start was recorded for each patient. The primary outcome was time reduction associated with the introduction of an alarming system. Results: A total of 71 patients were included in the 3 groups, 25, 25, and 21 patients during the baseline, implementation, and post‐implementation periods, respectively. The median time between stroke team activation and procedure start was 108.5 minutes in the baseline period, 58 minutes in the implementation period, and 79.5 minutes in the post‐implementation period. The median time reduction in this study period, from the start of alerting to the start of the endovascular thrombectomy procedure, ranged from 47.8 to 51 minutes (mean differences 0.8 to 11.8 minutes). Conclusion: Although the median time reduction between stroke team activation and procedure start was significant, there was no time reduction in the post‐implementation period.

Exactly! The design of the study arms considers both the immediate and long-term impact of the standardized alarming system on treatment times and workflow in stroke patients with interhospital transfer for thrombectomy. You can continue working on it!

Study Overview
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
This is an open-label, multicenter, Phase 1/2 study of RVU120 in combination with venetoclax (VEN) for patients with relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia (r/r AML) and/or myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS).

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is an open-label, multicenter, Phase 1/2 study to evaluate the safety and tolerability, explore the efficacy and recommend the Phase 2 dosing regimen of RVU120 and VEN for patients with R/R AML and/or MDS. During the Phase 1 portion, two dose levels of RVU120 in combination with two dose levels of VEN will be evaluated in patients with R/R AML and/or intermediate-2, high-risk (i.e.; International Prognostic Scoring System [IPSS]-R score ≥5 or adverse cytogenetics including t(8;21), iCBFB-MYH11, t(16;16), or complex karyotype). Starting dose cohorts in the Phase 1 portion of the study will be determined based on available toxicity data from the AML cohort in previous studies of RVU120 administered alone or in combination with investigational or marketed agents for the same indications. During the Phase 2 portion, efficacy and safety will be analyzed in all evaluable patients with r/r AML and/or MDS enrolled in the dose cohorts that demonstrate a satisfactory safety and/or tolerability profile during the Phase 1 portion of the study. The Phase 2 portion of the study will enroll up to approximately 140 patients with r/r AML and/or MDS. Patients of any age who provide informed consent are eligible to participate in this study.

Official Title
-----------------
A Phase 1/2 Study of Oral RVU

Description:: The study design is a phase 1 adaptive parallel-design randomised dose-escalation study in which the dose of RVU120 will be escalated or de-escalated depending on pre-specified safety and efficacy criteria. For dose escalation, four dose levels have been selected of RVU120 to be administered in combination with Venetoclax, these being; 125, 250, 375 and 500 mg every other day for 13 consecutive days followed by 8 days off (days 1-16 & 22-24) every 21-days for up to four cycles (28-days). The maximum starting dose in the expansion phase will be dependent upon the dose limiting toxicity and recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) from the dose escalation phase. 
For the phase 2 expansion study, there will be two separate arms; one arm will consist of patients receiving RVU120 every other day for 13 consecutive days followed by 8 days off (days 1-16 & 22-24) every 21-days for up to four cycles (28-days) (Arm II) and another arm will consist of patients receiving RVU120 twice every day on days 1-14 of each 21-days cycle for the first cycle followed by every other day for 13 consecutive days followed by 8 days off (days 1-16 & 22-24) every 21-days for the remaining 3 cycles (Arm III).  
Arm II:
Randomisation to Arm II will be an open label, parallel design with two dose levels of RVU120 of 250 and 500 mg. Patients with de novo and relapsed/refractory AML who are ineligible for intensive chemotherapy or who have relapsed after intensive chemotherapy will be enrolled onto Arm II.

This is the component of the intervention that engages with social connection and aims to strengthen existing relationships. The remaining prompts for expressive writing will be the same as those in the TNB Identity Affirmation (IA) Condition. It is important to mention that after completing the letter of gratitude, participants will be instructed to destroy it or keep it private, depending on their preference. This is done to ensure that the individual's privacy is maintained and that the gratitude letter is not seen by others. At the end of each writing task, participants will be reminded to save their written responses in their private electronic journal, stored on the participant's personal device. groundtruth: For the TNB Identity Affirmation (IA) Condition, participants will receive the same prompt for all four days of writing. This design, often used in expressive writing interventions, allows for deeper and continued reflection into specific thoughts and emotions. The prompt will involve reading a vignette that describes the experience and response of a young adult who experiences rejection from a close friend after a first disclosure of their gender identity. Participants will then be asked to write in response to three prompts: 1) identify expressions of internalized transphobia in the vignette character, 2) reflect on times the participant has experienced similar feelings, 3) identify thoughts and feelings that promote and support a positive and affirming identity in contrast to negative emotions and thoughts.

In the IA + Strengthening Social Connections (SSC) Condition, participants will complete the TNB Identity Affirmation intervention on the first three days, following the same prompts as the previous arm. On the fourth day, participants will be directed to compose a brief letter of gratitude to an individual to whom they have not previously expressed gratitude, and who has provided meaningful and affirming support to them as a TNB person. This additional component aims to further enhance social connections and gratitude, which are important factors in promoting well-being.

In the Control Condition, participants will engage in expressive writing about events of the day, without any specific prompts related to TNB identity or social connections. This neutral writing task will serve as a comparison to evaluate the specific impact of the TNB Identity Affirmation and Social Connection interventions on reducing internalized stigma and promoting well-being, compared to general expressive writing.

Exactly! You have successfully designed the study arms. These arms will allow us to assess the impact of TNB Identity Affirmation and Social Connection interventions on reducing stigma and promoting well-being in TNB individuals. Well done!

Background
-----------------
Currently, invasive bacterial infections (IBI) are treated with β-lactam antibiotics as a single agent. However, a substantial proportion of IBIs are caused by bacteria with intrinsic or acquired resistance to β-lactams. A combination of a β-lactam with a β-lactamase inhibitor (BLI) to treat IBIs is a very attractive therapeutic option because of high clinical efficacy and low resistance rates. Ermonate, a once-daily oral combination of meropenem and vaborbactam, has shown clinical non-inferiority vs β-lactam monotherapy in a well-controlled phase 3 study for the treatment of IBIs. This study in adults is an analysis of the safety and tolerability of Ermonate in adults and adolescents with IBI. Safety and efficacy of IBI management with Ermonate will also be compared with that of best available therapy (BAT). This will increase the likelihood that Ermonate will be used effectively to treat IBI, especially in difficult locations and in vulnerable populations. Methods

Design
-----------------

   Participant Group/Arm: Children aged 6 to 8 years
   Intervention/Treatment: Fruit-flavored drink with allulose at Dose 2 (4.3 g per 120 ml)
   Reasoning: This arm is important to compare the gastrointestinal tolerance of a higher dose of d-allulose with the lower dose. It allows us to determine if there is a dose-dependent response in terms of gastrointestinal symptoms and tolerance in children.

3. Placebo Comparator: Control (CON)
   Participant Group/Arm: Children aged 6 to 8 years
   Intervention/Treatment: Control drink containing high fructose corn syrup
   Reasoning: This arm serves as a control to compare the effects of d-allulose with a placebo. By using a control drink with high fructose corn syrup, we can evaluate the specific impact of d-allulose on gastrointestinal tolerance in comparison to a known substance. The participants will be divided into the TD cohort and the non-TD cohort based on the diagnosis of tumor deposits by the pathologists at the department of pathology. We define TD in accordance with the 2022 WTF guidelines. For patients in the TD cohort, we recommend careful surgery and pathological examination to exclude any missed cases. Patients undergo lobectomy or total thyroidectomy and central lymph node dissection with or without lateral neck dissection following the standard diagnostic and therapeutic protocol. The thyroidectomy technique is standardised to minimise tissue injury. After the operation, the pathologists histopathologically examined the specimens to determine whether there were any missed cases. For patients in the non-TD group, we also recommend careful surgery and pathological examination to exclude any missed cases. The thyroidectomy technique and postoperative pathological examination are the same as those used for the TD cohort.

Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: This study assessed the effectiveness of progressive pressure release (PPR) therapy for painful trigger points in the Flexor Digitourum Brevis (FDB) muscle.BACKGROUND: Trigger points can cause various symptoms such as pain and discomfort, and a trigger point in the FDB muscle can cause hallux valgus.PATIENTS AND METHODS: We randomly assigned 74 participants into two groups, intervention and control groups. The intervention group received PPR therapy on painful trigger points and the control group did not receive any intervention, and both groups had bilateral FDB trigger points. We assessed the pain intensities in both groups using a visual analogue scale (VAS) for pain.RESULTS: The mean changes in the FDB trigger point VAS were 2.34 ± 2.39 points for the controls and 2.37 ± 2.42 points for the intervention group. There was no statistical significance (p = 0.975). Similarly, there was no statistical difference between both mean changes in the bilateral FDB trigger point VAS (p = 0.975).CONCLUSIONS: PPR therapy has no short‐term effect on a trigger point in the FDB muscle.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: There is a paucity of information on the characteristics of renal function following organ trauma in kidney donors, and the incidence and severity of delayed‐graft function (DGF). We aimed to conduct a prospective study of the relationship between renal ischemia‐reperfusion injury and clinical outcomes in kidney donors, focusing on the incidence of DGF and its associated risk factors.METHODS: Kidneys from 229 consecutive deceased donors were retrieved and allocated for transplantation according to allocation time. Recipients were allocated to two groups based on allocation time: urgent/emergency transplants (UE) and scheduled transplants (S). Renal ischemia‐reperfusion injury was calculated using the creatinine increment from admission (baseline) to after reperfusion. Posttransplantation outcomes, including graft survival, eGFR recovery, and hospitalization, were observed.RESULTS: At 3 months, 49 kidneys were found to be in the UE group and 180 kidneys were found to be in the S group. Multivariable analysis showed a relationship between ischemia‐reperfusion injury and higher risk of DGF [odds ratio (95% CI) = 0.79 (0.64, 0.98), P=0.037]. Graft survival was significantly different between the UE group [100% at five years, p<0.001 (Fig 1), but after multivariable analysis a relationship with ischemia‐reperfusion injury could not be demonstrated.CONCLUSION: Renal ischemia‐reperfusion injury is a significant risk factor for higher rates of DGF in kidney transplants retrieved from deceased donors. As early as three months, graft survival does not appear to be affected by this injury, but long‐term follow‐up is needed.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of two treatment methods (manipulation and injection of autologous adipose tissue) in patients with temporo‐mandibular joint dysfunctions (TMDDs). Methods: The study included 27 subjects (13 females and 14 males) with TMDD. The inclusion criteria for the study were complaints of TMDD as well as a negative response score on the Palmers's diagnostic criteria for TMDD. Following diagnostic and pre‐treatment evaluations, patients were randomly allocated to one of three groups. The first group (group I) received only manipulative treatment and a cervical pillow according to a modified method of Mulligan. The second group (group II) received only one injection of harvested autologous adipose tissue according to Lekine et al.'s method while the third group (group III) received both manipulative treatment, as well as a cervical pillow. All of the patients were evaluated with visual analog scales of pain intensity as well as the masticatory function before treatment and at 7 and 14 days after treatment. Statistical analyses included the chi‐square test, ANOVA, and the Friedman test. A P value of 0.05 was considered statistically significant. Results: At 7 and 14 days after treatment, patients in all groups showed significant reduction in pain intensity and increased masticatory function score but no statistically significant difference between groups was found. Conclusion: Both the manipulative treatment and injection of adipose tissue can reduce pain intensity and improve the masticatory function in patients with TMDD.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this study is to improve the early diagnosis of Cystic Fibrosis (CF) and its associated complications by introducing an Early Screening Program. The study aims to screen 5,000 families with cystic fibrosis in the UK for the most common CF mutations. This will allow early diagnosis and access to treatment for those children found to carry the mutation.

Detailed Description
-----------------
CF is the most common genetic disease affecting the UK population. It causes lung, bowel and glandular problems. Symptoms of CF can go unrecognised and it is often months or years before it receives treatment. This delay can lead to serious health complications and premature death. Newborn screening is now available to identify the most common genetic mutations which are known to cause CF but there is a wide variation in uptake for this screening. This study aims to improve cystic fibrosis (CF) diagnosis, reduce delays in diagnosis, and reduce serious health complications and deaths. Patients will be recruited to determine whether an Early Screening Program will be successful. Participants will attend a routine Newborn Heel Prick, with parents informed about the benefits of early diagnosis and inclusion in the screening program. If agreed, CF genetic blood samples will be sent for analysis. If a child screens positive for CF, their parents will be contacted with the support of the CF nurse team at Oxford John Radcliffe Hospital (OUH). A further saliva sample will be collected 3 weeks after birth from the child for re-analysis using a newer technique. The study will include all 72 Health Board Areas in England, Scotland and Wales. After screening 5,000 families, this study aims to show that this program is successful. Parents will be asked to provide written consent, and all participants will remain anonymous. The study does not involve any medical treatments, drugs or invasive procedures and will not harm the child in any way. The study is aimed at improving existing NHS policy, and will not benefit directly from the research.

Official Title

Improving Early Screening for Cystic Fibrosis Using an Anonymous National DNA Program

Abstract:
Background: The risk of dyslipidemia increases with advancing age and exposure to obesity and diabetes. Whether there is a direct association between dyslipidemia and osteoporosis (OP) is not clear because they are not known to be under the same endocrine control. The purpose of this study was to investigate the association of dyslipidemia with OP in elderly individuals in China. Methods: This cross‐sectional study recruited 1528 elderly patients from China and the data about dyslipidemia and OP was collected. The association between dyslipidemia and OP was estimated using Cox proportional hazards regression and multivariable logistic regression. Results: Patients with dyslipidemia had an increased risk of OP and total hip fracture (THF) than patients without dyslipidemia. Specifically, a strong association between dyslipidemia and lumbar spine and femoral neck BMD (BN‐LS and BNF) and incident low BMD (LBMD) was observed in men only. Further analysis showed that the association between dyslipidemia and BNF in men existed in patients aged <80 years old. Discussion: The presence of dyslipidemia is associated with an increased risk of OP and THF, especially in men aged <80 years old. Further study should focus on underlying mechanisms and investigate which specific dyslipidemia is the true associated factor.

Abstract:
Background The purpose of this study is to show the therapeutic effects of intramyometrial injection of botulinum toxin A (BTX‐A) during pregnancy on the muscle symptoms of primary dystonia secondary to cerebral palsy(CP) and explore the mechanism of action. Methods Moving thumb dystonia (MTD) was induced bilaterally with a double‐blind crossover randomized controlled trial. Patients were received BTX‐A 5U (N=33) or placebo (N=30) intramyometrially between 24 and 32 weeks of gestation into myometrial muscles of each thigh. Their clinical features were recorded pre‐and post‐treatment. Also, we compared two groups on clinical efficacy, delivery characteristics, and neonatal outcomes. Result Two months after the injection were performed, the severity of MTD decreased significantly in the BTX‐A group (p<0.001) compared with the placebo group. The incidence of labor induction(18.2% vs. 66.7%) was reduced in the BTX‐Agroup, and significantly less neonates had facial asymmetry(54.8% vs.100%). There were no cases of postpartum hemorrhage or neonatal intensive care unit transfer due to respiratory distress or hypoglycemia in both groups. Conclusion Botulinum toxin A injection is a safe and effective method to alleviate the symptoms of intrauterine MTD without affecting neonatal outcome.

Intervention
=================
The study include 2 main arms:1. A descriptive cohort of children with cleft palate:  We will collect demographic and clinical data from children with clef palate who attend the Speech Therapy clinic at the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD) (N=150), as well as a comparison group of normally developing children (N=150). We will use a matched control group of normally developing children to ensure that the observed differences in language outcomes in children with cleft palate are attributable to their cleft condition, rather than other factors such as socio-economic status or genetic influences that may influence language development. 2. A randomized controlled trial (RCT) to evaluate the effectiveness of a speech training intervention: The RCT will include 100 children with cleft palate and their randomly assigned peers. Participants will be randomly assigned using a block-randomized design with a block size of 3, stratified by age and cleft type. Half of the children in the intervention group will receive the speech training intervention, and the other half will receive a placebo intervention. 

Intervention
=================
The intervention consists of a 12-week speech training intervention designed to improve the articulation of consonants and vowels in children with cleft palate. The intervention will include 12 one-on-one sessions with a speech therapist, with three sessions per week for the first four weeks, and two sessions per week for the remaining eight weeks. The intervention will use a combination of exercises, visual aids, and electronic speech devices to help children learn how to produce clear and accurate speech sounds. 

The placebo intervention will consist of 12 one-on-one sessions with a speech therapist, with three sessions per week for the first four weeks, and two sessions per week for the remaining eight weeks. The placebo intervention will involve the use of general speech therapy techniques, but will not include any specialized exercises or therapy strategies designed to improve articulation

Study Summary
=================
RATIONALE: Drugs used in chemotherapy, such as atezolizumab or ROSE12, work in different ways to stop the growth of tumor cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing. The combination of these drugs may kill more tumor cells. PURPOSE: Phase I trial to study the effectiveness of ROSE12 alone and in combination with atezolizumab in treating patients who solid tumors.

Detailed Description
-----------------
OBJECTIVES: Primary Determine maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of ROSE12 in combination with atezolizumab in solid tumors. Estimate progression-free survival (PFS) rate at 6 months Determine the safety and tolerability of ROSE12 in combination with atezolizumab in solid tumors. Exploratory Determine RECIST1.1 response and clinical benefit rates, assessed by an independent central radiology adjudication committee Secondary Determine pharmacokinetic profiles of ROSE12 and atezolizumab in combination in both cohorts OUTLINE: This is a dose-escalation study of ROSE12 followed by a phase II portion with ROSE12 + atezolizumab. Patients are assigned to 1 of up to 3 cohorts. Cohort 1: Patients receive ROSE12 intravenously (IV) over 15-120 minutes on day 1 and atezolizumab IV over 1-30 minutes on day 1. Treatment repeats every 21 days in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. Cohort 2: Patients receive atezolizumab IV over 1 hour on day 1 only. Cohort 3: A dose cohort of ROSE12 + atezolizumab will be enrolled at a dose of ROS-12 administered at the recommended phase II dose (RP2D) from the ROSE12 arm (Cohort 1) in combination with atezolizumab administered at the same dose as in Cohort 2. Background:
=================
Solid tumors are a group of cancers that originate in tissues, such as the bones, muscles, and organs, as opposed to liquid or blood-based cancers. These tumors are a diverse collection of different cells with various genetic alterations that can lead to abnormal cell growth, resulting in the formation of a mass.

While there has been significant progress in the treatment and management of solid tumors in recent years, several patients do not respond well to current therapies and have a poor prognosis. Furthermore, there is always a demand for new and innovative treatments that are more targeted and effective.

Anti-PD-1 antibodies are a class of monoclonal antibodies that selectively bind to PD-1, a protein found on immune cells that helps to regulate the immune response. By blocking PD-1, these antibodies can enhance the body's immune response against cancer cells.

One such antibody, Atezolizumab, has been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for the treatment of several types of solid tumors. However, some patients may still have inadequate responses to Atezolizumab monotherapy, and there is a need to identify new and more effective treatment approaches.

Previous research suggests that the immune system plays a crucial role in the development of solid tumors. Therefore, it is plausible that targeting the immune system through a combination therapy may produce better outcomes than monotherapy. This rationale is supported by the fact that immune checkpoint inhibitors, such as anti-PD-1 antibodies, have been shown to be effective in clinical trials.

Abstract:
Background and study aims: It is unknown if non‐alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), the most common chronic liver disease, shares environmental risk factors in common with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Using data from the UK Biobank cohort (https://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk), we aim to compare risk factors for NAFLD in individuals with RA to the general population to identify potential environmental triggers of NAFLD in this inflammatory muscle and joint disease. Method: Participants were divided into two groups: 1918 individuals with RA and 44,299 UKB participants without RA. Age, sex, and body mass index (BMI) were collected, as well as self‐reported physical activity, medication usage (anti‐inflammatory drugs, aspirin, prednisone, non‐steroidal anti‐ inflammatory drugs, systemic immunosuppressants), tobacco use, and alcohol consumption. Odds ratios (ORs) were obtained using logistic regression and expressed as the ratio of the number of patients with NAFLD in each group. Adjustment of ORs obtained from logistic regression analysis was performed using the step‐down procedure using an F‐test. Results: In the univariate analysis, individuals with RA were 4.5 times as likely to have NAFLD as those without RA (OR = 4.5, 95% CI: 3.62‐5.69, p<0.001). The adjusted OR (AOR) = 4.69 (95% CI: 3.74‐5.89, p<0.001). The RA group had a significantly higher BMI (30.5 kg/m2 vs. 29.4 kg/m2, p<0.05). Medication usage, tobacco use, and alcohol consumption were not significantly different between those with and without RA

groundtruth: Great! Based on the information you've provided, I can help you design the study arms. Let's start with the first arm, the active comparator: 4H group. This arm consists of children who will fast for more than 4 hours before sedation. This arm consists of children who will fast for 1 hour before sedation, with the allowance of oral hydration (water). The intervention in this arm is 1 hour of fasting time, where oral intake, except for water, is not allowed for 4 hours before sedation, while water intake is allowed up to 1 hour before sedation. The reasoning behind this arm is to test the new fasting policy and evaluate its safety and efficacy. Allowing water intake until 1 hour before sedation aims to reduce the risks associated with prolonged fasting, such as hypoglycemia and dehydration. What do you think about this arm?

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of the study is to describe the number of readmissions, time to readmissions and rehospitalization rates within 30 days and 1, 3, 6, and 12 months in veterans after an episode of Sepsis. An episode is defined as a sepsis event followed by an ICU stay. Sepsis events will be identified using ICD-9 billing diagnoses and ICU utilization data within the Veterans Affairs (VA). The VA Corporate Data Warehouse (CDW) will also be used to assess rehospitalization rates and length of hospital stay within 30 days and 1, 3, 6, and 12 months. The study will leverage the VA's Enterprise Data Warehouse (EDW) to identify Sepsis patients and conduct a national cohort study. The data in the EDW are de-identified for confidentiality and the researchers will use statistical software, SAS® 9.4 to conduct all analyses and build a model which identifies the risk factors for 30-day readmission within 30 days, 1, 3, 6, and 12 months. Additionally, we will determine the incidence of sepsis events within 30 days, 1, 3, 6, and 12 months from index hospitalization within the VA by using billing data only.

Official Title
-----------------
Retrospective Epidemiologic Study of Risk Factors for 30-Day and 1-Year Readmission After Hospitalization for Sepsis in Veterans

Sepsis

* Other: no intervention

Study Summary
=================
RATIONALE: Tested compounds may improve the symptoms of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). PURPOSE: This randomized clinical trial is studying how well testing compounds to see how they work in treating patients with chemoprevention-selected NSCLC.

Detailed Description
-----------------
OBJECTIVES: I. Establish proof-of-concept that the administration of cisplatin and/or paclitaxel can improve the time to recurrence in patients with NSCLC after a period of chemoprevention with celecoxib. II. Establish proof-of-concept that the administration of cisplatin and/or paclitaxel can improve overall survival time in patients with NSCLC after a period of chemoprevention with celecoxib. III. Assess the incidence of grade 4 toxicity (as defined by the National Cancer Institute Common Toxicity Criteria 4.0) in patients receiving the cisplatin/paclitaxel combination for chemoprevention-selected NSCLC. OUTLINE: Patients are randomized to 1 of 2 arms. ARM I: Patients receive celecoxib orally (PO) once daily (QD) on days 1-28. ARM II: Patients receive oral celecoxib QD on days 1-28. Beginning on day 1, patients receive cisplatin IV over 15-60 minutes and paclitaxel IV over 1-3 hours on day 1 and then undergo total thoracoscopic wedge resection (TTWR)-based tumor resection. Treatment repeats every 28 days for up to 4 courses in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. After completion of study treatment, patients are followed up every 3 months for up to 2 years.

Brief Summary
-----------------
The present prospective, randomized, controlled trial is intended to compare the surgical approaches for the dissection of bilateral neck nodes on the occipito-cervical region in open surgery to achieve complete removal of cervical lymph nodes (LNs) in patients treated for squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SCCHN). The patients of the surgical group will undergo supra-omohyoid dissection following neck dissection. The procedure will be performed by two experienced surgeons in the departments of Onco-Head and Neck-Surgery.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Lay Summary: The present prospective randomized, controlled trial is intended to compare the surgical approaches for the dissection of bilateral neck nodes on the occipito-cervical region in open surgeries, in order to achieve complete removal of all LNs. This study will be conducted at the outpatient clinics and operating room of the departments of Onco-Head and Neck-Surgery and Plastic-Reconstructive Surgery, Faculty of Medicine, Cairo University. Patients diagnosed with SCCHN in the departments, whose treatment plan specifies head and neck surgery associated with a neck dissection, will be offered to the study. One hundred (100) patients aged between 18-75 will be included in the trial. 50 patients with American Joint Committee of Cancer (AJCC, 7th edition, 2010) stages IA (2-3 cm, depth ≤4 mm) IIA (2-3 cm, depth >4 mm) or IB (<2 cm, depth ≤4 mm) tumors will be assigned to receive either a conventional neck dissection (CND) or supra-omohyoid dissection (SOD) as part of their treatment plan. Patients will be randomly assigned into two groups, A or B, through a computer-generated randomization code. Each treatment will be performed by two experienced surgeons in the departments of Onco-Head and Neck-Surgery or Otolaryngology - Head and Neck Surgery and assigned in equal numbers in each group
