Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
There has not been any research looking at how the changes in the endometrial cancer cause changes in the way it looks on an MRI scan and whether this can help doctors to predict its response to treatment with chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy after surgery. This project will attempt to answer these questions. The main objective is to determine whether molecular pathology in patients with newly diagnosed endometrial cancer could be used to predict response to chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy after surgery.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Endometrial cancer is the most common gynaecological cancer and the fourth most common cancer in women in the UK, it affects 1 out of every 43 women from mid life onwards. It almost exclusively affects women of reproductive age. The only effective treatment of this disease is surgery and in some patients follow up treatment with chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy. However, there is great variation in the way endometrial cancer behave and there are currently no biological markers to help individualise treatment for patients with this disease. MRI scans are used extensively in the diagnosis of endometrial cancer by identifying suspicious tumour lesions in and around the uterus. Patients sometimes receive a further MRI scan to estimate residual disease post-operatively. Current imaging techniques are not able to accurately determine the extent of cancer in the body, and furthermore there is no test to predict disease recurrence following treatment. In addition, the imaging techniques available at present are not able to distinguish between benign lesions and low grade malignant lesions. Therefore, more than half of the operations performed for endometrial cancer are potentially avoidable. Recently it has been shown that MRI scans can identify tumour cells based on their metabolism, so-called MRI-detected tumour microenvironment (MRI TME) biomarkers. Endometrial cancer is strongly associated with increased insulin sensitivity and insulin-driven cancer progression and resistance to chemotherapy and radiotherapy. Using these scans the team aims to determine the molecular correlates of both radiological and pathological features of endometrial cancer. This will involve comparing the molecular profiles

Abstract:
The present study was designed to evaluate antigen presenting ability of dendritic cells after stimulation with the anti‐tumor necrosis factor antibody infliximab in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and patients with Crohn's disease in remission. In 24 RA patients (12 on infliximab) and 12 Crohn's patients on maintenance‐ dose infliximab, ex vivo stimulation of peripheral blood mononuclear cells with the anti‐tumor necrosis factor monoclonal antibody infliximab increased ex vivo antigen processing capacity of monocyte‐derived dendritic cells and increased ex vivo T‐helper type 1 (TH1) and T‐helper type 2 (TH2) immune responses to allosensitization in patients with normal TH1/TH2 ratios. Infliximab stimulated increased TH2 activity in patients with high TH2/TH1 ratios in the presence of allosensitization. By contrast, a single dose of 5 mg/kg infliximab did not induce significant stimulation of the antigen presenting function of monocyte‐derived dendritic cells or a TH1 or TH2 immune response in 15 healthy volunteers. These results suggest that infliximab selectively activates the antigen presenting ability of dendritic cells in patients with RA in remission and those with Crohn's disease in remission and leads to significant T‐cell activation in vivo.

The purpose of this study is to observe the local effects of an anti-inflammatory drug (dexamethasone intravitreal implant) in patients with diabetic macular edema (DME) not responsive to intravitreal bevacizumab therapy. This study compares the improvement of vision after switching from intravitreal bevacizumab therapy to dexamethasone implant treatment, for patients with DME for whom treatment with bevacizumab is no longer effective. Intravitreal bevacizumab therapy usually consists of injections up to every 5-7 weeks. Conversely, for patients treated with a single intravitreal dexamethasone implant, injections of anti-VEGF are no longer required. The goal is to assess the efficacy and safety of switching from bevacizumab to a dexamethasone implant, when indicated for a patient with DME unresponsive after 3 intravitreal injections of bevacizumab. The hypothesis is that the results obtained with a dexamethasone implant will allow a reduction in the frequency of injections and the overall treatment burden, as well as improve the visual outcome and reduce the associated costs. Informed consent was obtained from all subjects involved in the study.

1. Abstract
Objectives: Acne has been proved to be a chronic skin disease. This study is aimed at exploring the efficacy of Chinese medicine compound decoction in treating acne in children. Patients and methods: 106 children aged 5‐18 diagnosed with acne vulgaris were recruited and randomly divided into medication group (107 cases) and control group (106 cases) in accordance with the random number table method. Medication group received herbal compound decoction in addition to 0.05% benzoyl peroxide gel, while control group only received 0.05% benzoyl peroxide gel. The efficacy and clinical signs were monitored after 6 weeks of treatment. After finishing the treatment, the recurrence rate of acne was also analyzed. Results: The effective rate of medication group was 92.7% (95% CI of the effective rate was (90.5%, 94.9%). The recurrence rate was 17.8 ± 9.6%, which was much lower than that in the control group. Patients' acne was alleviated to a large extent in medication group, and there were no relapses even 2-3 months later (P<0.05). 
Conclusion: Herbal compound decoction combined with 0.05% benzoyl peroxide gel in treating acne has high effectiveness and few side effects. It is effective in relieving the symptoms and accelerating the cure.
1. Introduction
Acne is a common skin disease among adolescents, of which acne vulgaris accounts for 75% . It has been proved that acne vulgaris is caused by bacteria, and its occurrence and development are related to the following factors: exogenous invasion of bacteria, endogenous influence of hormones, and unhealthy habits. Clinically, many herbal drugs have been studied for treating acne. However, the results are still being controversial.
